He said that this Case was filed to tarnish the image of former MP Duminda Silva, therefore, he has been denied a justifiable trial similar to that of any other citizen is entitled to in this Case.
 
The appeal will be called again tomorrow.

heading: Joint Opposition seeks debate on who had obtained money from PTL
description:
The Joint Opposition is making preparations to request a parliamentary debate regarding the Central Bank Bond Scam and of persons who had obtained money from Perpetual Treasuries owner Arjun Aloysius.
 
A Joint Opposition MP told us that the Joint Opposition is to inform Speaker Karu Jayasuriya regarding this at the party leaders' meeting scheduled to be held today (Jun 05).
 
While 2 MPs publicly accepted that they had obtained money from Perpetual Treasuries owner, Arjun Aloysius, 37 MPs had said by day-before-yesterday that they did not obtain money from Aloysius.

heading: Neomal & Emil Ranjan further remanded
description: IP Neomal Rangajeewa and Prisons' Commissioner Emil Ranjan Lamahewa, who were arrested over Welikada Prison riots have been further remanded until 19th of June.

heading: 3 MP's vying for Speaker's post
description:
As 3 names have been proposed for the vacant post of Deputy Speaker, a vote will be called to select a suitable nominee for the position.
 
The Deputy Secretary General of the Parliament Neil Iddawela noted that a secret vote will take place.
 
Monaragala MP Ananda Kumarasiri has been nominated by the UNP.
 
MP Ajith Mannapperuma expressing his views to the media noted that following the group meeting held yesterday, the Prime Minister agreed to the nomination.
 
In addition, Jaffna district MP Angajan Ramanadan has been nominated by the SLFP for the Deputy Speaker position.
 
The SLFP team of 16 which resigned from the unitary government has nominated MP Sudarshani Fernandopulle.
 
The leader of the Joint Opposition MP Dinesh Gunawardena noted that a decision would be taken regarding the Deputy Speaker position following the parliamentary group meeting which is scheduled for this morning (Jun 05).

heading: Kaduwela Councillors stage a black armband protest
description:
The Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna Councillors of the Kaduwela Municipal Council arrived at the sessions today (Jun 05) wearing black armbands protesting the current political situation in the country and 20th amendment to the constitution.
 
Our correspondent said around 20 SLPP councillors took part in the agitation.
 
When the SLPP councillors were entering the chamber, the councillors from the United National Party had protested against them.

heading: Bandula challenges Malik for a debate on SL – Singapore FTA
description:
Joint Opposition Parliamentarian Dr. Bandula Gunawardena challenges Minister Malik Samarawickrama for a public debate on the Sri Lanka - Singapore Free Trade Agreement.
 
Addressing a media conference in Colombo today (Jun 05), Dr. Gunawardena labelled the FTA as a treason and said that it would unable to be corrected even in the future.

heading: President visits SLFP headquarters
description:
President Maithripala Sirisena has made a surprise visit to the Sri Lanka Freedom Party headquarters on T. B. Jayah Mawatha.
 
An SLFP spokesperson said that the President arrived there this morning (Jun 05) and thereafter had discussions with new office bearers of the party including its General Secretary, Professor, Rohana Lakshman Piyadasa and National Organizer, Minister, Duminda Dissanayake.
 
The UPFA General Secretary, Minister, Mahinda Amaraweera, SLFP Assistant Secretaries, Deputy Minister, Lasantha Alagiyawanna, Western Provincial Chief Minister, Isura Devapriya and Group of 16 members - MPs Dayasiri Jayasekera and Sumeda G Jayasena were also present.
 
Meanwhile, the SLFP Central Committee is scheduled to meet this Thursday night at the President’s official residence.

heading: Influenza death toll in South risen to 20
description:
The Southern Provincial Health Services Director, Dr. G. Wijesuriya says that the death toll caused by Influenza spreading in the Southern Province has risen to 20.
 
Of them, 14 were children and 6 were adults.
 
He further said over 350 patients are still receiving treatment at hospitals.
 
Meanwhile, Sri Lanka Medical Research Institute identified that the deadly flu is caused by Influenza-A virus.
 
Samples of phlegm collected from the patients have been sent for further tests in Hong Kong.
 
At the same time, the Director General of Health Services, Dr. Anil Jasinghe said that a committee of specialists has already been appointed to ascertain whether influenza affected patients need any injections.
 
Meanwhile, the GMOA Secretary, Dr. Haritha Aluthge charged that the Ministry has failed to take sufficient action to control flu-related deaths.
 
At the same time, MP Kanchana Wijesekera charged Health Minister, Dr. Rajitha Senarathna for his failure to take preventive action against the virus.
 
Meanwhile, Matara Pre School Development Association decided yesterday to keep all preschools closed until 10th of June due to the prevailing health concerns.

heading: President's fmr. Chief of Staff & fmr. STC chairman remanded
description:
President's former Chief of Staff I. K. Mahanama and State Timber Corporation former Chairman P. Dissanayake have been re-remanded till 19th of June.
 
They were arrested by Bribery Commission for accepting Rs.20 million from an Indian businessman.

heading: Traffic jam in Parliament roundabout due to ETI depositors' protest
description:
Heavy traffic congestion is reported in Parliamentary roundabout due to a protest by the depositors of ETI Finance.
 
Our correspondent said that the ETI depositors are engaging in the demonstration on the road.
 
Meanwhile, the Pelawatte - Battaramulla road towards Parliament is also blocked as a result of another protest.
 
It is carried out by the employees of the National Water Supply and Drainage Board.

heading: UNP MP's request government to reduce taxes
description:
The United National Party parliamentary group has requested the Finance Minister Mangala Samaraweera to reduce taxes which are imposed on several sectors.
 
UNP MP Chaminda Wijesiri told us that because of those taxes, certain businesses are struggling to survive.
 
The MP said because of that the UNP parliamentary group decided to make a request from the Finance Minister of taxes.
 
The request was made when the UNP MPs met at Temple Trees with PM Ranil Wickremesinghe at the chair.

heading: Sri Lanka Freedom Party new office-bearers appointed
description:
A host of temporary office bearers of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party were appointed today.
Accordingly, the new secretary to the party is Professor Rohana Lakshman Piyadasa.
The temporary appointments were made at the SLFP Central Committee meeting that was held at Ape Gama Premises under the patronage of President Maithripala Sirisena.
The Meeting commenced after the arrival of the party leader President Maithripala Sirisena.
The President officially accepted the proposal on the resignation of Office Bearers made by the former general secretary Duminda Dissanayake, following which temporary appointments were made.
Furthermore former Presidents Mahinda Rajapaksa and Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaranathunga as well as the former prime minister, D.M. Jayarathna has been appointed once again to the advisory board of the SLFP.
The new general secretary Professor Rohana Lakshman Piyadasa was voted in unanimously.
The former general secretary Duminda Dissanayake was appointed the National Organizer, a post which was previously held by former minister Susil Premajayantha.
Furthermore, four Senior Co-Chairmen namely Minister Nimal Siripala De Silva and former ministers W D J Senevirathne and Anura Priyadharshana Yapa were appointed as Co-Chairmen, including former Minister Susil Premajayantha.
Parliamentarian S B Dissanayake was appointed the party treasurer.
Apart from this 11 other Co-Chairmen were appointed at the meeting. 
A H M Fowzie , Sarath Amunugama , Mahinda Amaraweera, Piyasena Gamage, Vijith Vijayamuni Soysa, Mahinda Samarasinghe, Dayasiri Jaysekara, Dilan Perera, Angajan Ramanadan, Reginald Cooray and Shan Wijelal were the 11 appointed Co-Chairmen.
Ranjith Siyambalapitiya, Lasantha Alagiyawanna, Dr. Sudharshani Fernadopulle, Sumedha G Jayasena, Sarath Ekanayake, Dharmasiri Dasanayake, Isura Devapriya and Chamara Sampath were appointed as Deputy Secretaries to the party.

heading: University students arm detached in accident in Ratnapura
description:
The right arm of a university student has severed in an accident involving a tipper and a Sri Lanka Transport Board bus in Sannasgala, Pelmadulla in Ratnapura.
The student was onboard the SLTB bus plying from Colombo to Bibile when the accident had occurred.
It is reported that other passengers had admitted the student to Ratnapura hospital, along with the detached arm.
Police stated that measures were taken to transfer the student to Colombo National Hospital, thereafter.
A spokesperson at the Colombo National Hospital told our news team that a surgery was conducted to re-attach the severed arm.

heading: Startling revelation by Wasantha Samarasinghe
description:
The Voice against Corruption charges that 106 pages of the bond commission report that contained highly sensitive information, have gone missing recently.
 
Its' Convener Wasantha Samarasinghe made this statement addressing a media briefing held in Colombo today (Jun 03).
Meanwhile, as of now, two MPs have openly acknowledged that they received funds from the owner of Perpetual Treasuries, Arjun Aloysius.
31 MPs had denied that they received money from Arjuna Aloysius
 
Another 6 MPs and Ministers today denied receiving funds.
However, another 186 have not yet made any statements whether they received money from the owner of Perpetual Treasuries or not.

heading: Higher Education Minister speaks of a cultural disaster
description:
Minister of Higher Education and Cultural Affairs Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe says that the establishment of universities for Visual and Performing Arts has triggered a cultural chaos.
He expressed these views addressing an event in Kundasale, Kandy yesterday (Jun 02) to declare open the National Arts Centre.

heading: Chairman of Thalawakele - Lindula Urban Council arrested for abducting a small girl
description:
Chairman of Thalawakele - Lindula Urban Council & 3 others arrested for kidnapping and selling of a 5-year-old girl.
 
The suspects, council's chairman Anagipura Asoka Sepala and councillor Ishara Anuruddha Manchanayake were arrested along with 2 others yesterday (Jun 03).
 
They are accused of abducting the child in 2017 from the Portmore Estate, Agarapathana and then selling her.

heading: IGP gets award from President
description:
Inspector General of Police, Pujith Jayasundara says that one should not criticize others in order to conceal one’s own faults.
He made this statement at a ceremony held in Colombo today (Jun 03) under the patronage of President Maithripala Sirisena.
The President awarded a special token in recognition of the service rendered by the IGP towards the Buddha Sasana at this occasion.

heading: “Group of 16” talks about removal of SLFP Gen. Sec.
description:
The 16-member group that left the government in April says removal of Minister Duminda Dissanayake from the post of General Secretary of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party was a victory achieved by them.
 
At the SLFP CC and All-Island Committee Meeting, it was decided to replace Duminda with Prof. Rohana Lakhsman Piyadasa as the General Secretary of the SLFP.
 
Minister Dissanayake was appointed as the National Organizer.
 
MP Perera said their next aim is to ensure SLFP is completely withdrawn from the government.
 
He said until then, they will work with former President Mahinda Rajapaksa while being in the opposition.

heading: Southern province still affected by viral fever
New Exchange Control Bill could affect economy says Wimal
description:
The leader of National Freedom Front, Wimal Weerawanse says that the government has introduced a new Exchange Control Bill, which would harm the country's economy.
 
He said this addressing an event in Chilaw yesterday.
 
MP Sanath Nishantha joining the occasion talked about his time at the prison.
 
He said that the government is using laws in an illegitimate manner against those who highlight government's shortcomings.
 
MP Nishantha says the government has branded MP Dayasiri Jayasekera as a robber after he left the government.

heading: Postal workers launch 48-hour token strike
description:
The Postal and Telecommunication Officers' Union launched a 48-hour strike from last midnight over several demands including the confirmation of the new appointments of postmasters.
 
The union's General Secretary H. K. Kariyawasam said that they would continue the strike for two days.
 
Convening a media briefing in Kandy yesterday (Jun 03), Posts, Postal Services and Muslim Affairs Minister A. H. M. Haleem said that action was being taken to provide solutions to their demands.
 
Meanwhile, water supply to several areas has affected as a result of a strike launched by the employees of National Water Supply and Drainage Board.
 
They demand a salary hike of 25%.
 
The NWSDB employees say they have stopped attending to weekend work as a trade union action.

heading: Woman murdered in Ruwanwella (Photos)
description:
A 36-year-old woman has been hacked to death in Ruwanwella this morning (Jun 04).
 
The incident had happened at an estate dwelling in Kannantota, at Parawatte in Ruwanwella.
 
Police arrested the alleged paramour of the victim for committing the murder.

heading: Surgery on detached arm of undergraduate unsuccessful
description:
The surgery to re-attach the hand of the university student which was ripped-off in an accident in Pelmadulla was unsuccessful.
 
The surgery was performed at the National Hospital, Colombo.
 
The right arm of the undergraduate was severed in an accident involving a Sri Lanka Transport Board bus and a tipper.
 
The Deputy Director of the hospital, Dr. Samindi Samarakoon said that the surgery was unsuccessful due to the severity of the injuries.
 
It has been reported that the student had been resting his right arm on the window-ledge of the bus.
 
The severed arm was sent to the Ratnapura Hospital in a bag of ice, along with the injured student.
 
The student was first admitted to Ratnapura Hospital and later transferred to the National Hospital, Colombo for the surgery.
 
The victim, 23-year-old undergraduate of Sabaragamuwa University is Isuru Sandaruwan, a resident of Agalawatte.

heading: Eastern Governor's wife & daughter released on bail
description:
The wife and daughter of Eastern Province Governor Rohitha Bogollagama have surrendered to Colombo Magistrate's Courts over an attempted assault case.
Later they were granted bail.

heading: Letter distribution affected by strike
description:
The 48-hour token strike launched by the postmasters has affected the distribution of letters and parcels.
 
They began the strike last midnight (Jun 03), based on several demands including that they be made permanent.
 
A spokesperson from the union said the strike action has affected 653 post offices and 42 satellite offices.
 
The union's General Secretary H. K. Kariyawasam said that they would continue the strike for two days.
 
Convening a media briefing in Kandy yesterday (Jun 03), Posts, Postal Services and Muslim Affairs Minister A. H. M. Haleem said that action was being taken to provide solutions to their demands.
 
Meanwhile, water supply to several areas has affected as a result of a strike launched by the employees of National Water Supply and Drainage Board.
 
They demand a salary hike of 25%.
 
The NWSDB employees say they have stopped attending to weekend work as a trade union action.

heading: AG informs his decision on Ranjan's statement to courts
description:
Attorney General has informed the Supreme Court that at a glance there is a prima facie case of contempt in Deputy Minister Ranjan Ramanayake's statement.
This was informed when the case was taken before Supreme Court judges Eva Wanasundara and L. T. B. Dehideniya.
Earlier, the Supreme Court informed the Attorney General to express his opinion on the controversial statement made by the Deputy Minister.
Ranjan Ramanayake had said on several occasions that most of the judges and lawyers in Sri Lanka are corrupt.
He made a statement on 21st of August, 2017.
Thereafter, Ven. Magalkande Sudatta Thera and several others went to the Supreme Court against the Deputy Minister's statement and the case was first taken up on 14th of December.
The Additional Solicitor General Priyantha Naavana who appeared for the Attorney General informed the Supreme Court today that the statement made by the Deputy Minister, at a glance is in contempt of court.
The case will be called again on 18th of June.

heading: "Crisis in 2 main parties affect us", says TNA
description:
Tamil National Alliance says as a result of the ongoing crisis in the 2 main political parties, it is not whether a solution would be found for the issues of the Tamil people.
 
The General Secretary of the TNA, Mavai Senathiraja said this expressing his views regarding the statement made by President on the 100-day programme.

heading: New Gen. Sec. promises to revive SLFP
description:
The newly appointed General Secretary of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party, Prof. Rohana Lakshman Piyadasa says that he will start finding solutions to the present crisis of the SLFP within a short period of time.
 
The newly appointed General Secretary said this after assuming duties at the SLFP headquarters in Darley Road, Colombo this morning (Jun 04).
 
He further said that the party should follow a programme that has the potential to unite all factions under the leadership of the President.
 
Meanwhile, former SLFP General Secretary, Duminda Dissanayake, who was appointed as the National Organizer of the party also assumed duties this morning.
 
Addressing the gathering at the party headquarters, he said that personal agendas should be put aside, and they should march forward under a new vision.
 
A group of temporary office bearers was appointed at the SLFP CC & All Island Committee meetings held at Ape Gama, yesterday.
 
These appointments are to be in place until a full restructure is carried out within 45 days.
 
Meanwhile, an SLFP CC meeting is scheduled for this Thursday to discuss proposals submitted to ratify those appointments.

heading: Presidential Commission probing frauds at national career begins work
description:
The Presidential Commission, which was appointed to look into alleged malpractices at SriLankan Airlines, SriLankan Catering, and Mihin Lanka has commenced witness hearings.
 
Accordingly, the Commission will record statements from the Director General of Department of Registrar of Companies and another official.
 
The alleged malpractices of the 3 entities from 1st of January 2006 to 1st of January 2018 will be probed by this commission, which was appointed on 2nd of February.
Former Supreme Court judge, Anil Gooneratne, former Appeal Court judge, Rohan Amarasekera, former High Court judge, Piyasena Ranasinghe, former Deputy Auditor General Anthony Harold and the Director General of the Auditing Standard and Research Board of Sri Lanka, Wasantha Jayaseeli Kapugama function as members of the Commission.

heading: A request to new Gen. Sec. of SLFP
description:
UPFA MP, Joint Opposition's Rohitha Abeygunawardena asks the newly elected General Secretary of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party, Prof. Rohana Lakhsman Piyadasa to visit the villages and see the destiny of the SLFP in his own eyes.
 
He said this addressing a media conference held at the office of Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna in Battaramulla today (Jun 04).
 
Meanwhile, the General Secretary of the Pivithuru Hela Urumaya, MP Udaya Gammanpila says he will hand over an affidavit to Speaker Karu Jayasuriya tomorrow saying that he did not obtain money from the owner of the Perpetual Treasuries, Arjun Aloysius.
 
He said this addressing the media in Colombo today.

heading: Speaker says full Bond report will be tabled
description:
Speaker informs Parliament that since only a portion of the Bond Commission report has been received, he will table the full after other sections are also presented to him. 
Earlier in the day, it was reported that the Sections C- 350 to C-360 of the report, which was not released so far, were handed over to the Speaker by President's Secretary. 
The Presidential Secretariat was asked to hand over the remaining sections of the Bond report by the Speaker.

heading: PM instructs ministers to initiate development projects
Secret ballot likely to elect Deputy Speaker
description:
Deputy Secretary-General of Parliament Neil Iddawala says that when Parliament convenes on the 5th of this month, a new Deputy Speaker will be elected. 
He said that in case the Government and Opposition both suggest names for the vacant post, a secret ballot may have to be held. 
It is reported that the UNP intends in proposing the name of its Moneragala District Parliamentarian Ananda Kumarasiri. 
UNP MP Nalin Bandara said that they have the required number of votes to ensure their nominee would be elected.
 
However, Joint Opposition Parliamentarian Udaya Gammanpila said that they too hope to put forward a candidate.
 
Although the SLFP had previously put forward MP Angajan Ramanathan, the Party’s General Secretary, Minister Duminda Dissanayaka said that a final decision is yet to be taken.

heading: Postal employees to go on a strike
description:
The Postal and Telecommunication Officers' Union says that they would launch a 2-day token strike from tomorrow midnight (Jun 03) over several demands including issues in the recruitment process.
The General Secretary of the Union, H. K. Kariyawasam said that all postal officers would support this action.
However, the Post Master General Rohana Abeyratne said that all steps have been taken to face the strike.

heading: Decline in Southern viral flu cases
description:
Director General of Health Services, Dr. Anil Jasinghe says there is a decline in cases of viral flu in the Southern Province.
 
Addressing a media conference in Colombo, he said there's a decline in admissions to Karapitiya, Matara and Kamburupitiya hospitals.

heading: Chinese-run brothel raided in Colpetty
description:
Colpetty police after obtaining a search warrant have raided a brothel in Colpetty, which was operated by a Chinese national.
 
The operators and 3 other Chinese women were arrested during the raid.
 
The arrested women were aged between 38 and 45.
 
It was found that the women even did not have the visa to stay in Sri Lanka.

heading: Govt.'s Presidential Candidate will be known by November, Minister Rajapakshe says
description:
Minister of Higher Education and Cultural Affairs Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe says that the government’s Presidential Candidate will be announced by November.
 
He said this while speaking to media after calling on the Chief Prelates of the Malwathu and Asgiri chapters.
 
The Minister while expressing views on the 20th amendment said that it would destabilize the country.

heading: 60,000 new Tax files opened
Heavy showers and strong winds predicted
description:
Met Department says showers or thundershowers will occur at times in Western, Southern, Sabaragamuwa, Central and North-Western provinces and fairly heavy falls above 75 mm can be expected at some places.
 
Showers or thundershowers may occur at few places in Uva province and in Batticaloa and Ampara districts after 2 pm.
 
Light showers may occur at few places in Anuradhapura district.
 
Fairly strong gusty winds up to 50kmph can be expected over Uva and Southern provinces.

heading: 20th amendment sent to AG
description:
The 20th amendment Draft Bill handed over to the General Secretary of Parliament by the Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna has been forwarded to the Attorney General.
Upon evaluation by the Attorney General, it would be gazetted and taken up for debate in Parliament.
A two-thirds majority is required to ensure passage of the bill.

heading: SriLankan flight time changes tomorrow
description:
SriLankan Airlines says that the departure and arrival timings of several flights at Bandaranaike International Airport(BIA) tomorrow (Jun 03) have been changed due to the launch of an experimental flight over the Indian Ocean by a country in the region on this day.
SriLankan Airlines said any inconvenience caused to the passengers is beyond their control.

heading: Roger resigns from Wimal's party
IMF approves 4th installment of EFF
description:
Executive Board of the International Monetary Fund has completed the fourth review of Sri Lanka’s economic performance under the program supported by a three-year Extended Arrangement under the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) arrangement.
The IMF said that the completion of this review enables the disbursement of about US $ 252 million, bringing total disbursements under the arrangement to the equivalent of about US$ 1,014 million.
Sri Lanka’s three-year extended arrangement was approved on June 3, 2016, in the amount of about US $1.5 billion.

heading: SLFP Central Committee meeting where positions change, tomorrow
Abducted 8-month-old infant found
description:
The 8-month-infant who was abducted from a residence in 1st Cross Street of Good Shed Road, Vavuniya, has been found from Puthukuduirippu area.
The police said that the infant was found during a search operation carried out.
Two women who have been looking after the infant have also been arrested.
The infant is to be handed over to the mother after investigations are concluded.
The infant was abducted on Thursday by three individuals who had arrived in a van while the infant’s mother and the grandmother had been asleep.
The father of the infant, who is a former member of the LTTE, has told police that he carried out the abduction.
The father of the infant has told police over the phone this morning that he abducted the child as his wife had refused to show the infant during a video call.
According to the mother, the father who is suspected to have carried out the abduction is said to be residing in England with another partner.

heading: ETI depositors stage another protest
description:
A group of depositors of the ETI Finance staged a protest at the firm's head office today (Jun 02) demanding their money.
ETI is a subsidiary of EAP Group.
The depositors charged that the ETI management is not taking steps to return their deposits.
They have already staged protests a number of times at the ETI office.
At every time, the depositors charge, that the management promises to repay the money, however, the promises are yet to be fulfilled.
Even today, they had failed to give a clear timeline to repay the money.

heading: Who got money from Arjun Aloysius ?
description:
So far 31 parliamentarians have said that they did not obtain money from Arjun Aloysius.
It means 192 MPs are yet to reveal whether they had got money or not.
MP Dayasiri Jayasekeral recently said that bond commission report has mentioned names of 118 persons who had obtained money from Aloysius.
116 more names are yet to be revealed.

heading: Mangala appointed UNP Deputy Chairman
description:
The Minister of Media and Finance, Mangala Samaraweera has been appointed the Deputy Chairman of the United National Party.
 
The appointment is effective from 26th of April.

heading: Two women murdered in Kosgama
description:
Police say 2 women have been hacked to death at Warallamandiya in Kosgama in Avissawella this morning (Jun 02).
The deceased were 34-year-old, mother of one child and her grandmother, who was a 78-year-old.
The young mother's child was just one-month-old.
Police said the murders have been committed over money.
It is suspected that a relative of the victims had committed the murders and he has fled the area.
The suspect was a money lender.

heading: Hema Nalin is no more
description:
Veteran journalist and television host Hema Nalin Karunaratne has passed away.
He had suffered a heart attack while being at home.
Hema Nalin was 56 years old.

heading: probe on murder of Dananjaya’s father handed over to CID
description:
The investigations into the murder of Ranjan de Silva, father of cricketer Dananjaya de Silva, have been handed over to the Criminal Investigations Department.
Police Media Spokesperson said that several other police teams have also been appointed to assist the investigations.
The Police Special Task Force arrested 3 suspects in connection to the incident in Angulana recently.

heading: Bad smell emanating from water being distributed from Biyagama
description:
The consumers say that a bad smell in emanating from the water being distributed from the Biyagama Water Purification Plant over the last few days.
 
Because of this, the consumers in Kelaniya, Wattala, Ragama, and Biyagama are inconvenienced.
 
Hiru News contacted General Manager of National Water Supply and Drainage Board's production division, S. Sumanaweera said as a result of the recent floods, the water from paddy fields has entered the Purification Plant.
 
He said that no odour is coming out from the water that is being distributed now.
 
Meanwhile, demanding a 25% salary hike, NWSDB employees have stopped attending to work during weekends.

heading: Decisive SLFP Central Committee meeting today
prevailing showery condition to prevail
description:
The Met Department says that the prevailing showery condition in the South-western part of the island and cloudy condition can be expected to continue further.
Showers or thundershowers will occur at times in Western, Southern, Sabaragamuwa, Central and North-Western provinces.
Heavy falls about 100 mm can be expected at some places, particularly in Sabaragamuwa province.
Showers or thundershower may occur at a few places in Ampara and Badulla districts after 2 pm.
Light showers may occur at few places in Anuradhapura district.
Fairly strong gusty winds up to 50kmph can be expected over Southern province and Monaragala, Matale and Polonnaruwa districts.

heading: Secret vote underway to select Deputy Speaker
description:
A secret vote is now underway in Parliament to select the Deputy Speaker.
 
UNP MP Ananda Kumarasiri and MP Dr. Sudharshini Fernandopulle were proposed for the post.

heading: Trains on mainline delayed
Water Board employees launch token strike
description:
The employees of the National Water Supply and Drainage Board have launched a 4-hour work stoppage until 1 pm.
 
They are demanding a 25% salary hike as well as several other issues to be addressed.
 
The employees say they will also stop attending to maintenance activities during the weekend.

heading: Spread of viral fever continues, more infants falling sick
description:
Health officials have decided to extend the pediatric emergency services at Karapitiya Teaching Hospital (KTH) as a measure to contain the spread of the viral fever in the Southern Province.
 
48 infants believed to have contracted the disease are being treated at the children's wards of the KTH.
 
In the month of May, 14 children have died of the disease.
 
Director of the KTH, Dr. Jayampathi Senarathna said that however, the number of patients being admitted to his hospital is gradually decreasing.
 
Matara District Health Services Director, Dr. A. D. U. Karunaratna said that there is still a significant a risk of the spread of the disease amongst small children.
 
The Matara HSD said further that although there was a decrease in the number of adult patients, there was no decrease in small children.

heading: Train services on mainline resumes
description:
The Railway Main Control Room says that services on the main line which was stalled after an unidentified body was detected on the rail track in Ambepussa have resumed.
 
Police suspect that the body would have been on the track since last night.
 
It was found this morning and then the authorities suspended the train services temporarily until it was removed.
 
Later, the deceased was identified as a 34-year-old, resident of Wallawa, Kurunegala.
 
The body was taken to Wathupitiwala Hospital for the postmortem.

heading: Court orders arrest of wife & daughter of Rohitha Bogollagama
description:
The Colombo Chief Magistrate Court has ordered to arrest the wife and daughter of the Eastern Governor Rohitha Bogollagama.
The arrest order was issued after they failed to appear before the court relating to a case filed by a woman in Kurunduwatte against them.
The woman had made this complaint alleging that the wife and daughter of the Eastern Governor attempted to assault her and tried to rob Rs. 25,000 from her.
They were issued with the notice to appear before the court today (June 01) and the Magistrate issued the arrest order after they failed to appear before the court.

heading: A message for users of Southern Expressway
description: The Road Development Authority says that the left lanes between Kokmaduwa and Godagama interchanges of the Southern Expressway will be closed from today (Jun 01) for construction and maintenance.

heading: Golden Peacock medal returned to Sumithra Peries
description:
Police have returned the Golden Peacock honorary medal won by late Dr. Lester James Peiris to his wife Sumithra Peris.
 
The medal was stolen by a group of robbers from the home of the late film maestro while the funeral activities being taken place.

heading: Two suspects arrested over murder of Dhananjaya's father
Johann Peries given a rousing welcome at BIA
description:
Johann Peries who became the second Sri Lankan to reach the Everest summit returned to the island this morning (Jun 01).
 
He was given a rousing welcome at the Bandaranaike International Airport.
 
Peries first attempted to reach the summit in April 2016 along with Jayanthi Kuru-Utumpala, but he was forced to suspend the hike due to lack of oxygen.
 
Then he was just 448 meters to the summit.
 
However, last month he was able to fulfill his dream.

heading: President assures to develop all sectors
description:
President Maithripala Sirisena says facilities will be given to developing all the sectors in the country.
 
He said this joining the Government's Registered and Assistant Medical Practitioners’ Annual General Meeting in Colombo yesterday (May 31).

heading: Sri Lanka – China FTA discussions stalled
description:
Talks between China and Sri Lanka for a free trade agreement have hit major hurdles, according to a report filed by Reuters.
 
Quoting Sri Lanka’s top negotiator it said the talks are limping mainly because Beijing will not agree to Colombo’s demand for a review of the deal after 10 years.
 
China’s exports to Sri Lanka dwarf the trade that goes in the other direction, leaving Colombo with a big deficit with Beijing.
 
Sri Lanka’s chief trade negotiator K. J. Weerasinghe has said that Colombo was insisting on a right to review the free trade pact after 10 years, but China was not ready to agree that.
 
Ministerial-level discussions about an agreement have not been held since March last year.
 
Lower-level discussions between officials have made little progress, according to Weerasinghe.
 
“The talks have come to a standstill. China wants to remove the review clause,” Weerasinghe told Reuters. Beijing was opposed to such an option because it wanted longer-term stability, he said.
 
The review clause that Sri Lanka wants would allow it to change some of the deal terms if they were hurting the island nation’s businesses.
 
China’s commerce ministry did not respond to Reuters requests for comment.
 
Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying told reporters in Beijing that China attached a great deal of importance to its relationship with Sri Lanka, and that they are willing to continue with cooperation in all areas including trade and business.
 
“We are also willing to play a constructive role in Sri Lanka’s sustainable development and economic diversification,” Hua said.
 
Weerasinghe said another point of contention was that China wanted zero tariffs on 90 percent of goods the two countries sold to each other as soon as an agreement is signed while Colombo would rather it started with zero tariffs on only half of the products concerned and expanded gradually over 20 years.
 
Sri Lanka imported $ 4.2 billion worth of Chinese goods in 2016, mostly raw materials for garments, machines and electronics, metals, transport equipment and chemicals.
 
Its exports to the world’s second-largest economy were just $211 million the same year, which included textiles, tea, and vegetables, footwear and rubber.

heading: Speaker writes to President’s Secretary seeking names of MPs obtained money from Aloysius
description:
Speaker Karu Jayasuriya has written to President’s Secretary seeking the list of the 118 parliamentarians who had reportedly received money from Perpetual Treasuries Limited or its subsidiary companies that belonged to Arjun Aloysius.
 
Sources from the Speaker’s Office stated that this written request was sent yesterday (May 31).
 
Meanwhile, MP Dayasiri Jayasekera admitted that he had received a cheque for one million rupees from Aloysius.
 
He further said the money was offered to his election campaign and that he has no direct involvement in that transaction.
 
In addition, Minister, Sarath Fonseka also publicly admitted that Aloysius had offered him Rs. 100,000.
 
As a consequence, political parties are now pointing fingers at one another and are expressing various views regarding the list of MPs.
 
Now the public is also demanding that the so-called list of 118 MPs should be exposed.
 
Meanwhile, it was reported yesterday that there is a roadblock preventing the names being exposed.
 
It is reported that the confidential documents including the C-350 document which carries the 118 MPs names have been sent to the National Archives with an embargo for 30 years.
 
The speaker, however, has the ability to access the names as allegations levelled against the entire Parliament of being accepting money.
 
Under that vested power, the Speaker has written to the President’s Secretary requesting that he be provided with the list.

heading: President’s Secretary seeks AG’s advice to publicize bond scam report
description:
The Secretary to the President says that he has asked Attorney General's advice on publicizing the full report of the Presidential Commission of Inquiry that probed the Central Bank bond scam.
In a media statement, Austin Fernando said if the AG and the Director General of the Bribery Commission agree, he is planning to release the full report.

heading: Rains expected to enhance
description:
Met Department says that the showery condition in the South-Western part of the island is expected to slightly enhance from today (Jun 01).
 
Showers will occur at times in Western, Southern, Sabaragamuwa, Central and North-Western provinces.
 
Showers or thundershowers may occur at few places in the Uva province and in the Batticaloa and Ampara districts in the afternoon.
 
Fairly heavy falls about 50 mm can be expected at some places in Western, Sabaragamuwa and Central provinces.

heading: Baddegama prison escapees in Colombo ?
description:
It is reported that the 5 suspects who had escaped from prison officials at the Baddegama Magistrate Court are roaming in Colombo.
 
Several teams from the Special Task Force are conducting probes to arrest them.
 
A special team, headed by Matara Assistant Prison's Superintendent is also investigating the incident.
 
That report will be handed over to the Department of Prison's next Monday (June 04).
 
Last Monday (May 28), 6 inmates escaped from the prison guards after they were taken to the Baddegama Magistrate Court.
 
Next day one of the inmates was apprehended while he was hiding at his girlfriend's home in Ellekanda, Baddegama.

heading: Water Board employees on strike
description:
The employees of National Water Supply and Drainage Board have struck work and they will continue their agitation campaign until 1 pm today (May 31).
 
The convener of the trade union, they have decided to take a trade union action since authorities are responding to a demand for 25% salary hike.

heading: Minister Fonseka accepts he received money from Aloysius
description:
Minister Field Marshall Sarath Fonseka accepts that he had also received monetary donations from Perpetual Treasuries owner Arjun Aloysius, for his election campaign.
 
The owner of Perpetual Treasuries is in remand custody for his alleged connections to the Central Bank bond scam.
 
The Minister revealed this yesterday, after paying a courtesy call on Malwatta Chapter Chief Incumbent.

heading: Casual, temporary and contract technical workers of Railways urged to report to work
description:
All casual, temporary and contract Railway Technical workers are called for work by 12 noon today (May 31).
 
The Assistant General Manager of Sri Lanka Railways said otherwise they will be treated as vacated their posts.

heading: Showers to return from tomorrow
description:
Met Department says that a slight change in prevailing weather is expected from tomorrow (Jun 01).
 
Therefore, showery condition over the island will be slightly enhanced from tomorrow.
 
Fairly strong winds over the island and sea areas around the island can be expected until today.
 
Several spells of showers will occur in Western, Sabaragamuwa, Central and North-Western provinces and in Galle and Matara districts.
 
Strong gusty winds up to 50-60 kmph can be expected over Kandy, Matale, Badulla, Nuwara-Eliya, Ratnapura, Kegalle, Galle and Matara districts and fairly strong gusty winds up to 50kmph in Western, North-Western and North-central provinces.

heading: Step mother sentenced for child torture
description:
A 51-year-old woman was sentenced by the Negombo Magistrate Court for inflicting burn injuries on a 7-year-old child.
 
The woman was convicted after she had accepted of committing the crime.
 
The Negombo court sentenced her for 2 years and stayed the order for 5 years.
 
It was revealed that the mother of the child was abroad and his father was an airman.
 
The stepmother had come to their home in Katunayake to look after the child, but later she had begun a clandestine affair with the boy's father.
 
The woman was fined Rs. 7500 and she was also ordered to pay Rs. 50,000 to the victim.

heading: Joint Opposition opposes 20th A
description:
The leaders of the political parties affiliated to the Joint Opposition have decided to oppose the 20th amendment to the constitution.
 
The amendment was moved by the Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna and it seeks to abolish the Executive Presidency.
 
The Joint Opposition took this decision during a discussion chaired by former President Mahinda Rajapaksa, held at his Colombo resident, yesterday (May 30).

heading: An infant abducted in Vavuniya
description:
A group of persons has abducted an eight-month-old infant from a house in Goodshed Road in Vavuniya.
 
The incident took place early this morning (May 31).
 
It was revealed that the parents of this child have separated and police suspect that the father of the child may have engineered the abduction.

heading: Woman dies in accident (Contains highly sensitive photos)
description:
Police say that a woman was killed on the spot following an accident in Armour Street in Colombo this morning (May 31).
 
She was knocked down by a Kadawatha - Colombo private bus.
 
Later, police arrested the driver and conductor of the bus.
 
Kotahena Police probes the incident.

heading: Railway strike to be ended at 4 pm
description:
The Railway Technical Services’ Union has decided to end the strike action at 4 pm today.
 
The decision was taken during an Executive Committee meeting, held this morning.

heading: President blames IGP over underworld
description:
President Maithripala Sirisena says that that the Ministry of Law and Order and the Police Department should be held responsible for the failure to arrest underworld criminals.
 
The President said he had recently warned about this to the IGP.
 
The President said this addressing the inaugural ceremony of the Welisara Court Complex this morning (May 31).

heading: MP Sanath Nishantha given bail
description:
MP Sanath Nishantha Perera who was in remand custody for allegedly assaulting Arachchikattuwa Divisional Secretary has been granted bail by Chilaw High Court this morning.
 
The co-accused, his brother was re-remanded till 7th of June.
The two brother are accused of assaulting the Divisional Secretary of Arachchikattuwa in 2008.
They were arrested on 19th of March this year for breaching bail conditions.

heading: Group of 16 opposes 20th A
description:
The Sri Lanka Freedom Party's Group of 16, who resigned from the government says they are opposing the 20th amendment, moved by the Janatha Viumkthi Peramuna.
 
Former State Minister Lakshman Yapa Abeywardena addressing a media conference in Colombo today (May 31), said it seems like that the 20th amendment is a contract given to the JVP by someone else.

heading: Cabinet ratifies training for unemployed graduates
description:
The Cabinet has ratified a proposal to recruit the unemployed graduates who had presented themselves for interviews for training.
 
They will be trained in several phases.
 
Accordingly, 5,000 unemployed graduates will be trained in July and 15,000 more will be trained in September.
 
The Cabinet has approved a payment of Rs. 20,000 during the training period.
 
The interviews were held recently for unemployed graduates below aged 45 years.

heading: Application for Grade 1 admissions released
description: Education Ministry says circular and application for the admission of children to Grade 1 of the government schools in 2019 have been released.

heading: Daily clinics halted at Debarawewa Hospital
description:
The daily clinics being conducted at Debarawewa Hospital have been suspended due to the lack of medical practitioners.
 
Although the hospital requires 52 doctors to run the daily clinics, it has only 31 doctors.
 
The Hospital Director said although the authorities have been informed of this, the issue remains.

heading: Rs. 65 million worth gold detected at BIA
description:
The Customs officials at the Bandaranaike International Airport apprehended a Polish national this morning (May 31) while he was trying to smuggle in 100 gold biscuits.
 
The estimated value of the find was Rs. 65 million.
 
The suspect had arrived from Dubai and he had hidden the gold biscuits in his waist belt.

heading: An unidentified person hacked to death in Angunakorapelessa
description:
Police have found a body of an unidentified person with cut injuries from a paddy field in Adapaanawatte in Angunakorapelessa this morning (May 31).
 
The Magisterial inquiry will be conducted this afternoon.

heading: Woman sent to Homagama mortuary returns to life
description:
In a bizarre incident at the Homagama Hospital, a 40-year-old woman returned to life while she was being taken to hospital mortuary.
 
In this incident, a woman was recently admitted to Homagama Hospital with stomach pains and she had fainted after a nurse administered an injection to her.
 
Later, the doctor who had checked the woman ruled that she was no more.
 
However, an hour later, while the body was being taken to the hospital mortuary, the relatives have noticed a shake in the woman's leg.
 
Then the relatives having taken care of her had taken the woman to a private hospital, where she is recovering now.
 
Hiru News attempted to contact Homagama Hospital to get more information about this incident, but nobody answered the phone calls.

heading: 4 arrested for abducting a teenage girl
description:
Police have arrested four persons for allegedly abducting a 14-year-old girl in Saadamulla, Batapola.
 
The abduction took place at around 3 am yesterday (May 29).
 
Police said that a group of 5 persons had forced open the door, before taking away the girl.
 
Police were able to find the girl last afternoon and now investigations are underway to arrest the 5th suspect.

heading: Semi-luxury bus service abolished
description:
National Transport Commission says that the semi-luxury bus service will be abolished after 31st of December.
 
The NTC said that decision was taken considering the complaints received from the public.

heading: Young policeman dies in Veyangoda accident
description:
A 23-year-old policeman was killed in an accident in Veyangoda last evening (May 29).
It was reported that the motorcycle ridden by the police constable had collided with a push-cycle at around 7.10 pm on the Sapugastenna - Kalagedihena road.
After the accident, the motorcycle had veered off the road and toppled.
The motorcyclist died upon admitting to the Wathupitiwala Hospital.
The deceased was attached to Mannar Police Station.

heading: Several train engines damaged, internal inquiry launched
description:
Sri Lanka Railways has commenced an internal inquiry after 3 train engines at the Maradana Railway Yard found to be damaged.
 
The damages were identified last evening, an official from Sri Lanka Railways said.
 
Meanwhile, Sri Lanka Railways authorities say there will be train delays as a result of the ongoing strike action launched by several trade unions.
 
The unionists say they would continue their 48-hour token strike.
 
They commence a 48-hour token strike at 4 pm yesterday (May 29) over three demands, including a 12.1 percent salary increase be implemented.
 
Meanwhile, the Sri Lanka Railways announced that casual, temporary and contractual employees of the Railway Technical Service should report for work immediately
 
However, the trade unions that are engaged in the strike said that if the authorities take action to suppress the trade unions, they would take action to continue the token strike.
 
Railways General Manager, S. M. Abeywickrema also requested that the employees end the strike and report for work.
 
However, the President of the Railway Technical Services’ Trade Union Committee, Sampath Rajitha said that the strike would be in force till 4 pm tomorrow.

heading: Train strike disrupts daily services, CID to investigate sabotage
description:
The daily train schedules including office trains were disrupted this morning (May 30) as a consequence to the ongoing strike by several railway trade unions.
 
Railway General Manager, S. M. Abeywickrama has made a complaint to the Criminal Investigation Department to probe several acts of sabotage at Maradana and other places.
 
The Railway Technical Services’ Union Committee is staging a 48-hour token strike demanding a 12.1% salary increase.
 
The Main Control Room says that 350 services were delayed due to the strike.
 
Meanwhile, the Sri Lanka Railways announced that casual, temporary and contracted employees of the Railway Technical Service should report for work immediately
 
However, the trade unions that are engaged in the strike said that if the authorities take action to suppress the trade unions, they would take action to continue the token strike.
 
Railways General Manager, S. M. Abeywickrama also requested that the employees end the strike and report for work.

heading: Father of one killed after motorcycle falls into 'Yodha' canal
description:
Police said a 26-year-old father of one was killed when the motorcycle ridden by him veered off the road and fell into the Yodha canal in Hingurakgoda.
 
The incident had taken place last night (May 29) when he was returning home after visiting a house of a relative.

heading: Mahinda Deshapriya writes to President and PM on PC elections
description:
The Chairman of the Elections Commission Mahinda Deshapriya has written to President Maithripala Sirisena, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe and Speaker Karu Jayasuriya requesting them to take steps to conduct the Provincial Council elections as early as possible.
 
Deshapriya has also sent those letter to party leaders as well.
 
Already the tenures of Sabaragamuwa, North Central, and Eastern Provincial Councils have elapsed and the elections are yet to be held.
 
The tenure of North Western, Central, Northern and Southern PCs will end this year and the term of the Uva, and Western PCs will end next year.
 
A spokesperson from the Elections Commission said that the Provincial Council election system is being changed and it would force to postpone the PC elections further.

heading: Power disrupted in several areas of South
description:
The Ministry of power and Renewable Energy says electricity in several areas of South is disrupted due to damages to the supply line from fallen trees.
 
The Ministry said Hambantota, Tangalle, Hakmana, Beliatta, Walasmulla, and Sooriyawewa are affected.

heading: Speaker asked to remove tainted COPE members
description:
Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna says that the Speaker should take steps to remove the members of the COPE who have had obtained money and had phone links with Perpetual Treasuries Limited.
 
The Chairman of the SLPP, former Minister G. L. Peiris said this addressing a media conference in Colombo today (May 30).

heading: TID summons Northern Education Minister
description:
Northern Provincial Education Minister, Kandaih  Sarveshwaran has been summoned by the Terrorists Investigation Division.
 
Sarveshwaran has been called to give a statement with regard to his order to have government schools in the North to fly the provincial flag half-mast to commemorate the war-dead on 18
 of May.
 
The Provincial Minister said that he would not report to the TID on 5
 of June.
 
He said that he took that decision, as his name has been misspelled in the letter he received from the TID.

heading: Two tunnels to be constructed to address flooding in Colombo
description:
Two tunnels will be constructed in Mutwal and Torrington Place to address the floods in Colombo.
 
The relevant agreement was signed between Ministry of Megapolis and China Petroleum Company in Colombo today (May 30).
 
The full project cost is $ 321 million and $ 214 million of that is infused by the World Bank.

heading: Former Military Intelligence Director remanded
description:
Former Military Intelligence Director and Chief of Staff of the Army, Rtd. Major General Amal Karunasekara has been further remanded till 13th of June.
 
The military officer is in custody over his alleged links to the abduction and assault of journalist Keith Noyahr.

heading: Cabinet allows importation of drugs without tenders to contain viral flu
description:
The Cabinet approval has been granted to import medicine and other requirements to control the spread of viral flu without tender procedures.
 
The relevant Cabinet paper was submitted by President Maithripala Sirisena, when the Cabinet met at the Presidential Secretariat today (May 30).
 
So far around 12 children had died of the viral flu which is being spread in the South since last month.
 
It is reported around 4,00 patients, most of them are children, are being treated at hospitals.
 
The majority of cases are reported from Kamburupitiya, Walasmulla, and Tangalle.

heading: US House of Committee representatives meet Sampanthan
description:
A delegation from the US House of Committee on Armed Services met with the Opposition Leader R. Sampanthan in Colombo.
 
The US embassy in Colombo said the current situation in the North and East and progress on reconciliation in Sri Lanka were among the topics discussed.

heading: President says 'ready for an open debate' on what has happened
description:
President Maithripala Sirisena says he's ready for an open debate on what has been happening for the last 3 1/2 years.
The President said this addressing the 76th birth anniversary of late venerable Maduluwawe Sobitha Thera.
The President started his speech revealing that he was not invited to attend the event.
Addressing the gathering he said venerable Sobitha Thera who mooted the idea of 'Common Candidate', had never asked the 'Common Candidate' to rob the Central Bank of the country.

heading: US House Committee delegation meets President and PM
description:
A delegation from the US House Committee on Armed Services met President Maithripala Sirisena at the President’s Official Residence in Colombo, today (May 30).  
 
The delegation comprised of Chairman of the US House Committee on Armed Services, Mac Thornberry, Henry Cuellar, Vickie Hartzler and Carol Shea-Porter.
 
During this meeting, the President said that Sri Lanka is a country, which will work with the cooperative and friendly manner with the international community.
 
He recalled the assistance given by the US in training Sri Lankan forces.
 
President Sirisena said that the cooperation of the United States Security forces is important to control the ways that drugs smuggled into the country.
 
The Congress committee members who agreed to provide assistance to prevent drug trafficking in Sri Lanka mentioned that it is their country’s policy to give necessary assistance in order to build Sri Lanka as a strong and prosperous country.
 
The US delegation also met with Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe.
 
The meeting took place at Temple Trees this morning (May 30).

heading: Railway Technical Services' strike to continue ?
description:
Railway Technical Services' Trade Union say they are considering to continue their strike action as a result of the lethargic response from the authorities as well as from other trade unions.
 
They said that the striking trade unions will meet at 10 am today (May 31) to make a final call.
 
The train commuters have greatly inconvenienced as a result of this strike and most of the trains were delayed.
 
The Railway Technical Services' Trade Union Joint Committee launched a trade union action on Tuesday demanding a salary hike of 12.1%.

heading: Updated : Man hacks 4 family members and commits suicide
description:
A man has hacked his 6-months old child, his wife, his mother-in-law and father-in-law and committed suicide.
Police said that the infant died at the Kuliyapitiya Hospital.
The incident has happened in Ihala Kadigamuwa, Bingiriya at around 1.35 pm..
The sources said that the condition of others is critical.
The suspect's wife is aged 24 and her mother and father are aged between 42 and 62 years respectively.
The suspect's face was damaged beyond recognition and police believe that he might have used 'hakka patas' to commit suicide.

heading: UNP Working Committee meets
description:
The Working Committee of the United National Party is meeting today (May 31).
 
It will be held this morning under the patronage of Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe.
 
New members will be appointed to the UNP Working Committee during this meeting.

heading: Human Rights Commission accredited 'A' status
description:
Constitutional Council congratulates Sri Lanka Human Rights Commission that has been promoted to the "A" category in the latest ranking of Global Alliance of National Human Rights Institutions.
 
The Chairman of CC, Speaker Karu Jayasuriya said it showed that Sri Lankans are a disciplined nation.
 
Meanwhile, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs congratulating the HRCSL said the Government will continue to support the important and challenging mandate of the Commission in safeguarding, promoting and protecting the human rights of all citizens.

heading: Perpetual Treasuries head office combed by CID
description:
A Special police team from the Criminal Investigation Department carried out a search operation at the head office of Perpetual Treasuries Limited on Park Street, in Colombo 2 last night, as part of the ongoing investigation into the bond issue.
The inspection was carried out, after obtaining a search warrant from Fort Magistrate, Lanka Jayaratne.
During the investigation, which commenced at around 7 last evening, police officers analyzed documents and computer data.
On the 24th of May, the chairman of Perpetual Treasuries Limited, Geoffrey Joseph Aloysius was ordered, by the courts, to produce necessary documents for the investigation.
However, since necessary support was not extended, the CID decided to carry out the search.
The Owner of Perpetual Treasuries, Arjun Aloysius and the CEO of the company, Kasun Palisena who were both arrested on the 4th of February were remanded until the 7th of June.

heading: Water Board workers commence a protest
description:
The employees of the National Water Supply and Drainage Board are engaging in a 4-hour work stoppage demanding the authorities to address their issues.
 
The convener of the union, Upali Ratnayake said the discussion with the management failed and following that they decided to take a strike action.

heading: One of prisoners escaped from custody arrested
description:
Police have arrested one of the 6 prisoners who was escaped from the custody of prisons officials while they were produced before the Baddegama Magistrate.
Police said that a 21-year-old escapee was arrested this morning following an operation conducted by police and STF officials in the Ellakanda area in Baddegama.
 
The arrested detainee was in remand custody over a rape case.
 
Other 4 escapees are accused of theft.

heading: 19 injured in bus collision
description:
19 garment workers were injured when 2 buses collided at Madola on the Avissawella - Ratnapura main road last evening (May 28).
 
Later police arrested the drivers of the 2 buses.
 
Police said that most of the injured female garment workers were discharged and only 3 remain in hospital.

heading: Leave of railway workers cancelled
description:
The Ministry of Transport announces that leave of all the Railway workers has been cancelled ahead of a planned strike by Railway Technical Services’ Union.
 
The Deputy Minister of Transport, Ashok Abeysinghe confirmed the leave cancellation.
 
The Railway Technical Services’ Union says they will launch a strike from 4 pm today (May 29) as the authorities are not willing to address their professional issues.
 
The Union has demanded to solve their salary anomaly as well as other issues.
 
The Chairman of the Railway Technical Services’ Union’s Committee  Sampath Rajitha said that as a consequence of this trade union action, the train services could be affected.

heading: Dengue outbreak predicted
description:
The Association of Epidemiologists says that the breeding of mosquito larvae could rise at an increased rate due to the existing wet weather conditions in many parts of the country.
 
The Chairman of the Association, Najith Sumanasena said that an outbreak of dengue is possible unless preventive measures are taken immediately.

heading: Shots fired at a textile shop
description:
Two persons on a motorcycle have opened fire at a textile shop in Nupe in Matara.
 
The shooting took place early this morning (May 29).
 
It was reported that no one was in the shop at the time of the shooting.

heading: Airman escaped with service weapon arrested
description:
An Air Force soldier who escaped with his service weapon along with his service weapon has been arrested.
 
He escaped last morning (May 28) from Trincomalee Air Force camp.
 
However, he was arrested by police last afternoon in Periyamadu in Batticaloa.

heading: Manufacture of banned polythene continues
description:
The All Ceylon Polythene Manufacturing and Recycling Association says that their degradable products cannot fetch a reasonable price as banned polythene varieties are still sold in the open market.
 
The association's chairman, Anura Herath said that his association will withdraw their membership in the future, due to this situation.
 
The production of the Polythene with micro less than 20 was banned on the January 1st this year.
 
Meanwhile, the Chairman of the Central Environmental Authority Chandrasena Pallegama said that the staff is not enough to conduct raids.
 
He further said that a decision has been taken to conduct raids with the support of police and public health officers.

heading: Railway token strike launched
description:
The Railway Technical Services’ Union has launched a 40-hour token strike.
They said that the authorities are not willing to address their professional issues.
The Union has demanded to solve their salary anomaly as well as other issues.
The Chairman of the Railway Technical Services’ Union’s Committee Sampath Rajitha said that as a consequence of this trade union action, the train services could be affected.

heading: Train delays reported
description:
The Railway Main Control Room says there's a delay in train services.
It is caused by a 48-hour token strike launched by the Railway Technical Services’ Union.

heading: Schools in South open tomorrow after health scare
description:
The government schools in the Southern Province that were closed following the spread of viral flu will be re-opened tomorrow (May 30).
 
However, the Provincial Education Minister, Chandima Rasaputra told us that the pre-schools will be opened only on next Monday.
 
Meanwhile, Provincial Health Services Director, Dr. G. Wijesuriya stated that the closure of schools has not indicated any sign of controlling the spreading of the disease.
 
He said, therefore, he informed school authorities to re-open schools.
 
However, Provincial Education Minister Rasaputra said that such a notice has not been received from the Provincial health authorities as yet.
 
He said schools will be re-opened tomorrow and the health authorities should take the responsibility.
 
Meanwhile, Director of the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital, Dr. Jayampathi Senanayake told us that there are doubts that the cause of death of several children could be the result of allergic reactions to several viruses.
 
11 children below the age of 12 in the southern province have died of this flu so far.

heading: Message to Railway workers
description:
All casual, temporary and contract workers of the Railway Technical Service are asked to report to work immediately.
 
The General Manager of Sri Lanka Railways says otherwise they will be treated as vacated their posts.

heading: 12 Sri Lankans stranded in Somalia, coming home
description:
Ministry of Foreign Affairs in coordination with the Sri Lanka Embassy in Addis Ababa, and with the assistance of the International Organization for Migration has succeeded in working towards ensuring the safe return of twelve Sri Lankan migrant workers stranded in Somaliland as a result of a labour dispute.
 
Sri Lanka does not have a diplomatic and consular presence in Somaliland.
 
Therefore, the Ministry and the Sri Lanka Embassy in Addis Ababa had worked with the IOM Office in Hargeisa which interceded to negotiate with the employer concerned in Somaliland to resolve the labour dispute, secure the release of the Sri Lankans, and make arrangements for their safe return.
 
The twelve Sri Lankans are scheduled to return home shortly.

heading: Various views expressed on Rajan's media conference
description: Politicians expressed views today (May 29) on the views came out during a media conference hosted by Deputy Minister Ranjan Ramanayake yesterday.

heading: Canned fish stock unfit for consumption to be sent back
description:
137,000 kilos of canned fish in 74 containers which were declared as unfit for human consumption will be re-exported to the countries of origin.
 
Sri Lanka Customs confirmed it.

heading: Investigation on prison escapees transferred to Matara
description:
The Department of Prison has initiated an investigation into the escape of 6 prisoners from the Baddegama Magistrate Court premises.
 
The investigation will be conducted under the supervision of Assistant Prison Superintendent of Matara.
 
Prison Media Spokesperson, Thushara Upuldeniya said several teams have been deployed to round up the other escapees.
 
29 inmates of the Galle prison were transported to Baddegama to be produced before Baddegama Magistrate yesterday.
 
Later, two prison guards have taken a sick prisoner to the hospital while another one took an inmate to obtain fingerprints.
 
Then only three prison guards were left for the guard of 27 inmates in the court premises.
 
When the inmate who gave fingerprints was put back into the court cell, 5 of the inmates had escaped.
 
Meanwhile, two guards have been hospitalized after they got injured during a scuffle with the escapees.
 
However, one of the escapees was arrested by STF while he was hiding in a house at Ellakanda in Baddegama this morning (May 29).

heading: Diverse views expressed on Dayasiri's revelation
description: Diverse views are being expressed on the revelation by former Minister Dayasiri Jayasekera who accepted that he obtained money from Arjun Aloysius to be used for the election campaign.

heading: T. B. Ekanayake to appear before FCID
description:
Former State Minister of Lands T. B. Ekanayake has been summoned to the Financial Crime Investigation Division to record a statement.
 
He is accused of misusing a vehicle when he was the State Minister of Cultural Affairs.
 
Police said that although the former State Minister, was summoned on 24th this month, he had informed that he would not be able to appear on that day due to having parliamentary sessions.
 
The former State Minister was subsequently informed to appear before the FCID at 10 am today (May 28).

heading: Hero police officer's remains taken to Madampe police (Photos)
description:
The remains of the hero police officer who died while attempting rescue a family of three, who were marooned in the floods, were taken to Madampe Police last night (May 27).
The accident occurred on Friday and his body was recovered last morning.
The funeral of the hero police officer will take place in Malgamuwa, Giriulla today.

heading: T. B. Ekanayake arrives at FCID
description:
Former State Minister T. B. Ekanayake has arrived at the Financial Crime Investigation to give a statement.
He is accused of misusing a state vehicle.
Our correspondent said that the Sri Lanka Freedom Party's 16-member group who resigned from the government is also present at the FCID accompanying their colleague.

heading: Actress Deepani Silva arrested
description:
Actress Deepani Silva has been arrested by Bandaragama Police.
 
She was arrested after a small child injured when her vehicle collided with a three-wheeler.

heading: 34 suspects further remanded over Kandy incidents
description:
They will remain in remand custody until 11th of June.
 
They are accused of create tension and communal riots in Kandy in early March.
The 34 suspects including the leader of the Mahason Balakaya have remanded again when they were produced before the Theldeniya Magistrate today (May 28).

heading: IUSF meets Dinesh Gunawardena
description:
A group of representatives from the Inter University Students' Federation has met with the Parliamentary Group Leader of the Joint Opposition Dinesh Gunawardena.
 
The issue of enrolling SAITM students to Kotelawala Defence University was discussed at the meeting which was held this morning (May 28).

heading: Gotabhaya promises a free country for all
description:
Former Defence Secretary Gotabhaya Rajapaksa says a country in which all can live without fear and suspicion will be created under a Rajapaksa rule in future.
 
He said this addressing an event in Beruwela yesterday (May 27).

heading: Food poisoning sends students to hospital
description:
35 students from Piliyandala Sir John Kotelawala Vidyalaya were hospitalized following food poisoning.
 
They were admitted to Piliyandala Hospital.
 
It was revealed that the students had complained of discomfort after consumed food served when they were observing sil this morning (May 28).

heading: Jeewantha Kulatunga rejects match-fixing allegations
description:
Former cricketer Jeevantha Kulatunga has issued a media release rejecting match-fixing allegations.
 
He says he has never involved in match-fixing and added that the documentary “Cricket’s Match-fixers Al Jazeera Investigations“ dated 27th May 2018, is false and out of context as far as he is concerned.
 
He said it that it has been deliberately used to tarnish his image and reputation as a cricketer and coach.

heading: Death toll due to inclement weather increased to 24
description:
Certain areas in Gampaha, Ja Ela & Puttlam remain inundated...
 
The death toll due to the inclement weather conditions has risen to 24.
 
74,310 persons of 45,680 families in 20 districts have been affected.
 
It has been reported that certain areas in Gampaha and Ja Ela remain inundated due to the flooding of the Attanagalu Oya, and several areas in Puttalam are remain inundated as well.
 
Meanwhile, the final rights of the police officer Dilan Sampath, who died while trying to save a 3-member family on Friday (May 25) in Madampe was held today at Malgamuwa in Giriulla today.
 
The late officer was given an honorary 21 gun salute.
 
Many police personnel including the Inspector General of Police attended the funeral.
 
The body of Officer Dilan Sampath who went missing whilst on a rescue mission was recovered yesterday.
 
Meanwhile, the Disaster Management Minister, Duminda Dissanayake has instructed the IGP to look into the difficulties faced by relief groups while assisting those affected by floods.
 
The instruction was issued by the Minister after he received complaints that certain groups are demanding extortions from relief providers.
 
Therefore, the Disaster management Center requests the public to inform on such persons or groups to 119 or 117.
 
A landslide warning has been issued for the districts of Ratnapura, Kegalle, Kandy, Matale, Nuwara Eliya, Kalutara and Galle.
 
The Disaster Management Center says the warning was issued after taking into consideration the prevailing rainy weather conditions
 
Furthermore, the Department of Irrigation noted that the water levels of the Kalu River, Nilwala River and Attanagalu Oya have risen, and therefore requested that people living in the surrounding areas to remain vigilant.

heading: TB questioned for over 4 and half hours
description:
The Financial Crime Investigation Division recorded a statement from a former State Minister of Lands T. B. Ekanayake for over 4 and half hours today (May 28).
 
He was summoned to give a record a statement in connection with an alleged misuse of a state vehicle during his tenure as the State Minister of Cultural Affairs in the previous regime.
 
MP, Ekanayake who arrived at FCID at 10 am had left the premises in the afternoon.
 
Meanwhile, MPs Bandula Gunawardana and Mahindananda Aluthgamage, as well as several members of the SLFP Group of 16, were present at the FCID to show solidarity with MP Ekanayake.

heading: Deepani Silva granted bail in a car crash (CCTV footage)
description:
Veteran actress Deepani Silva who was arrested following an accident was released on a personal surety of Rs. 200,000 by the Panadura Magistrate Kalhari Liyanage this afternoon (May 28).
 
The Magistrate impounded her driving license.
 
Her car driven by Deepani collided with a three-wheeler at the Kindelpitiya Junction this morning.
 
A 10-year-old schoolgirl was critically injured in the accident and her father was also injured.
 
The girl is being treated at the Kalubowila Hospital and her father was discharged.
 
Following the accident, Bandaragama Police arrested the actress and produced before Panadura Magistrate.

heading: Ranjan's attempt backfires
description:
During a media conference held in Colombo today (May 28) Deputy Minister Ranjan Ramanayake inquired from astrologist Sumanadasa Abeygunawardena about a house allegedly owned by former Defence Secretary Gotabhaya Rajapaksa.
 
This is the discussion:

heading: Dayasiri regrets obtaining Arjun's money
description:
Parliamentarian Dayasiri Jayasekera says he shouldn't have accepted money from Arjun Aloysius.
 
He is accused of allegedly obtaining Rs. 1 million from the tainted businessman.
 
The former Minister said this in response to questions posed by journalists during a media conference in Colombo today (May 28).

heading: Railway technical staff to strike
description: The Railway technicians say they will launch a strike from 4 pm tomorrow.

heading: Former Sports Minister Dayasiri expresses views on pitch-fixing
National Policy on early childhood development mooted
description:
The Parliamentary Sectoral Oversight Committee on Women and Gender says that a national policy on early childhood development will be formulated.
 
The Chairperson of the Committee, MP Dr. Thusithaa Wijemanne told us that the topics of early childhood development and elementary education were discussed extensively at a meeting held at the Parliament premises.

heading: Winds in seas around Sri Lanka to enhance
description:
The Met Department says that the windy conditions are expected to enhance further in the sea areas around the island.
 
Showers or thundershowers will occur at times in the sea areas extending from Puttalam to Hambantota via Colombo and Galle.
 
Showers or thundershowers will occur at several places in the other sea areas.
 
Winds will be southwesterly in the direction of the sea areas around the island and wind speed will be 35-45 kmph.
 
Sea area extending from Mannar to Batticaloa via Puttalam, Colombo, Galle, and Hambantota can be rough or very rough at times as the wind speed can increase up to 60-70 kmph at times.

heading: Johann Peries says he achieves his dream
description:
The second Sri Lankan to reach the summit of Mount Everest, Johann Peries says that he succeeded in making his dream a reality.
 
He said that he did not give up on his dream even though he failed for the first time when he accompanied the first Sri Lankan to reach the summit, Jayanthi Kuru-Uthumpala.

heading: Development Officer candidates accuse 'they were bullied at interviews'
description:
It was reported that inappropriate questions on personal matters have been asked from female candidates at the interviews to recruit development officers.
 
The interview panel had reportedly asked questions on personal matters such as their marital status and relationship status, from unemployed graduates.
 
An unemployed graduate told us that the panel paid more attention towards extra-curricular activities than their academic qualifications.
 
The Convener of the Unemployed Graduates Association, Venerable Thanne Gnanananda Thera said that the government should take measures to prevent such situations.

heading: CEB engineers to move out of repairs
description:
The CEB engineers say they will move out of weekend duties, attending to sudden power outages and renovation work.
The CEB engineers commenced a work-to-rule campaign on 9th of this month.
They resorted to the trade union action in protest against failure by Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka to approve the Long-Term Power Generation Plan submitted by the CEB.

heading: Showers recede, landslide risk remains
description:
The Met Department says that although showers are expected to recede, the South-Western parts of the island are expected to experience few more showers.
 
The Director of the Met Department, Athula Karunanayake said that showers or thundershowers will occur at times in Western, Sabaragamuwa, and Galle and Matara districts.
 
153, 712 persons belonging to 40, 017 families have been affected by inclement weather experienced in 20 districts.
 
National Disaster Management Centre said that 23 persons have lost their lives in weather-related incidents.
 
The landslide warning issued for Kalutara, Galle, Ratnapura, Kegalle and Nuwara-Eliya remains in place.
