The Ministry of Power and Renewable Energy says that due to heavy showers Castlereigh Reservoir is closing spill levels.
 
The Media Spokesperson of the Ministry Sulakshana Jayawardana speaking to us said that water levels of reservoirs used for hydropower generation have now neared 80 percent of their capacity.
 
Meanwhile, the body of the hero police constable attached to the Madampe Police who was dragged away by flood waters while trying to rescue a marooned family has been found.
 
Madampe Police stated that the 29-year-old Police constable’s body was found 200 meters from Galwala South.
 
He has been posthumously promoted to the rank of police sergeant.

heading: Water bowser hits A-320 Airbus at BIA, damages exceed Rs. 15mn
description:
An extensive damage has been caused to a SriLanka Airlines' A-320 Airbus when a water bowser had collided with its tail last morning (May 26).
Our correspondent said that the flight had returned from Lahore and the estimated cost of the damage is around Rs. 15 million.
The authorities have called an inquiry and suspended the driver of the bowser.
When contacted, the Communications Manager of SriLankan Airlines, Deepal Perera said an investigation has been launched into the incident.

heading: Police fire kills rehabilitated LTTE cadre in Tamil Nadu
description:
It has been identified that one of the 13 persons killed in Tamil Nadu police fire was a Sri Lankan.
 
The police opened fire in Tuticorin on Wednesday on a protest which was held against the expansion of the Sterlite plant.
 
It was found that the victim was a rehabilitated LTTE cadre and he had gone to Tamil Nadu recently.
P. Mahendran, chief of Tuticorin police, said 18 policemen were injured in the clashes.
Tamil Nadu chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami has ordered a judicial inquiry into the shootings but defended the police response.
The company's operational licence had expired in April and the company was waiting for the government to renew it.
Residents who say the copper smelter is causing environmental damage, have been protesting against it for months.

heading: 11 districts face landslide risk
description:
The Disaster Management Center says 11 districts are still facing the risk of landslides.
 
The districts are: Ratnapura, Kegalle, Kandy, Matale, Nuwara Eliya, Badulla, Kalutara, Galle, Kurunegala, Colombo and Gampaha.
 
Meanwhile, the water level of Kaluganga and Attanagalu Oya are rising further and the water level of other reservoirs and rivers are receding.

heading: Rs. 16mn worth heroin detected
description:
Police have arrested an associate of underworld figure SF Lokka with 160g of heroin during a raid in Vijayapura in Anuradhapura.
 
The market value of the find was Rs. 16 million.
 
The suspect was arrested last afternoon (May 26) based on information provided by another suspect who is already in police custody.
 
The underworld figure SF Lokka is in remand custody.

heading: Schools in Gampaha education zone to be closed
description: The Ministry of Education says as a result of the existing floods, all the schools in the Gampaha Education Zone will be closed.

heading: Enrollment to Education Colleges on June 5 and 6
description:
The Ministry of Education says enrollment to 19 Educational Colleges in the island will be taking place on June 5th and 6th.
 
It will be done based on 2015 advanced level examination and the students are enrolled in 27 subjects.
 
Altogether, 4746 students will be enrolled.
 
Meanwhile, Education Minister Akila Virak Kariyawasam has instructed the authorities to provide textbooks to the students who are affected by the prevailing weather havoc.
 
The relevant instructions have been issued to Educational Directors of the areas hit by floods and landslides.

heading: Rain continues to affect Puttlam and Gampaha
Prime Minister to visit North
description:
Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe is scheduled to undertake a visit to the North tomorrow, the PM's Office said.
 
He will take a firsthand look at the progress of the development projects being undertaken in the region by the government.
 
The progress of resettlement, housing construction, employment creation and improvement of other infrastructure will be evaluated by the PM during his visit.
 
The PM's Office said that PM Wickremesinghe will chair 2 Progress Review Meetings in Kilinochchi and Jaffna.

heading: Inhumane act of ransom takers
description:
Most of the main roads in the district of Puttalam are under water due to incessant rains.
 
Some good Samaritans extend a helping hand to the fellow countrymen in this time of the need.
 
However, there are few people who demand ransom from those who come to assist the affected people.

heading: Police says Dananjaya's father was ‘the target’
description:
His body bears 3 cut wounds....
Further investigations launched to find assailants....
 
The post-mortem of Councillor Ranjan de Silva, the father of national cricketer Danajaya de Silva, has revealed that there were three stab wounds in his chest area.
 
Following this police said that Ranjan de Silva was, in fact, the target of the assailants and not his son.
 
Ranjan de Silva was shot dead on Thursday (May 24) outside his house while he was talking to two others, by unidentified gunmen.
 
The elder brother of Dananjaya de Silva, Sachithra de Silva has stated that he suspects that their father was murdered over a dispute he had with an accomplice of Amal Sinhara alias Kudu Anju.
 
Police stated that CCTV footage recovered from the area had revealed many facts, and accordingly investigations are being carried out to find the assailants - however, they added that no arrests have been made so far.
 
The funeral of Ranjan de Silva will be held at the Mount Lavinia public cemetery at 4 pm tomorrow.
 
A number of politicians had arrived at the family residence to pay their final respects to the Municipal Councillor.

heading: People near Jaela urged to evacuate
description:
The Disaster Management Center asks the people living in the low-lying areas of Jaela to seek shelter at safe locations as the water level of Jaela is rising with the receding of flood waters from the Attanagalu Oya.
It was also reported with the flooding of Deduru Oya, Chilaw, Jayabima and Deduruoya areas have inundated.
50 families in those villages have been affected and 40 other families in Madampe and Galahitiyawa are also affected.
Our correspondents said that the central hills are experiencing rough winds.
The Road Development Authority said that the Hatton - Colombo road has been cleared for vehicle movements now.
The vehicle movement was restricted due to a landslide in Diyagala last afternoon.

heading: Former UPFA councillor killed in a motorbike accident
description:
A 44-year-old person was killed when 2 motorcycles collided head-on in Medagama, Monaragala last night (May 25).
The deceased was a former councillor at the Medagama Pradeshiya Sabha.
2 others who sustained injuries in the accident were first admitted to Medagama Hospital and thereafter transferred to Monaragala Hospital.

heading: Rtd. Judge to probe fixing allegations against clubs
description:
Sri Lanka Cricket has invited Retired Judge of the Supreme Court Justice Rohini Marasinghe to conduct an independent inquiry into the allegations of match-fixing against Panadura CC and Kalutara PCC.
 
The Judge will evaluate the reports of the inquiries conducted by the SLC appointed Panel of Inquiry led by Asela Rekawa and that of the Ministry of Sports conducted by Palitha Kumarasingha PC.
 
She will also conduct her own inquiry and pronounce a final judgment as well as recommendations for punitive action against those found guilty.

heading: Public urged to drink purified water
description:
The health authorities are urging the public to drink purified water in order to prevent the spread of communicable diseases in the wake of the prevailing weather.
 
They also request the people to be vigilant against respiratory ailments, dengue and rat fever.

heading: Ma Oya overflows in Puttalam
description:
Most of the roads in the Puttalam District have inundated due to the flooding of Ma Oya.
Our correspondent said Madampe - Kuliyapitiya road and Colombo - Puttalam road are inundated in Mahawewa.
The Puttalam - Anamaduwa road and Nattandiya - Thummodara roads are also flooded.

heading: Heavy showers to reduce from tomorrow; Ja-ela overflows, several roads in Puttalam under water. 19 dead due to inclement weather
Floods affect Nattandiya, Mahawewa and Wennappuwa
description:
The flood situation in the Nattandiya, Mahawewa and Wennappuwa areas has increased.
 
The Disaster Management Center says it is dangerous for small vehicles to use the Lunuwila Bridge on the Colombo - Puttalam main road.
 
They also urged the public not to visit flooded areas.

heading: Probe expanded into murder of Dhananjaya’s father
description:
A team from the Mount Lavinia Police will record a statement from cricketer Dhananjaya De Silva’s elder brother Savithra de Silva, regarding the death of his father, who was gunned down on Thursday night (May 24).
 
A senior officer of the Mount Lavinia Police said that investigations will be conducted based on his statements to the media yesterday.
 
Vital information has been uncovered through CCTV footage regarding the killing.
 
A Senior Officer carrying out investigations said that the vehicle used by the assailants has been identified.
 
Police stated that the deceased,  Ranjan De Silva, who was a Councillor of the Dehiwala – Mount Lavinia Municipal Council representing the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna, had been shot 12 times.
 
An underworld gang who arrived in a white colour motorcar is reported to have carried out the killing.

heading: UN says 96% of disasters in Sri Lanka caused by climate issues
description:
The UN agencies say 96 percent of disasters in Sri Lanka are caused by climate issues, such as flooding, landslides, extreme winds and drought.
 
Sri Lanka has ranked the fourth most climate change affected the country in 2016 according to the Global Climate Risk Index, 2018.
 
The annual cycle of floods and drought is causing severe household economic and social stress in Sri Lanka, they say.
 
Heavy rainfall during the southwest monsoon period in 2016 and 2017 caused widespread floods and landslides in southern and western regions.
 
Over 500 people were killed (including 191 people still reported as 'missing' in official documents) and over 1.3 million people were affected during the two years.
 
The high number of deaths is being attributed to inadequate emergency preparedness measures.

heading: Disaster deaths increased to 21
description:
The Disaster Management Center says weather-related deaths have increased to 21.
 
The DMC said that 153,712 persons are affected by inclement weather.

heading: Underworld involves in killing of Dhananjaya’s father ?
description:
Police have uncovered many facts regarding the murder of the father of cricketer Dananjaya de Silva.
 
Police had recorded a statement once again from the elder brother of Dananjaya, Sachithra de Silva this morning.
 
He has stated that he suspects that their father was murdered over a dispute he had with an accomplice of Amal Sinhara alias Kudu Anju.
 
The incident had taken place on last Vesak day.
 
Police suspect that Amal Sinhara alias Kudu Anju, who is connected to many crimes, may have ordered the murder which is suspected to have carried out by another group.
 
4 special police teams are conducting investigations into the incident while another team commenced investigations under the directives of the Inspector General of Police. 
 
Police stated that CCTV footage is also being examined to identify those who were involved in the murder.
 
The mortal remains of councilor Ranjan de Silva were brought to his residence in Rathmalana last night.
 
Cricketers and many politicians paid their last respects to the late councilor today.
 
The final rites of the late councilor will be held on Monday at the Mount Lavinia Cemetry.

heading: GMOA urges Govt. to take speedy measures to contain viral flu
description:
The Government Medical Officers' Association says that health authorities should take speedy measures to prevent the viral flu spreading across the Southern Province, from becoming a severe epidemic.
 
The Karapitiya Hospital branch of the GMOA noted that 8 individuals including children have died in Karapitiya Teaching Hospital alone, of the disease.
 
However, Director of Health Services of the Southern Province, Dr. J. Wijesooriya stated that the situation would be contained within two weeks.

heading: SB says other SLFPers in government will come out
description:
Former Minister S. B. Dissanayake says they will convince the remaining Sri Lanka Freedom Party members in the government to leave it.
 
Dissanayake said this addressing a public forum organized by the SLFP's 'Group of 16", who left the government last month.
 
Addressing the forum, MP Lakshman Yapa Abeywardena said various political forces are now uniting with them.

heading: Bandula seeks legal action against misuse of public funds
description:
Parliamentarian Bandula Gunawardena says he would seek to take legal action against the misuse of the public finance.
 
He said this in Parliament yesterday (May 25).
 
National Policies and Economic Affairs State Minister Niroshan Perera intervened in the discussion, creating a tense atmosphere in the House.

heading: Former President Mahinda on the lookout for a candidate for 2020
description:
Former President Mahinda Rajapaksa says that he too is on the lookout as to who would be the Presidential candidate in 2020.
 
The former President expressed these views after having called on the Chief Prelate of the Malwathu Chapter, Most Venerable Thibbatuwawe Sri Sumangala Thera last afternoon (May 25).

heading: Heavy showers predicted to reduce from today
description:
President Maithripala Sirisena has instructed officials not to make circulars an obstacle when providing relief to the people who are affected by the recent floods and landslides.
The President expressed these views joining an inspection tour in Chilaw to look into relief efforts.
153,712 persons belonging to 40 thousand 17 families have been affected by inclement weather experienced in 20 districts.
21 persons have lost their lives.

heading: TNA says 'do not believe' in a new constitution
description:
Tamil National Alliance Parliamentarian S. Sritharan says that the Tamil people do not believe in the proposed new constitution.
He said that the Tamil people do not trust that it will be able to solve the issues of the Tamil community.
The TNA MP said that when Hiru News sought his views on the new constitution.

heading: Fire at private bank in Kalubowila
description:
A fire broke out in a private bank in Kalubowila early this morning (May 27).
The bank's front entrance and ATM machine were damaged by the fire.
The fire was contained by the Fire Brigade at Dehiwela - Mt. Lavinia Municipal Council and Kohuwela police.

heading: Body of hero police officer found
description:
The body of the hero police constable who was missing while attempting to rescue a family that was marooned by flood waters, has been found.
The body was found following a search operation conducted by a Navy team.
The 29-year-old police constable went missing on Friday (May 25) and his body was located from 200m where he went missing.
Police said that the body is now kept at Chilaw Hospital.

heading: Viral flu spreads to Hambantota
description:
The viral flu spreading in the South is now affecting the public in the Hambantota district.
 
It is reported that cases of viral fever have increased by 50 percent over the last few days.
 
The Director of Hambantota District Health Services, Dr.  A. P. R. S. Chandrasena said that the majority of those patients are reportedly from Tangalle, Walasmulla and Tissamaharama.
 
The authorities have closed the preschools in the area until 4th of June to contain the spread of the disease.
 
Meanwhile, the primary sections of the schools in Udugama, Morawaka, Galle, Matara, Mulatiyana, Akuressa, Tangalle and Walsamulla educational zones were also closed for 2 days.
 
Those schools will remain closed on Monday as well.
 
So far 14 persons have died of this viral flu and 400 patients are receiving treatment at hospitals in the South.

heading: Collapsing earth mound kills a father of one
description:
A 40-year-old person was killed when an earth mound collapsed on his house in Alawwa early this morning (May 25).
 
The victim was a resident of Nawathalwatte in Alawwa.
 
Police said the victim who was sleeping at the time of the incident, died upon admission to Dambadeniya Hospital.
 
The victim's wife and 3-year-old daughter were not at home when the tragedy struck and they had gone to wife's mother's house.
 
Meanwhile, a 50-year-old person died in Ratnapura Hospital after he had drowned in flash floods in Galagamadeniya.
 
He was on a make-shift boat.
 
With those incidents, the DMC said that the death toll in weather-related incidents rose to 16.

heading: Weather havoc : Rains to continue
description:
The death toll due to inclement weather has risen to 16.
The Disaster Management Centre said that the majority of the deaths were caused by victims being swept away by flood waters or by drowning.
The impact of the adverse weather continues to affect 19 districts, where approximately 127,913 have been affected.
Meanwhile, the Irrigation Department said that the catchment areas of Kelani River and Attanagalu Oya had received heavy rains last night.
At the same time, Assistant Director of the Disaster Management Center Pradeep Kodippili said that the landslide red alerts will remain in place.
The Met Department said that the prevailing rains in the south-western part of the island will continue throughout today.
Showers or thunderstorms will occur at times in Western, Southern, Sabaragamuwa, Central and North-Western provinces, and elsewhere after 2 pm.

heading: Earth slips block Colombo - Hatton road (Photos)
description:
Vehicular movement along the Hatton - Colombo main road has been disrupted in Diyagala, Ginigathhena due to earth slips.
 
Only one lane of the road is accessible after rocks and soil embankment collapsed on the road last evening (May 24).
 
Police while urging the motorists to use alternative roads asked the road users to be vigilant.

heading: 20 A handed over to Speaker
description:
The Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna handed over the 20th amendment to the constitution to Speaker Karu Jayasuriya in Parliament this morning (May 25).
 
The amendment proposes the abolition of the Executive Presidency.
 
The proposal has been moved as a private member bill.

heading: Pradeshiya Sabha officials and vendors clash in Wellawaya
description:
A tense situation erupted in Wellawaya town this morning (May 25), when Pradeshiya Sabha officials took steps to remove pavement hawkers.
 
They demolished unauthorized trade stalls on the pavements.
 
It led to a tense situation.
 
However, Pradeshiya Sabha officials sought the assistance of the police to continue the demolition.

heading: Electricity breakdown in Colpetty
Hero police officer reported missing in Madampe while rescuing flood victims
description:
A member of a police team that rescued people who were stranded in flood waters is reported missing after he was swept away.
 
The Police Spokesperson's Office said that the incident took place at Galmuruwa in Madampe.
 
The missing police constable was aged 29 and was attached to Madampe Police.

heading: Four police teams deployed to track gunmen in murder of Dhananjaya’s father
description:
Four police have been deployed to probe last night’s murder of the father of Sri Lankan national cricketer, Dhananjaya de Silva.
 
A senior police officer said the investigators will also analyze the CCTV footage in the surroundings to find any clues of the assailants.
 
He added that statements from family members are being recorded.
 
The drive-by shooting took place on Gnanendra Road in Ratmalana when the victim, Ranjan de Silva was chatting with few friends in front of his house.
 
Initial investigations revealed that T-56 weapons were used in the crime.
 
Police said that Ranjan de Silva had been shot 12 times.
 
Meanwhile, a spokesperson from Kalubowila Hospital said that the other two victims who were injuries are not in a critical condition.
 
Police further said that CCTV footage will be analyzed as part of the ongoing investigation.
 
62-year-old, Ranjan de Silva of Beach Road, Ratmalana was a member of the Dehiwala - Mt. Lavinia Municipal Council.
 
He was elected to the council from Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna after winning at the February 10
 Local Government Election.
 
Meanwhile, Dhananjaya de Silva who was to leave for West Indies with the Test squad has withdrawn from the team.

heading: Weather havoc : Death toll risen to 15
description:
The Disaster Management Center says the death toll due to weather-related incidents has risen to 15.
 
The DMC said most of those deaths are caused after victims were carried away by flood waters and by drowning.
 
The data shows 126,000 persons in 19 districts are affected by inclement weather.

heading: Weather havoc : 138,000 persons affected
description:
The Disaster Management Center says 138,292 persons belonging to 35,129 families are affected by inclement weather, which has affected 20 districts.
 
The DMC said there are 16 fatalities and one person is missing.
 
53,616 persons of 13,199 families are given shelter at 231 welfare centres.
 
64 houses were fully destroyed and 3,841 houses were partially damaged.
 
Meanwhile, our correspondent said one of the sluice gates of the Laxapana Reservoir was opened this afternoon due to prevailing rains.
 
62-year-old, Ranjan de Silva of Beach Road, Ratmalana was a member of the Dehiwala - Mt. Lavinia Municipal Council.
 
He was elected to the council from Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna after winning at the February 10
 Local Government Election.
 
Meanwhile, Dhananjaya de Silva who was to leave for West Indies with the Test squad has withdrawn from the team.
Sports Minister directs officials to resume School Rugby League
 
It has been agreed during a discussion held this morning (May 25) to resume the matches of the School Rugby League from this week.
 
The discussion was held between the Sports Ministry officials and Education Ministry officials at the Sports Ministry.
 
The officials were asked to ensure the safety of the match officials and the players.
 
The matches of the School Rugby League Championship were postponed after clashes erupted during several matches in the past few days.

heading: Weather havoc : Most parts of Puttalam & Kurunegala flooded
description:
Most parts of Puttalam and Kurunegala have flooded due to persistent rains.
 
The roads and schools have also gone under water.
 
Police said a motorcyclist and a police constable were carried away by flood waters in separate incidents.
 
The policeman was a member of a team that rescued a group of people who were stranded in flood waters.
 
He was reported missing after being swept away.
 
The Police Spokesperson's Office said that the incident took place at Galmuruwa in Madampe.
 
The missing police constable was aged 29 and was attached to Madampe Police.

heading: Bail plea of Arjun Aloysius postponed
description:
The consideration of the bail application filed by the owner of the Perpetual Treasuries, Arjun Aloysius and its CEO Kasun Palisena was postponed to 1st of June by the Court of Appeal today (May 25).
 
The bail plea was taken up before the President of the Court of Appeal, Preethi Padman Surasena and Shiran Gooneratne.
 
Meanwhile, appearing on behalf of the Attorney General, Senior Additional Solicitor General Yasantha Kodagoda told the court, that the order issued by Colombo Fort Magistrate rejecting this bail application was legitimate.

heading: Power supply restored in Colpetty
description:
The Ceylon Electricity Board says that the power supply has been restored in Colpetty.
 
Due to a technical fault in the high tension cable from Kolonnawa, the power supply to Colpetty was disrupted this afternoon.

heading: Attanagalu Oya and Ma Oya reaching to flood level - DMC
description:
The Disaster Management Center says that the water level of Attanagalu Oya has risen to a major flood level.
 
People living in Divisional Secretariat areas of Negombo, Ja-Ela, Katana, Minuwangoda, Gampaha and Attanagalla are requested to be vigilant and take safety measures.
 
The DMC also warned that the water level in Ma Oya has increased.
 
The people living close to the waterway in Badalgama and Giriulla are advised to be vigilant.

heading: Depositors charge Muthukaruppan Chettiar acquired using ETI money
description:
The depositors of ETI Finance charge that the ETI Director Board has acquired Muthukaruppan Chettiar using their deposits.
 
The ETI depositors say, however, that the ETI Director Board is trying to show it as a separate entity.
 
They pointed out that ETI Finance and Muthukaruppan Chettiar have the same Director Board which included Nalaka  Edirisinghe and Jeewaka Edirisinghe.
 
The depositors said that the ETI Director Board is responsible for their deposits.
 
They charge that the ETI Directors have acquired other institutions using their money.
 
The depositors urged the government to intervene to acquire Muthukaruppan Chettiar and settle their deposits.

heading: Chickenpox closes agri-faculty at Rajarata University
description:
The Rajarata University's agri-faculty situated at Saliyapura in Anuradhapura has been closed due to the spread of chickenpox among the undergraduates.
 
Accordingly, the agri-faculty will be closed for 2 weeks until 6th of June.
 
Around 350 students are attached to the agri-faculty and they were informed to vacate the hostels last evening.

heading: Weather havoc : Heavy rains hit Puttalam and Ratnapura
description:
The Meteorology Department says that the existing low-pressure in the Bay of Bengal could develop into a depression.
 
The Department said that as a result the prevailing rain could be further enhanced in the next few days.
 
In the last 24 hours, ending at 8:30 this morning, the highest rainfall of 122.7mm was reported in Mellawa in Puttalam.
 
Several areas including Wanaathavillu, Arachchikattuwa are still under water.
 
Train services on the Puttalam line that were disrupted yesterday following the overflow of Hamilton canal have been restored today.
 
Meanwhile, several areas of Ratnapura is underwater, due to prevailing rains.
 
Our correspondents said Bulathsinhala, Millaniya, Ingiriya, Palinda Nuwara have inundated.
 
The affected residents have been sent to safe locations with the intervention of the DMC officials.
 
The Irrigation Department warned that people living close to low lying areas in the banks of Gin, Kalu, and Kelani rivers to be vigilant for flash floods.
 
The landslide alert issued for Kegalle, Ratnapura, Kalutara, Galle and Nuwara Eliya is still active.
 
Meanwhile, the Disaster Management Center said 124,733 persons in 18 districts are affected due to the prevailing inclement weather.
 
It added that the death toll has increased to 12.
 
The DMC said that displaced persons are given shelter at 229 welfare centers.

heading: ETI depositors protest again in Ward Place
description:
A group of people who have deposited money at ETI Finance staged a protest in front of the ETI office in Ward Place, Borella today (May 24).
 
The ETI Finance is a subsidiary of EAP Group.
 
The depositors have protested a number of times in front of the ETI Head Office, so far, but they are yet to get their money.
 
They accused that the management of the company is evading them.
 
Later, the depositors marched towards the Official Residence of President in Wijerama Road and staged a protest there.
 
Then 2 of the protestors were allowed to meet a Coordinating Secretary of President Sirisena to hand over a document.
 
He had informed the protestors that the President has already taken necessary steps to address the issues of ETI depositors.
 
Meanwhile, it was disclosed at the Parliament yesterday that Swarnamahal Jewellers (Pvt.) Limited, which is a subsidiary of EAP Group, is obtaining deposits from the public without Central Bank approval.

heading: Parliament faces flood threats ?
description:
Speaker Karu Jayasuriya has informed the relevant authorities to be stand-by as the Parliamentary Complex is faced with the threat of being flooded.
 
A senior official at the Speaker's Office said that the Secretary-General of Parliament has accordingly informed about it to the security personnel.
 
The Ministry of Megapolis and Western Development had informed the Speaker yesterday (May 23) of the imminent danger faced by the House.
 
In 2010 too, the ground floor of the Parliament was flooded.

heading: Update : Mother dies in Nittambuwa shooting
description:
Of the two persons - a mother and son - who were injured during a shooting in Nittambuwa, the mother has succumbed to her injuries.
They were shot at by a motorcyclist at around 12.55 pm while they were travelling on a motorcycle.
The injured were admitted to Wathupitiwala Hospital.  
The mother, 53-year-old Vinitha Padmini, was a resident of Dumunnegedara, Kaleliya.
The son who was aged 26, is being treated at Wathupitiwala Hospital.
Nittambuwa Police probe the incident. 
Update: Thursday, 24 May 2018 - 14.58
...........................................................
Shooting in Nittambuwa, mother & son injured
Police say a mother and her son were injured in a shooting incident in Nittambuwa this afternoon.
 
The sources said that the condition of the mother was critical.
 
Police said that they were shot at by a gunman on a motorcycle in Hathwadunna at around 12.55 pm.
The victims were travelling on a motorcycle.

heading: Police arrest hit & run driver
description:
Police have arrested a hit and run driver who had knocked down a pedestrian in front of the Maharagama Municipal Council.
 
The victim, who was crossing the road on a zebra crossing, was knocked down in the wee hours of today (May 24).
 
The 56-old-person died and the car had sped away after the accident.
 
However, the police were able to track the vehicle and arrest the driver this morning.

heading: Naval & fishing communities warned
description:
The Met Department says that the sea area extending from Mannar to Potuvil via Puttalam, Colombo, Galle and Hambantota can be rough or very rough at times as the wind speed can increase up to 60-70kmph at times.
 
Temporarily very strong gusty winds up to 70-80kmph and rough seas can be expected during thundershowers.
 
Naval and fishing communities are requested to be vigilant.

heading: Interpol locates Arjuna Mahendran
description:
The Interpol has informed the Criminal Investigation Department that former Central Bank Governor Arjuna Mahendran is in Singapore.
 
The Interpol's Singapore branch has conveyed this.
 
The Attorney General Department revealed this when the case relating to the Central Bank bond scam was taken up at the Colombo Fort Magistrate Court, before Magistrate Lanka Jayaratne.
 
Meanwhile, the owner of Perpetual Treasuries Arjun Aloysius and its CEO Kasun Palisena were remanded until 7th of June.
 
They were also produced before the court today (May 24).

heading: Kaduwela Bridge to be closed from 8 pm
description:
The Road Development Authority says that the bridge linking Biyagama and Kaduwela towns will be closed from 8 pm today (May 24).
 
The RDA said it will be closed until 6 am tomorrow as a precautionary measure.
 
The vehicle movement has been restricted on the bridge after soil erosion was detected on the banks due to heavy rain.

heading: Youth murdered by slashing neck in Mullaithivu (Photos)
description:
Police last evening found a body of a 28-year-old person who had been cut to death by unidentified persons in Selvapuram, Mullaitivu.
 
The body was found last evening and the magisterial inquiry was conducted this morning (May 24).
 
Police said that the victim was missing from last morning.
 
Police said there were several cut marks in the victim's body and his neck has been slashed.

heading: Ven. Galagodaatte Ghanasara Thera found guilty
description:
Ven. Galagodaatte Ghanasara Thera of 'Bodu Bala Sena' has been found guilty of threatening journalist Pradeep Ekneligoda's wife in front of Homagama courts.
 
The Homagama Magistrate Udesh Ranatunga delivered the verdict today (May 24).
 
The sentencing will be taking place on 14th of June.
 
Ven. Ghanasara Thera was accused of threatening Sandhya Ekneligoda on 25th of January 2016.

heading: Finance Minister says VAT will be reduced
description:
Finance Minister Mangala Samaraweera says the Value Added Tax will be reduced by 2.5% in 2020.
 
At present, the VAT stands at 15%.
 
The Minister said this addressing an event at the Finance Ministry today (May 24) where letters of appointment were presented to 68 newly selected Assistant Superintendents of Customs.

He said most of those files had been opened voluntarily.
 
The Minister further said that after Independence in 1948, the highest amount of debt servicing has to be paid in 2018.
 
The total foreign debt to be paid this year is US$ 2,845 million and of which US$ 1,789 million has to be paid for government borrowings done before the year 2015.
 
He added only an installment of US$ 1,056 to be paid for the foreign loans borrowed after 2015.

Police have arrested a teacher at Thelippalai Union College, Jaffna for allegedly sexually abusing seven girls from grade 7.
 
The arrest was made yesterday (May 23).
 
Police said the accused teacher, who was teaching mathematics in English medium has been abusing the 12-year-old girls for some period, threatening them.

The suspected teacher will be produced before courts today.

description:
The authorities have decided to close all the pre-schools in Southern Province until 3
 of June.
 
The move has been taken to contain the spread of viral fever.
 
Meanwhile, the primary schools in the Udugama, Morawaka, Galle, Matara, Akuressa and Tangalle educational zones will be closed on 24, 25 and 28 of May due to the infectious fever epidemic.

Department of Irrigation says that the water level of the Kelani River is now receding.
 
However, it was reported that the water level of the Kalu Ganga is rising due to the prevailing rainy weather.
 
Meanwhile, the Department of Education has decided to postpone several examinations to be held in the coming days.
 
Meanwhile, the Met Department said that the prevailing rainy condition in the South-western part of the island is expected to continue.
 
Showers or thundershowers will occur at times in Western, Southern, Sabaragamuwa, Central and North-Western provinces.
 
Showers or thundershowers will occur elsewhere, particularly after 2 pm.
 
Showers or thundershowers will occur in Jaffna, Mannar and Mullaitivu districts in the morning too.
 
Heavy falls, about 100-150 mm can be expected at some places in Sabaragamuwa, Western, Central and North-western provinces and in Galle, Matara districts.

description:
Police say a huge traffic congestion is reported from the Technical Junction in 
due to a fallen tree.

description:
The Disaster Management Center urges the people living in Kalutara, Dodangoda, Millaniya, Horana, Bulathsinhala, Ingiriya, Kuruwita, and Ratnapura, nearby the bank of Kaluganga to move out.

Weather havoc : Over 119,000 affected
description:
The Met Department says that ongoing rains in the South-western part of the island are expected to continue.
 
Periodic showers or thunderstorms will occur in Western, Southern, Sabaragamuwa, Central, and North-Western provinces, with the same expected elsewhere, after 2 pm.
 
Heavy rainfall around 150 mm is predicted in Sabaragamuwa, Western, Central and North-western provinces and also in the Galle and Matara districts.
 
Meanwhile, 11 deaths have been reported, with over 119,000 individuals in 18 districts have been adversely affected by the inclement weather.
 
The Disaster Management Centre noted that the flood victims are being sheltered at 229 camps.
 
As water levels of Kalu River rose due to heavy rains, residents in low lying areas in and around Ratnapura and Kalutara districts were evacuated with the assistance of the DMC and security forces.
 
Residents of Ratnapura, Kiriella, Elapatha, Kuruwita, Kalutara, Dodangoda, Horana, Palinda Nuwara, Bulathsinhala and Ingiriya have been evacuated.
 
The Assistant Director of the DMC Pradeep Kodipilli noted that those who have been directed to safer locations should remain at these locations until further notice.
 
The Puttalam and Ratnapura districts are still severely impacted by heavy rainfall.
 
Our reporters said that as a result of all minor tanks in the Puttalam District exceeding spill-over level, low-lying areas in Mahawewa, Madampe, Naththandiya, and Aarachchikattuwa have been inundated.
Certain low-lying areas in Gampaha and Colombo districts have also been flooded.
Reports state that as a result of Kelani River overflowing, roads in Biyagama and Malwana in addition to other low-lying areas are still flooded.

description:
Former Minister MP Susil Premajayantha says the 16 Sri Lanka Freedom Party group would work with the Joint Opposition to establish a strong opposition against the government.
 
He said this was agreed upon during a special discussion with former President Mahinda Rajapaksa in Colombo last evening.
 
The discussion which was lasted for 2 hours, was attended by 15 of 16 SLFP MP’s who recently resigned from the Unity Government.
 
Former minister Anura Priyadarshana Yapa did not attend the discussion as he was overseas.

description:
A group of railway workers - ticket checkers and goods inspectors - have been engaging in a strike since last midnight.
They are urging the authorities to address their wage issues as well as to fill the vacant positions in their categories.
However, railway signalmen who were also scheduled to join the strike, have withdrawn from the strike.
Sri Lanka Railways said that the ongoing strike would not affect the train services.

Thabbowa reservoir overflowing - DMC
Special message for pregnant teachers
description:
The pregnant teachers will be allowed to report to duty in a suitable dress from today (May 24) onwards.
 
This decision has been taken after medical specialists pointed out the need to allow the pregnant teaches to wear a suitable dress when they are teaching.
 
At present, there are 172,000 female teachers in the country and of them 10,000 obtain maternity leave each year.

heading: Weather havoc : Train delays reported
description:
Train services have been affected by the prevailing rains.
 
The Railway Main Control Room said that several trains were delayed in the morning due to this.

heading: MP Sanath Nishantha remanded
description:
Puttalam District Parliamentarian Sanath Nishantha and his brother Jagath Samantha Perera were further remanded until 7th of June by the Chilaw High Court today (May 24).
 
They were, accused of assaulting the Divisional Secretary of Arachchikattuwa.

UK Foreign Office destroys files on LTTE and M15 work in Sri Lanka
description:
Britain’s Foreign Office has destroyed almost 200 files on Sri Lanka dating from the start of a Tamil Tiger uprising during which MI5 and the SAS secretly advised the country’s security forces, it has emerged.
 
The loss of the files means that there is almost no record of the British government’s work with the Sri Lankan authorities at the start of a famously brutal civil war.
 
The destruction of the files raises fresh concerns about the Foreign Office’s attitude towards handling historic files on sensitive subjects. An official review in 2012 found that the department had destroyed thousands of documents detailing British counter-insurgency operations in Kenya and other colonies as the empire came to an end.
 
Under the Public Records Act, 1958 government departments are obliged to preserve historical records. But, in response to a Freedom of Information request from the Guardian asking for information about the destruction of the files, the Foreign Office stated that it was not required to preserve the documents. It said the files’ content “may be of a policy nature but might also be administrative or ephemeral”.
 
The Foreign Office has now confirmed that it destroyed 195 files on Sri Lanka, dating from 1978 to 1980, three decades after the country became independent from Britain. The department would not say exactly when, where, or how the destruction occurred.
 
“Files not selected for permanent preservation would have been destroyed offsite by the company contracted by the FCO for this purpose,” it said. “We understand the files would have been destroyed in line with the FCO’s paper and file destruction contract in force at the time.”
 
Rachel Seoighe, a criminologist and Sri Lanka expert, at Middlesex University, said: “This discovery is very concerning given the lack of public information available about British involvement in Sri Lankan security practices at the beginning of the civil war.” She has filed a complaint with Unesco, the international body that protects world heritage.
 
She added: “We know from other contexts, such as Kenya, that official files have been deliberately destroyed to conceal and deny abuse. The public has a right to know the extent to which Britain assisted Sri Lankan preparations for a war that was defined by disappearances, torture and mass atrocity.”
 
The Foreign Office kept a list of file titles, showing that the destroyed papers would have covered a range of important subjects, from security cooperation and arms sales to foreign aid and “requests for political asylum in the UK”.
 
The scale of destruction is such that only three files have survived from 1978, compared to 38 files from the previous year.
 
The loss of these records is a blow for Tamil historians, who struggled to safeguard records throughout the Sri Lankan civil war. The famous Jaffna library was burnt down in 1981 by anti-Tamil groups, incinerating almost 100,000 documents including irreplaceable ancient texts.
 
“The Tamil community is making strenuous efforts to collect and preserve records on history and the human rights situation in post-independence Sri Lanka,” said Vairamuttu Varadakumar, executive secretary of the, in Kingston, London. “We are horrified to learn that the UK’s Foreign Office has destroyed vital information on the British government’s training and arming of Sri Lankan security forces, which were involved in widespread human rights violations against the Tamils.”
 
The Foreign Office claim that the information contained in the files was insignificant has caused dismay among Tamil experts. Varadakumar said: “It is improper for the UK government to deceive the public, who have the right to know. It appears that the Foreign Office’s action is designed to cover up the involvement of the SAS and MI5 in the training of Sri Lankan security forces that might be potentially embarrassing to her majesty’s government.”
 
The Special Air Service visit to Sri Lanka is only mentioned in a handful of surviving files at the National Archives, which were preserved by the Ministry of Defence. Their contents have never been reported on before.
 
One MoD file reveals that late in 1978 Sri Lanka’s right-wing president, Junius Richard Jayewardene asked the Foreign Office for a British security expert to visit his country to help counter Tamil militants who were demanding an independent state of their own. However, a Foreign Office file called Sri Lanka: Security Assessment 1978, which could have shed light on the president’s request, was destroyed.
 
From the surviving defence files, it emerges that an MI5 director, who held racist views, made two advisory visits to Sri Lanka in 1979, under both Jim Callaghan’s Labour government and Margaret Thatcher’s Conservative administration. The full facts of these visits are hard to establish because the Foreign Office destroyed a 1979 file named Sri Lanka: Defence Visits from the UK.
 
The MI5 officer was John Percival Morton CMG OBE, better known as Jack Morton, a former colonial police chief in India who had spied on the independence movement there and once wrote that Indians were “a sort of immature, backward and needy people whom it was the natural British function to govern and administer”. He later became a director at MI5 and held various security positions inside Whitehall.
 
According to a defence file, it was on Morton’s recommendation that a SAS team visited Sri Lanka in 1980 to train a new army commando unit. Among the files destroyed by the Foreign Office was one entitled UK military assistance to Sri Lanka, 1980. The SAS visit occurred weeks after Britain’s premier special forces regiment staged the Iranian embassy siege. For the next four months, the SAS team secretly trained Sri Lankan army commandos, selecting 60 members to form an elite anti-terrorist force.
 
A Foreign and Commonwealth Office spokesperson said: “The FCO, as with all government departments, reviews all its files in line with the requirements of the Public Records Act before making a decision on permanent preservation.
 
“The FCO’s recommendations for the preservation or destruction of records take place under the guidance and supervision of the National Archives. FCO decisions are informed by the National Archive’s records collection policy and existing FCO policy.”
 
(The Guardian)

heading: Attempt to smuggle in cigarettes foiled
description:
A 35-year-old Sri Lankan who arrived from Kuwait this morning (May 24) was apprehended by Customs staff attached to Bandaranaike International Airport, Katunayake as he was attempting to smuggle 150 cartons of foreign cigarettes into the country.
 
30,000 cigarettes were detected and the estimated value was Rs. 1.5 million.
 
The suspect was a resident of Grandpass Colombo.

heading: 68 thousand affected by adverse weather; Rivers still at spill level; Heavy showers forecast from tomorrow again
Maldivian national arrested with 2.39 kilos of heroin
‘Group of 16’ to meet former President
description:
The meeting between the Sri Lanka Freedom Party’s 16 parliamentarians who resigned from the Unity Government will meet former President Mahinda Rajapaksa this afternoon (May 22).
 
It will be held at the former President's official residence, Colombo.
 
MP Chandima Weerakkody said that they are hoping to discuss a number of important political matters during the meeting.

heading: Rains to increase from today;Water levels of Kelani, Kalu, Ging and Attanagalu oya recedes
Group of railway workers to engage in strike action from midnight today
Joy jump ends in misery
description:
A schoolboy who had jumped into Gin Oya in Wennappuwa to enjoy had gone missing.
 
The student, 17-year-old R. Madhura Dilshan was a resident of Miriswatte, Lunuwila and the incident occurred last evening (May 22).
 
He had gone with another group to witness the floods, then suddenly he had jumped into the flood water.
 
An eye-witness said then the student was carried away by flood water.

heading: Services on Kelani-valley rail-line hampered
description:
Services on the Kelani-valley rail-line has been restricted up to Maharagama.
 
The Railway Main Control Room said that that the renovation on the rail track in Kottawa is still underway.
 
An Avissawella bound train derailed in Kottawa last afternoon causing damages to the rail track.

heading: Naval communities warned of sudden increase in wind speed in sea
description:
Met Department says due to the active cloudiness in the sea areas to the North and West of Sri Lanka, showers or thundershowers will occur at times in the sea areas off the coast extending from Galle to Trincomalee via Colombo, Mannar, and Kankasanturai.
 
The possibility for sudden roughness, associated with a sudden increase of wind speed (up to 70-80 kmph) in the sea areas in the above sea area is high.
 
Sea area extending from Puttalam to Pottuvil via Colombo and Hambantota can be rough at times as the wind speed can increase up to 60-70 kmph at times.
 
Naval and fishing communities are requested to be vigilant.

heading: Traffic congestion on Negombo - Colombo road
description:
Police say vehicular movement towards Colombo has been disrupted due to a container accident in Kandana on the Colombo - Negombo road.
Meanwhile, a minor flash flood situation in Tyre Kade Junction on the Ragama – Mahabage road has created a traffic congestion.

heading: Assessor arrested for soliciting a bribe
description:
The officers of the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption have arrested a senior assessor attached to Western Provincial Revenue Department's Kalutara office.
 
He was caught while obtaining the bribe of Rs. 25,000.
 
The suspect had demanded Rs. 27,500 as a bribe initially then he had increased it to Rs. 35,000 to reduce the stamp duties for a new land bought by a resident of Kalutara South.

heading: Rains to enhance from today onwards
description:
Met Department says that the rainy weather prevailing in the country's North-West and Northern districts could further rise from today (May 23) onwards.
 
The Department predicted over 100mm of rains in the Western, Sabaragamuwa, and Central and North-Western provinces as well as in Galle and Matara districts.

heading: Update : One lane of KAduwela Bridge opened
description:
Police say one line of the Kaduwela Bridge has been opened for vehicular traffic.
The bridge was completely blocked for traffic this morning due to heavy soil erosion.
Thereafter, a group of officials had inspected the damage and then decided to open one lane of the bridge.
Police are urging the motorists to use alternative roads.

heading: Southern flu : Another child dies at Karapitiya Hospital
description:
Another small child has died at the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital as a result of the viral flu which is being spread in the Southern region.
 
The Director of Health Services in the Southern Province G. Wijesuriya said that the victim was suffering from a heart ailment from birth.
 
The child who was aged less than one year had been admitted to Karapitiya Teaching Hospital with fever.
 
With this death, 8 children had died at the KTH since April.
 
The Health authorities say altogether 14 persons including 12 children died at the Southern region due to viral fever.
 
Already 400 persons with viral fever are being treated in hospitals in the South and 215 of them are being treated at Karapitiya, Matara and Hambantota hospitals.

heading: TNA objects to President’s nominee for Deputy Leader’s post
description:
United People’s Freedom Alliance MP Angajan Ramanathan has been nominated for the post of Deputy Speaker.
 
It is stated that the President has proposed his name to the Speaker.
 
The Speaker has conveyed the political party leaders during a meeting about the nomination of MP Ramanathan to the new post.
 
However, it is reported that the Tamil National Alliance has objected to the nomination of Ramanathan as the Deputy Speaker.
 
Meanwhile, a TNA MP told us that the party has not taken a decision on the matter.
 
MP M. A. Sumanthiran has objected the nomination in his personal capacity.
 
However, it is reported that the proposal will be further discussed during the next political party leaders meeting.
 
Angajan Ramanathan entered parliament as an SLFP nationalist MP.
 
He is currently functioning as the SLFP chief organizer of the Jaffna district.

heading: Joint Opposition rejects Mangala’s allegation
description:
The Joint Opposition said today (May 23) that former President Mahinda Rajapaksa did not meet Minister Mangala Samaraweera during the last Presidential election.
 
Addressing a media conference in Colombo yesterday, Minister Mangala Samaraweera said that former President Mahinda Rajapaksa visited him during the last Presidential election.

heading: Fonseka says Northern people commemorated war-dead not terrorists
description:
Minister Field Marshal Sarath Fonseka says that the people of the North recently commemorated not the terrorists but the people who died in the war.
 
He said this while speaking to journalists after participating in a ceremony in Kelaniya yesterday (May 22).

heading: 5 arrested at BIA with Rs. 3.9mn worth gold
description:
Sri Lanka Customs says 5 persons were apprehended at the Bandaranaike International Airport today (May 23) while trying to smuggle in Rs. 3.9 million worth of gold.
 
A Sri Lankan with British citizenship was among the suspects arrested.

heading: Health authorities warn ‘viral fever’ could spread further in South
description:
The Health authorities warn that as a result of prevailing rains, there is an increased risk of viral fever which is spreading in the Southern Province, becoming further enhanced.
 
A team of experts from the Borella Medical Research Institute carried out spot checks in Kamburupitiya, Matara, and Karapitiya yesterday (May 21).
 
They will submit a complete report soon.
 
The Southern Province Health Service Director's Office said that currently more than 600 patients are being treated at Karapitiya, Matara, Elpitiya, Kamburupitiya, Tangalla and Walasmulla hospitals.
 
Meanwhile, Southern Province Education Ministry has instructed that all pre-schools be closed from today till 27th this month.
 
It has also been instructed that primary schools in Galle, Matara, Akuressa, Mulatiyana, Tangalle, and Walasmulla educational zones be closed today and tomorrow.

heading: Water levels of Kelani, Kalu, Gin and Ma Oya rising again
description:
The Irrigation Department says that the water levels of the Kelani, Kalu, Gin and Ma Oya are rising again.
 
However, the Department said that the water level of Nilwala and Atthanagalu Oya is now receding.
 
It also urged the people not to venture into reservoirs and rivers until the inclement weather improves.
 
Our correspondent said that flood situation in Kiriella, Ratnapura is further worsening.

heading: Single Tusker electrocuted (Photos)
description:
A wild elephant popularly known as Thani Dalaya (Single Tusker) had died of electrocution in the Thorawil area in Puthukudiiruppu in Mullaitivu.
 
It was found that the jumbo had tangled with a power line laid to protect a cultivated land.

heading: Floods close Kaduwela interchange
description:
The Road Development Authority says that the Kaduwela interchange of the Colombo Outer - Circular Road has been closed due to flooding.
The RDA said that several places in Biyagama have inundated, as a result, the interchange has become impassable.
The vehicles coming from Kadawatha can exit from Athurugiriya while the vehicles arriving from Matara and Galle could exit using the Kotalawela exit.
Meanwhile, Sri Lanka Navy said 38 teams have been deployed to helped the people who are marooned due to flash floods.

heading: Wet weather to continue, people living close to rivers urged to be vigilant
description:
The Met Department says that the prevailing rains and overcast conditions in the South-western part of the island are expected to continue over the next few days.
 
Thunderstorms will periodically occur in the Western, Southern, Sabaragamuwa, Central and North-western provinces.
 
Thunderstorms are predicted elsewhere after 2 pm.
 
Heavy rainfall of above 75 millimeters can be expected in Sabaragamuwa, Western, Central, North-western provinces and in Galle, Matara districts.
 
Duty Meteorologist Buddhika Bandurathna requests the general public to take adequate precautions to minimize damages caused by lightning.
 
Meanwhile, the Department of Irrigation noted that water levels of Kelani and Mahaweli rivers and Ma Oya are currently receding.
 
The Disaster Management Centre stated that those who reside off the banks of Kelani River are advised to evacuate immediately after the river started to overflow last night.
 
In addition, Mahaweli River had reached spill levels around Peradeniya.
 
The irrigation department noted that Ma Oya was also overflowing around Giriulla.
 
The Director of Water Management at the DMC noted that the water levels of Kalu, Gin, and Attanagalu Oya are currently receding.
 
In addition, the Mahaweli Authority noted that 7 sluice gates of Polgolla reservoir remain open.

heading: Body found in Papiliyana canal (Photos)
description:
An unidentified body was recovered from a canal in Papiliyana this morning (May 22).
 
It was floating in the canal and an area resident had alerted the police about the gruesome find.

heading: Bus unions win, fares increased by 12.5%
description:
The Cabinet has granted its approval to increase bus fares by 12.5%.
 
Accordingly, the minimum fare will also be increased to Rs.12.
 
The Deputy Minister Nishantha Muthuhettigama confirmed this and he said that the new bus fares are effective from midnight today (May 22).
 
The proposal to increase the bus fare by 12.5 percent was presented to the Cabinet today.
 
The bus unions agreed for this bus fare revision during a discussion with the Deputy Transport Minister Ashok Abeysinghe on 16th of this month.
 
Consequent to this, the strike that was due to be launched on 17th was suspended.
 
However, All Island Private Bus Union Federation President Stanley Fernando earlier warned that if the Cabinet failed to approve the 12.5 percent bus fare increase, the federation will launch a strike action. 
 
We also inquired about this from Lanka Private Bus Owners' Association President Gemunu Wijeratne who said that he would refrain from expressing his views on the matter.
 
However, he had earlier said that according to the national policy, the bus fare could be raised only by 9 or 10 percent.

heading: Ex-Chief of Staff of President & Ex-STC Chairman remanded
description:
President's former Chief of Staff and former Chairman of the State Timber Corporation who were arrested while accepting a bribe of Rs. 20 million from an Indian investor were further remanded till 5
 of June.

heading: Gold smugglers arrested at BIA
description:
Four Sri Lankan passengers arrived from Dubai this morning (May 22) have been apprehended by Sri Lanka Customs staff attached to the Bandaranaike International Airport, Katunayake while they were attempting to smuggle in 448.862g of gold into the country.
 
The suspected passengers were aged between 39, 45, 38 and 44 years and residents from Colombo and Kegalle.
 
The estimated value of gold was Rs. 2.6 million.

heading: Heavy rains in excess of 150mm predicted
description:
Met Department says that heavy falls of about 150 mm can be expected at some places in  Sabaragamuwa, Western, Central, North-western provinces and in Galle, Matara districts.
 
Prevailing rainy condition along with cloudy skies in the Southwestern part of the island is expected to continue further during next few days.
 
Showers or thundershowers will occur at times in Western, Southern, Sabaragamuwa, Central and North-western provinces.

heading: 37 injured in Kahawatta bus accident
description:
Police say 37 persons were injured when 2 private buses collided head-on in Kahawatte, Ratnapura at around 11.35 am today (May 22).
One of the buses was plying from Embilipitiya to Kegalle while the other bus was heading towards Makandura from Kahawatte.
Two drivers also sustained injuries.
21 women and 16 men injured in the mishap and the condition of 2 men were serious.

heading: IP Rangajeewa & Prisons’ Commissioner Lamahewa remanded
description:
Inspector of Police Neomal Rangajeewa and Prisons’ Commissioner Emil Ranjan Lamahewa have been further remanded until 5
 of June.
 
They are in remand custody over the Welikada Prison riots occurred in November 2012.
 
27 inmates were killed in the incident.

heading: Rains to continue, Ratnapura worst affected
description:
The Met Department says that the prevailing rainy condition along with cloudy skies in the Southwestern part of the island is expected to continue further during next few days.
 
Showers or thundershowers will occur at times in Western, Southern, Sabaragamuwa, Central and North-western provinces.
 
Showers or thundershowers will occur elsewhere particularly after 2.00 p.m.
 
Heavy falls, about 150 mm can be expected at some places in Sabaragamuwa, Western, Central, North-western provinces and in Galle, Matara districts.
 
Meanwhile, Kurunegala had recorded the highest rainfall of 194.8mm during the 24 hours ended at 8.30 am today (May 22).
 
Approximately 38,000 persons from around 10,000 families in 12 districts have been affected by prevailing inclement weather.
 
The Disaster Management Center said that the death toll stands at 8.
 
Meanwhile, landslide warnings remain in effect in Kalutara, Ratnapura, Kegalle, Nuwara Eliya, and Galle districts.
 
The Irrigation Department states that the water levels of Kelani, Kalu, and Gin rivers, as well as the Ma Oya, are on the rise once again.
 
The Department noted that water levels of Nilwala and Attanagalu Oya are now receding.
 
However, the Department requests the public refrain from approaching these rivers for the next several days.
 
Meanwhile, Puttalam and Anamaduwa are experiencing floods as all 8 sluice gates of Deduru Oya have been opened.
 
Last night’s floods resulted in most small tanks in the area to overflow and traffic on many roads were curtailed.
 
Meanwhile, the Railway Control Room announced that train services on the Puttalam line have been limited to Lunuwila due to overflowing of Hamilton Canal.

heading: Aerial view of flood-affected Ratnapura
description:
The Disaster Management Center says Ratnapura is the worst affected areas due to the prevailing inclement weather.
 
A team from the Hiru News visited the area in an Air Force flight to have a look at the destruction.

heading: GMOA meets President to discuss Singapore FTA
description:
The Government Medical Officers' Association is planning to meet President Maithripala Sirisena this afternoon (May 22).
The Sri Lanka - Singapore Free Trade Agreement is the topic of the discussion.

heading: Over 50,000 affected by bad weather (Photos)
description:
Over 50,000 persons from around 14,000 families in 11 districts have been affected by prevailing inclement weather.
 
The Disaster Management Center said that the death toll stands at 8.
 
Meanwhile, landslide warnings remain in effect in Kalutara, Ratnapura, Kegalle, Nuwara Eliya, and Galle districts.
 
The Irrigation Department states that the water levels of Kelani, Kalu, and Gin rivers, as well as the Ma Oya, are on the rise once again.
 
The Department noted that water levels of Nilwala and Attanagalu Oya are now receding.
 
However, the Department requests the public refrain from approaching these rivers for the next several days.
 
Meanwhile, Puttalam and Anamaduwa are experiencing floods as all 8 sluice gates of Deduru Oya have been opened.
 
Last night’s floods resulted in most small tanks in the area overflowing and traffic on many roads was blocked.
 
Meanwhile, the Railway Control Room announced that train services on the Puttalam line have been limited to Lunuwila due to overflowing of Hamilton Canal.
 
Special joint rescue operations have been launched by the Navy, Army and the Air Force together with the Disaster Management Center.
 
The Army Media spokesman, Brigadier Sumith Atapattu said that extra troops have been deployed in the Ratnapura and Kalutara districts.

heading: Inclement weather : One person missing in Hiniduma
description:
Navy divers with the assistance of police have launched a search operation in Hiniduma after an individual was carried away by flash floods.
 
Police said that missing person had attempted to catch fish using a net when he was carried away by the force of the rising water.
 
The missing person was a resident of Habarakada.
 
Meanwhile, due to rising water level in the Kelani River, Hanwella - Nittambuwa road has inundated from Pugoda.
 
Our correspondent said the vehicular movement has affected as a result and the water level has risen up to 2 feet.
 
The Disaster Management Center said 17 houses in the Kandy area have damaged due to bad weather in the area.

heading: Minor landslide in Hatton, traffic affected
description:
The traffic on the Colombo - Hatton main road has affected due to a minor landslide in the Diyagala area in Ginigathhena.
 
Our correspondent said that the protective wall has also collapsed.
 
Meanwhile, the Disaster Management Center said that the water level in main rivers is rising as a result of the inclement weather.
 
Accordingly, people living in the low-lying areas close to Kalu, Gin, Nilwala rivers and Aththanagalu and Maa Oya are urged to be vigilant.
 
 
Meanwhile, Navy divers with the assistance of police have launched a search operation in Hiniduma after an individual was carried away by flash floods.
 
Police said that missing person had attempted to catch fish using a net when he was carried away by the force of the rising water.
 
The missing person was a resident of Habarakada.
 
Meanwhile, due to rising water level in the Kelani River, Hanwella - Nittambuwa road has inundated from Pugoda.
 
Our correspondent said the vehicular movement has affected as a result and the water level has risen up to 2 feet.
 
The Disaster Management Center said 17 houses in the Kandy area has damaged due to bad weather in the area.

heading: Weather chaos Death toll risen to nine
Farmers to be relieved of insurance payment of Rs. 1350
description:
The government has decided not to charge Rs. 1350 from farmers for the agri-insurance scheme.
 
Addressing a media conference in Colombo today (May 21), Minister Mahinda Amaraweera said from this season, each acre of cultivated land will be insured by Rs. 40,000.

heading: Attempt to smuggle in cigarettes and phones foiled
description:
Sri Lanka Customs Unit at the Bandaranaike International Airport this morning (May 21) arrested 3 passengers arrived from Dubai with 165 cartons of cigarettes of a foreign brand and 35 mobile phones.
 
The value of the cigarettes was Rs. 1.6 million while the estimated value of the mobile phone was Rs. 200,000.
 
The contraband was forfeited and the suspects, residents of Kurunegala were released after imposing a fine of Rs. 190,000.

heading: President orders speedy assistance to disaster-affected people
description:
President Maithripala Sirisena has instructed officials to take measures to provide adequate relief supplies to disaster-affected people without considering allocations.
The relevant instructions have been conveyed to District Secretaries and Divisional Secretaries.
The Disaster Management Center said 12 districts are affected by the prevailing inclement weather.
The DMC said 13,314 persons belonging to 3438 families are affected by bad weather.
The death toll has meanwhile risen to 7.
The Navy divers recovered the body of a person who went missing after he was carried away while trying to catch fish in the Gin River.
Over the last 2 days, 4 persons were killed in lighting and 2 had died of landslides.

heading: People living nearby Mahaweli River cautioned
description:
Mahaweli Authority says seven spill gates of Polgolla reservoir have been opened.
 
The people who are living close to the bank of Mahaweli River are cautioned.

heading: Southern preschools closed until next Monday
description:
All preschools in the Southern province will be closed from tomorrow, until 27
 of May.
 
The Southern Provincial Education Ministry said the decision was taken due to infectious fever epidemic spreading in the area.
 
The health authorities said that 13 persons including 11 children have so far died of the disease.
Meanwhile, a group of experts has been sent to South by the Ministry of Health to probe and advise remedial action to contain the spread of the viral flu.
It is suspected the flu is spread by adino and influenza viruses.

heading: Water levels rising, warned of floods
description:
Water levels in Ging, Kalu, Kelani rivers and Atthanagalu Oya are close to major flood level.
 
The Department of Irrigation urged the people living nearby the river banks to be vigilant.

heading: Colombo – Hatton road blocked by landslide (Photos)
description:
The traffic on the Hatton - Colombo road has stalled due to a landslide in Diyagala.
An early mound collapsed this afternoon when a group of Road Development Authority workers was attending to a soil bank after it was identified as an area prone to a landslide.
With that, the road was completely blocked.
Police urged the motorists to use alternative roads as Hatton-Colombo, Hatton-Kandy, Hatton-Ginigathhena, and Hatton-Laxapana roads are prone to landslides.

heading: 5 persons arrested with arms & ammunition in Ambepussa
description:
Police have arrested 5 persons, members of a criminal gang, in Ambepussa following a tip-off while they were on their way to kidnap a person and kill him.
 
They were arrested last night (May 20), while they were travelling by a van.
 
The suspects are residents of Nawagampura in Ampara, Rathgama in Galle, Walpola in Angoda, Asillawatte in Borukgamuwa and Pitawalawatte in Bopitiya.
 
Police also found 2 revolvers, 11 ammunition, 2 knives and 42.7g of heroin.
 
It was also revealed that the suspects were planning to abduct a resident of Lenagala in Warakapola after breaking into a house.
 
Few of those suspects are wanted criminals, the police said.

heading: Kelani water level risen to a flood situation, people urged to evacuate
description:
The Department of Meteorology forecasts more thundershowers in many areas during the next few days due to the existing turbulence in the atmosphere.
The Department said that heavy rain over 150 millimeters could be expected tonight as well in the areas of the Central, Sabaragamuwa, Western, Wayamba and the districts of Galle, Matara, and Hambantota.
At the same time, the National Building Research Organization has issued landslide warnings on 11 districts including, Ratnapura, Kegalle, Kalutara, Nuwara Eliya, Kandy, Badulla, Matale, Galle, Kurunegala, Gampaha, and Colombo.
Addressing a media conference in Colombo today (May 21), Director General of the Organization, Dr. Asiri Karunawardana said red alerts have been issued for 4 divisional secretariat divisions in the Ratnapura district.
He said some areas in the Kandy and Kegalle districts are also prone to landslides.
Meanwhile, the rivers of Kalu, Kelani, Gin and Attanagalu Oya have reached spill level thereby increasing the threat of imminent floods in the area.
The Director of the Irrigation Department, Mala Alawathugoda said that the River Mahaweli also has reached minor flood levels.
At the same time, sluice gates of several hydropower reservoirs such as Laxapana, Upper Kotmale, Kukuleganga, Polgolla and Deduru Oya have been opened due to heavy rain in catchment areas.
In addition, traffic on several main roads such as Hatton-Colombo, Matara-Akuressa have been disrupted due to floods.
Meanwhile, Acting Director General of the Meteorology Department, Athula Karunanayake told our news team that more rain could be expected after tomorrow.
The death toll of the impact of the existing inclement weather has risen to 8.
The body of a person who washed away by currents while fishing in Gin River was recovered by Navy divers and the Disaster Management Center officers this afternoon.
The Disaster Management Center requests people to be cautious during thundershowers and to avoid visiting flood-affected sites.
It further stated that 12 districts have been hit by the adverse weather thereby affecting 13,485 persons of 3495 families.
Among the most affected districts are Galle, Matara, Kalutara, and Ratnapura.
Meanwhile, Army Media Spokesperson Brigadier 
Atapattu stated that the tri-forces are always ready to assist the people on every necessary occasion.
In addition, Police Media Spokesperson SP Ruwan Gunasekara stated that disaster operations 
have been established in all police stations across the island.
Meanwhile, Education Minister, Akila Viraj Kariyawasam said that authority has been vested with zonal education directors and school principals whether to close the schools due to rain.
Accordingly, schools in Ratnapura, Nivitigala and Dehiovita educational zones of the Sabaragamuwa Province were closed today and they will be kept closed tomorrow as well.
In addition, several schools in Akuressa, Panadugama, and Athuraliye in the Matara district were also closed today due to heavy rain.
The Disaster Management Centre has advised people living close to the Kelani river bank to evacuate to safer areas as the water level in the Kelani river has risen to flood level.
President Maithripala Sirisena has instructed the authorities to provide immediate relief to the flood affected masses.
He has informed the district secretaries and divisional secretaries not to consider of set allocations.
At the same time, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe has also instructed authorities to make full commitments when providing relief to the affected.
In addition, Disaster Management Minister, Duminda Dissanayake told our news team everything has been planned already to provide relief to the needy.

heading: Mahaweli reaching to spill level
Electricity disconnected in several areas of Ratnapura
description: Ceylon Electricity Board says due to the prevailing threats of floods, electricity connection to Ehaliyagoda, Kuruwita, Kiriella

heading: Landslide 'Alert' issued for several districts
description:
The National Building Research Organization has issued an 'Alert' for possible landslides in several districts of the island.
 
The Director-General of the NBRO said the people living in the landslide-prone areas of Nuwara Eliya, Kegalle, Ratnapura, Kalutara and Kandy

heading: Over 9800 families affected by inclement weather
description:
The Disaster Management Center says around 38,040 persons of 9815 families are affected by inclement weather.
There were 8 deaths in weather-related incidents.














Being struck by lightning, buried in earth mounds, drowning and hit by falling trees have been noted as the various causes of those deaths.
 It has been reported that 19 houses have been completely damaged and 918 houses have been partially damaged owing to strong winds.
The Disaster Management Center said that measures have been taken to provide immediate relief to all individuals impacted by the adverse weather conditions.
The tri-forces are kept on call to assist with providing relief to those affected.
The Army Media Spokesperson Brigadier Sumith Atapattu noted that army troops and navy boats have been deployed in Kalutara, Ratnapura, Galle and Matara districts for relief missions.
The National Building Research Organization have issued landslide warnings for 11 districts including, Ratnapura, Kegalle, Kalutara, Nuwara Eliya, Kandy, Badulla, Matale, Galle, Kurunegala, Gampaha, and Colombo.

heading: Colombo - Puttalam train services affected
description:
The Railway Control Room says train services on the Puttalam line has been restricted to Lunuwila.
 
It said that the railway track between Naththandiya and Thummodera is inundated due to the overflowing of Hamilton Canal.
Because of that office trains had begun journeys from the Lunuwila station.

heading: 3 youths arrested for breaking into a petrol shed
description:
Police have arrested 3 suspects who had broken into a petrol shed on the Beliatte - Walasmulla road.
 
The suspects who had stolen Rs. 650,000 from the shed were arrested yesterday (May 21) in the Kambussawa area in Beliatte.
 
The suspects aged between 18 and 19 years are residents of Beliatte.
 
Police found Rs. 25,150 and a mobile phone worth Rs. 30,000 from the suspects.
 
They will be produced before Tangalle Magistrate today.

heading: Johann Peries becomes 2nd Sri Lanka to reach Mt. Everest summit (Photos)
description:
Johann Peries has successfully reached 29,030ft Mt. Everest by becoming the second Sri Lankan to reach the summit, Everest.
 
Jayanthi Kuru Utumpala reached the world's highest summit in 2016.
 
Although Johann was with Jayanthi when she was climbing the mountain, he became distressed with just 448m to reach the top.

heading: Joint Opposition seeks a debate on disaster situation
description:
The Joint opposition has requested the Speaker to cancel the scheduled Parliament debate today (May 22), and hold a special debate regarding the current disaster situation.
 
When we contacted, the JO Parliamentary Group leader MP Dinesh Gunawardena disclosed this.
 
Meanwhile the leader of the Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna, MP Anura Kumara Dissanayake said that the proposed 20th amendment to the constitution will be handed over to the Parliament on another date.

heading: 12.5% bus fare increase to be submitted to Cabinet
description:
The proposal to increase the bus fare by 12.5 percent will be presented to the Cabinet today (May 22).
 
The bus unions agreed for this bus fare revision during a discussion with the Deputy Transport Minister Ashok Abeysinghe on 16
 of this month.
 
Consequent to this, the strike that was due to be launched on 17th was suspended.
 
However, All Island Private Bus Union Federation President Stanley Fernando said that if the Cabinet failed to approve the 12.5 percent bus fare increase, the federation will launch a strike action. 
 
We inquired about this from Lanka Private Bus Owners' Association President Gemunu Wijeratne who said that he would refrain from expressing his views on the matter.
 
However, he had earlier said that according to the national policy, the bus fare could be raised only by 9 or 10 percent.

heading: Drivers using expressways urged to be cautious
description:
The Road Development Authority is advising the motorists using the expressways to be cautious.
 
It said it is advisable to keep the speed below 60 KMPH to avoid mishaps.
 
The RDA also asked the drivers to keep the headlights on during raining.

heading: MR highlights potential risks
description:
Former President Mahinda Rajapaksa says that Sri Lanka is heading for a dangerous situation in the country in the name of reconciliation.
The former President said this addressing a commemoration ceremony held at the Dakshinaramaya in Hokandara yesterday (May 19). 
He added that the masses are fully aware of the country's political and economic situation.
 
Former Defense Secretary, Gotabaya Rajapaksa too had taken part in the commemoration.
He said allowing to commemorate terrorists is not reconciliation.

heading: Protests held against Minister Rajitha’s statement
description:
A number of protests were held against the statement made by Minister Rajitha Senarathne alleging that the government had no objections for North holding a day of mourning over the death of LTTE leader Prabhakaran.
 
Members of the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna in Hingurakgoda and Elahera Pradeshiya Sabhas engaged in protests against the statements made by Minister Senarathne.
 
Following the religious ceremonies, they staged a protest and dashed coconuts and also burnt effigies of Minister Senarathne.
 
Furthermore, protests were held against Minister Senarathne in Chilaw and in Beruwala.

heading: Flashfloods disrupt vehicle movement
description: Police say vehicular movements have affected as flash floods have inundated the Avissawella - Kegalle main road in Thalduwa.

heading: Low-pressure zone develops over Sri Lanka
description:
