The Met Department says that heavy showers will continue for the next few days due to the South Western Monsoon and the formation of a low-pressure zone over Sri Lanka.
 
3 persons including a female were killed due to inclement weather during the last 24 hours.
 
The Disaster Management Centre said that a female had died in the Badalkumbura area in Moneragala as a tree had fallen on to her.
 
Meanwhile, 2 persons were killed by lightning in the Welikanda area in Polonnaruwa.
 
They were at a paddy field when the tragedy struck.
 
Meanwhile, our correspondents said that power disruptions are reported in Kegalle, Rambukkana, Mathugama, and Agalawatte due to trees falling on power lines as a result of incessant rains.

heading: Mangala accuses Rajapaksa brothers of trying to throw country again into “Vipath Maga”
description:
Minister of Finance and Media Mangala Samaraweera in a media statement charges that former President and Kurunegala District MP, Mahindra Rajapaksa and former Defence Secretary Gotabhaya Rajapaksa now seem to be engaged in an untiring effort to throw the country again into “Vipath Maga”, the destructive path.
 
He said the former President is responsible for ruining the country by allowing his family relatives and cronies to plunder the country’s economy.
 
He accused that his siblings, former defense secretary Gotabhaya Rajapaksa who unleashed terror through the white van culture that isolated the country internationally.
 
The Finance Minister charged that Gotabhaya Rajapaksa who invented white van terror in Sri Lanka that attracted world attention has said recently that the rulers and the public officials should be free of corruption.
 
Samaraweera pointed out that the economy during the previous government, handled by their cronies and henchmen didn’t have any proper system in place to implement the economic development in a manner that would bring direct benefits to the people.
 
He said, “The Rajapaksa siblings who ruled this country under such a background have been attempting to regain power by throwing the people into “Vipath Maga” the destructive path. Therefore we urge the people to defeat such attempts and rally round the Government’s agenda to build a strong economy and a rich country by the year 2025”.

heading: Death toll in weather-related incidents risen to 4
description:
The Met Department says that thundershowers can be expected in the next few days as well, as the South Western monsoon forms over the island.
 
The Department noted that heavy showers exceeding 100 mm can be expected tonight in the Sabaragamuwa, Western, Central and Uva provinces as well as in Galle and Matara districts.
 
4 people have died from lightning strikes and storms thus far.
 
A female monk was killed this afternoon after being struck by lightning while she was at a meditation center in Hegalawaththa in Horana.
 
Police said that another female clergy who sustained critical injuries was admitted to Horana Base Hospital for treatment.
 
Furthermore, two individuals in Welikanda in Polonnaruwa died after having struck by lightning yesterday, while they were at a paddy field.
 
The Disaster Management Centre noted that a woman in Badalkumbura – Monaragala died after a branch of a tree fell onto her.
 
A landslide warning has been issued to 8 districts in view of the prevailing rainy weather conditions.
 
The Disaster Management Centre noted that the landslide warning was issued to Kalutara, Kegalle, Ratnapura, Nuwara Eliya, Badulla, Galle, Kurunegala and Colombo districts.
 
Meanwhile, a house in Ambalangoda has been damaged after a soil embankment collapsed onto it.
 
Police stated that three individuals who had been inside the house have escaped unhurt. 
 
The water levels in Kalu and Gin rivers have risen due to the heavy rainfall received.
 
The Department of Irrigation urged those living in the divisional secretariat areas of Madurawala, Horana, Bulathsinhala, Ingiriya, and Palindanuwara to be vigilant as the Kalu River has reached its spillover level in Millakanda area.
 
The Department further noted that Baddegama, Bope, Poddala, Nagoda, Niyagama, Thawalama and Neluwa areas are also at risk as the water level in Gin River has reached its spillover level.
 
Additionally, the water level in Aththanagalu Oya too has risen.
 
Furthermore, two spill gates of Laxapana reservoir has been opened due to the heavy rainfall prevailing in the Central province.
 
The Disaster Management Centre noted that spill gates of Deduru Oya and Udawalawa reservoirs too remain to be kept open.
 
Roads in many areas have inundated due to the heavy rainfall.
 
The Disaster Management Centre noted that many byroads in Colombo and Gampaha district have flooded.
 
Meanwhile, the Road Development Authority urges motorists to limit their speeds to a maximum of 60 KMPH when using expressways. 
 
Police Media Spokesperson, SP Ruwan Gunasekara stated that 6 accidents have occurred on the expressways today (May 20).
 
Meanwhile, power supply to Thulhiriya, Rambukkana and Kegalle areas were disrupted this afternoon due to a technical fault in the transmission line between Polpitiya and Athurugiriya.
 
The Ministry of Power and Renewable Energy stated that measures are being taken to restore power supply to the areas.
 
Further, the power supply to Kurunegala, Matugama, Horana and Agalawaththa areas also have interrupted.
 
Meanwhile, Army Spokesman, Brigadier Sumith Atapattu stated that the army is prepared to provide assistance to the disaster-stricken areas.
 
The spokesman stated that the Army will constantly be monitoring the situation of the areas receiving heavy rainfall, with the Disaster Management Center.

heading: Earth slip kills one person in Bulathkohupitiya
description:
One person was killed when an earth mound collapsed on a house in Undugoda in Bulathkohupitiya.
 
The incident had taken place at around 8 pm yesterday (May 20).
 
The victim, a 40-year-old person was alone inside the house, at the time of the incident.

heading: Inclement weather leaves 5 dead, landslide warnings continue in  5 districts (Photos)
Gotabhaya responds to government's charges
description:
Former Defence Secretary Gotabhaya Rajapaksa says that the country needs the politicians who can work and deliver.
 
He said this in response to a media statement by Minister Mangala Samaraweera who accused that Rajapaksas are trying to regain power to take the country towards a "Wipath Maga".
 
The former Defence Secretary expressed his views addressing a forum in Badulla yesterday (May 20).

heading: "Cannot agree with Rajitha's statement" - says UPFA Gen. Sec.
description:
The General Secretary of the United People's Freedom Alliance, Minister Mahinda Amaraweera says that he cannot agree with the recent statement made by Minister Rajitha Senaratne on having a day of mourning in the North to commemorate the war dead.
 
Mahinda Amaraweera said this following a visit to Kundasale Agri School yesterday (May 20).

heading: Health authorities step up disease control in South
description:
Research is being carried out to determine if, in addition to the spread of the Influenza virus, the virus, Adino is also spreading in the Southern province.
 
As a result of the viral infections coupled with bacterial attacks 13 persons including 11 children, have died in the South so far.
 
The Director of the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital Dr. Jayampathi  Senanayake told our news team that the number of viral infected patients who are being admitted to the hospital has decreased notably.

heading: Provincial authorities given powers to decide on schools
description:
Minister of Education, Akila Viraj Kariyawasam says that the provincial education directors and principals are given authority to decide on the schools in the districts that are affected by inclement weather.
 
Already the authorities have decided to close the schools in the Ratnapura. Nivithigala and Dehiowita divisions.
 
With continuous rains, most of the waterfalls in the hill country have become active.
 
People are urged to stay away from downstream tributaries and rivers.
 
Due to rising water level in the Kala Oya, the Puttalam - Mannar main road has been flooded in Eluwankulama by around 2 1/2 foot.

heading: Water level in Kelani River rising
description:
There is a possibility that the tributaries of Kelani River overflowing as water levels are surging.
 
The Department of Irrigation warns people in risky areas to be vigilant.
 
Meanwhile, 3 spill gates in Kukuleganga reservoir are opened and Disaster Management Center is urging the people at downstream to be vigilant.
Several roads in the Galle district are reportedly underwater. Elpitiya - Aluthgama road is underwater from the Miriswatte area.

heading: NBRO issues Red Alert for Palinda Nuwara
description:
The National Building Research Organization has issued 'Red Alert' for Palinda Nuwara area in Kalutara district for possible landslides.
 
The Disaster Management Center alerted the people who are living close to landslide-prone areas to be vigilant.

heading: Sri Lankan youth killed in London knife attack
description:
Arunesh Thangarajah, 28, a Sri Lankan born person had been knifed to death on south-west London street last morning.
 
Thangarajah was found suffering from stab wounds in Mitcham in the early hours of Sunday (May 20).
 
Emergency services raced to the area of Upper Green East near Montrose Gardens and London Road shortly before 3.30am.
 
Police and paramedics fought to save him, but he was pronounced dead at the scene.
 
Scotland Yard said a murder probe has been launched by detectives from the Homicide and Major Crime Command.
 
Police have informed the man's next of kin, and a post-mortem examination will be arranged.
 
A 44-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of murder. He has been taken to a south London police station where he remained in custody on Sunday night.

heading: Inter-provincial bus union threatens to strike
description:
The Inter-Provincial Private Bus Owners’ Association says that they will launch a strike action from midnight on Wednesday (May 23) if the government fails to increase bus fares by 12.5 percent as it had pledged.
However, Lanka Private Bus Owners’ Association notes that bus fares can only be revised by 9 or 10 percent as per the National Policy on the revision of bus fares.
The association notes that the policy, which is based on 12 factors, has been formulated in a manner that both passengers and bus owners are protected.
The President of the Lanka Private Bus Owners’ Association, Gemunu Wijerathna said that considering the hike in diesel prices and other factors, bus fares should only be revised by 9 or 10 percent.

heading: SLFP can take any decision - Minister Madduma Bandara
description:
The Minister of Law and Order Ranjith Madduma Bandara says that the Sri Lanka Freedom Party can take any decision and the United National Party can govern the country alone.
 
The Minister said this responding to journalists following an event in Badalkumbura in Monaragala yesterday (May 20).

heading: Tri-forces personnel awarded for service excellence
Diyaluma waterfall becomes alive
description:
Due to the continuous rains prevailing in the Central hills, Rawana falls, Diyaluma falls and Dunhinda falls have become active.
 
In this context, the Disaster Management Center and police urged the visitors not to get closer those water streams.
 
The DMC also said the water level of Kirindi Oya which is fed by the Rawana falls has risen, and people are urged to be vigilant of that.
 
Meanwhile, our correspondent captured the beauty of Diyaluma waterfall which has become alive due to prevailing rainy weather in the area.

heading: Eelam faction launches cyber-attack on Govt. websites
description:
Several Sri Lankan websites including the website of the Ministry of Tourism Development and Christian Religious Affairs have been hit by a cyber-attack.
 
The websites have been hacked by a group identified as Tamil Eelam Cyber Force.
 
The group has hacked the official website of the Ministry of Tourism and that of the Sri Lankan Embassy in Kerala, India. 
 
The group in the websites has published announcements that the Sri Lankan tri forces massacred Tamil nationals in Vellamulliwaikkal during the fourth Eelam war.
 
When we inquired in this regard from the Minister of Tourism Development, John Amarathunga, he stated that measures were taken to rectify the issue immediately once they were made aware of the situation.
 
The Minister further stated that an investigation into the incident will be carried out on Monday.
Meanwhile, it was reported that the official website of the Batticaloa Urban Council also was hacked by the group.

heading: President says some don’t know ‘difference’ of war heroes and terrorists
description:
President Maithripala Sirisena says that certain members of the government, opposition, and non-governmental organizations cannot comprehend the difference between war heroes and terrorists.
 
The President made these comments at the Commemoration of National War Heroes held at the War Heroes' Memorial in Parliament Grounds, Kotte.
 
Many invitees including the Speaker, commanders of the tri-forces as well as the relatives of the war-heroes took part in the commemoration.
 
After the President arrived the National anthem was sung following which the ceremony began.
 
2 minutes of silence was held as a mark of respect to war heroes who laid down their lives for the country, following which the President addressed the gathering.
Here, he said that he will never allow the wishes of LTTE supporters to be fulfilled.

heading: True reality TV experience “Hiru Star” begins
description:
Hiru TV, Sri Lanka leading television channel is now bringing to its loyal viewers another reality show of international quality.
 
The stage is ready to commence 'Hiru Star' and up and coming singers from all over the country are getting ready to take part in this show.
 
The live reality TV show will be aired on Saturdays and Sundays from today onwards
 
The viewers can vote their favourite singer through the 'Hiru Star App'.
 
The viewers should upload the app to be eligible to vote.
You can download the app

heading: Lightning kills 2 in Welikanda
description:
Police say 2 persons were killed in lightning in Welikanda last evening (May 19).
They were in a paddy field at the time of the tragedy.
The victims aged 33 and 17 are residents of Magulpokuna, Welikanda.

heading: Discussion between ‘Group of 16’ and Mahinda, postponed
description:
The proposed discussion between the ‘Group of 16’ SLFP’ers who left the government and former President Mahinda Rajapaksa has been postponed to 23
 of this month.
 
The decision has been taken as many MPs of the group are currently out of Colombo.
 
Parliamentarian Lakshman Yapa Abewardana told our news team that the discussion will be held at 5 pm on 23rd.

heading: Fever in South : Over 50 children being treated in Kamburupitiya
description:
The health authorities are taking measures to containing the influenza virus which is spreading in the Southern Province.
 
So far around 13 deaths are reported and 11 of them were children.
 
Now new cases are reported from Matara, the health authorities said.
 
It was reported that 0ver 50 children are being treated in-house at the Kamburupitiya Base Hospital.
 
Earlier, 5 children died at the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital and 3 of them were affected by influenza and other 2 had infected with Adino virus and pneumococcal bacteria.
 
So far blood samples of 84 persons have been sent to Medical Research Institute in Borella for testing and 27 of those have been infected with influenza along with Adino virus and pneumococcal bacteria.
 
The health authorities say pregnant mothers and small children are more prone to this disease.
 
They urge the public to seek medical advice if fever persists more than one day.

heading: Cultural Minister advices Wigneshwaran to act responsibly
description:
Minister of Higher Education and Cultural Affairs Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe says that the irresponsible behaviour of the Northern Province Chief Minister causes disharmony among communities.
 
The Minister expressed these views at an event in Vavuniya yesterday.

heading: A warning from fishermen
description:
The fishing community says they would resort to a strike action if kerosene oil subsidy to distribute in a proper manner.
 
The Pitipana Fisheries Collective says the fishermen are greatly inconvenienced by the hike of fuel prices.
 
However, when contacted the Secretary to the Ministry of Petroleum Resource Development, Upali Marasinghe said steps have been taken to provide subsidized kerosene oil to the fishermen.

heading: Ready for any election says MR
description:
Former President Mahinda Rajapaksa says they are ready for any future election.
He said this responding to journalists following a war heroes commemoration at his official residence in Colombo, yesterday (May 19).

heading: UPFA Gen. Sec. says there won’t be major changes in positions
description:
Minister Mahinda Amaraweera says that only a few positions of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party will see some changes at the forthcoming Central Committee meeting.
 
The Minister addressing a media briefing in Kandy yesterday said that positions of the UPFA cannot be changed at an SLFP meeting.

heading: Non-academics of schools threaten to strike
description:
The Union of Education Non-academic employees threatens to launch a strike if issues relating to non-academic cadre categories are not solved within 21 days.
 
The union said the issue has cropped up by amalgamating 8 other positions to the category of KKS.

heading: Showers, lightning and winds to increase, Seas will be rough
description:
The Met Department said that Southwest monsoon conditions are getting established over the island.
 
Prevailing rainy conditions in the South-west part of the island is expected to enhance today (May 20).
 
Showers or thundershowers will occur at times in Western, Southern, Sabaragamuwa, Central and North-western provinces.
 
Very heavy falls, above 150 mm can be expected at some places in Sabaragamuwa province.
 
Meanwhile, windy conditions in the sea areas around the island and showery condition in the sea area to the South-west of the island are expected to enhance today.
 
Sea area extending from Puttalam to Kankasanthurai via Mannar and from Matara to Potuvil via Hambantota can be rough at times as the wind speed can increase up to 60 kmph.

heading: Immigration & Emigration officers suspend TU campaign
description:
The Immigration and Emigration Officers' Association has suspended their work-to-rule campaign carried out at the Bandaranaike International Airport.
 
They had agreed to suspend the trade union action after a discussion with Minister S. B. Navinna, who had agreed to address the issues raised by the union.
 
The Minister had agreed to submit a Cabinet paper on the demands cited by the union.
 
They urged the authorities to draft a service minute for them.
 
The activities of the BIA affected since last night as a result of the work-to-rule campaign launched by them.

heading: 595 SI's promoted
description:
National Police Commission has promoted 595 Sub Inspectors including 56 Women Sub Inspectors to the rank of Inspector of Police.
 
The promotions are effective from 31st of May.
 
The Police Media Division said that the promotions were recommended by IGP Pujith Jayasundara.

heading: Reservoirs reach spill levels, public urged to be vigilant
description:
The Met Department says that many parts of the island could experience heavy rainfall in the coming few hours.
 
It said Central, Sabaragamuwa, Uva, Western, and North-Western provinces as well as Amparai, Batticaloa, Galle and Matara districts will experience heavy rainfall exceeding 100mm.
 
The Irrigation Department announced that one sluice gate of the Udawalawa Reservoir has been opened due to persistent rains.
 
The people living in the low-lying areas are urged to be vigilant.
 
Meanwhile, the Disaster Management Center said 6 sluice gates of Daduru Oya reservoir have been opened.
 
It urged the people living in low lying areas in Chilaw, Pallama, and Arachchikattuwa to be vigilant.

heading: Sri Lankan Rs. 2.87 million found from ex-Malaysian PM's apartment (Photos)
description:
The crime investigation team probing the financial irregularities of former Malaysian PM Najib Razak has found Sri Lankan Rupees. 2.87 million from them.
 
The investigators have lodged a report detailing the items seized from the Taman Duta mansion belongs to the family of the ex-PM.
 
The items included over 50 luxury handbags from brands like Chanel, Gucci, and Prada.
 
Amongst the haul was ten luxury watches including several Rolexes and a Patek Philippe, as well as RM 537,000 and 2.87 million Sri Lankan Rupees in cash, the Malaysian police said.

heading: Duminda convicted by fabricating false incidents, President Counsels prove before Supreme Court
description:
The President Counsels proved before the Supreme Court again that the verdict given by the Colombo High Court against former MP, Duminda Silva is not legitimate.
 
When the Appeal by former MP Duminda Silva was taken up for consideration today (May 18), his President Counsels pointed out that the investigators have fabricated false incidents to make former MP Duminda Silva guilty.
 
The appeal by former MP Duminda Silva requesting the court to acquit him was taken up for consideration before a bench of 5 Supreme Court Judges headed by Chief Justice Priyasath Dep for a 6th day today.
 
Making submissions, President Counsel Anura Meddegoda stated that there is no any legal impact in the judgment against former MP Duminda Silva as it has no any legality.
 
Quoting a special statement made by the 3rd suspect from the dock, the President Council pointed out that the CID had obtained under duress the signature of the 3rd suspect to a few blank papers.
 
He said that the Judges acknowledged in the High Court that the special statement made by the 3rd suspect was faithful.
 
The President Counsel further pointed out that the CID produced before court two firearms as court productions citing they recovered them according to the information gathered from the 3rd suspect.
 
He pointed out that all charges including the arrest of the suspect and the discovery of firearms were fabricated incidents.
 
The President Counsel further said that the CID has concocted episodes to file false charges against former MP Duminda Silva.
 
President Counsel Anura Meddegoda further pointed out that such false incidents were not properly examined prior to the judgment was delivered.
 
On a previous occasion of the hearing of this appeal, President Counsel, Anuja Premarathna also stated that such contradictions and omissions of fabricated evidence against former MP Duminda Silva were pointed out in the High Court.
 
He said such contradictions and omission were not taken into proper consideration before giving the judgment.
 
The President Counsel who pointed out that former MP Duminda Silva had been convicted for offenses that were not filed in the charge sheet said that such conviction is not legal at all.
 
President Counsels further proved before the Supreme Court that the evidence in every incident that was given to make former MP Duminda Silva guilty was contradictory.
 
He said that the verdict has itself stated that such evidence given by the witnesses could not be accepted 100% correct.
 
He stated before the bench of five Supreme Court Judges that under such circumstances, the conviction of former MP Duminda Silva for any charge is not lawful.
 
President Counsel Anuja Premarathna said that the verdict against former MP Duminda Silva had been given neither on the evidence nor on the facts but was based on his personality as a popular political icon.
 
He said that although the verdict is read one hundred thousand times, it is not possible to understand why former MP Duminda Silva had been convicted.
 
President Counsel Anuja Premarathna further proved before the bench of five Supreme Court Judges that the judgment which found former MP Duminda Silva guilty of is not legitimate.
 
Meanwhile, President Counsel Anil de Silva stated that the verdict given by the Colombo High Court is full of omissions.
 
He said that the verdict has been passed by the Judge solely based on the submissions made by the State Counsels.
 
She has failed to examine whether such evidence was proved beyond reasonable doubt.
 
The President Counsel pointed out before the Supreme Court that former MP Duminda Silva was accused of using firearms but no evidence was given during the trial to prove such charges.
 
He pointed out that the shooting at former MP Duminda Silva was instigated by Bharatha Lakshman faction.
 
However such action was completely overlooked by the Judge when she passed her verdict.
 
The President Counsel said that it was proved by several evidence during the High Court trial that former MP Duminda Silva received gunshots at first but the verdict has stated that that was immaterial.
 
Therefore, the President Counsel said it was a fine example to prove that the judgment has ignored that the shooting was instigated by Bharatha Lakshman faction.
 
He also said that the judicial medical reports have also confirmed that Duminda Silva received gunshots in his forehead.
 
President Counsel Anil de Silva further pointed out before the Supreme Court that the High Court has ignored the submissions made by the Duminda Silva faction or the defense submissions and, has conducted the trial merely based on the fictitious incidents and evidence.
 
He said that this Case was filed to tarnish the image of former MP Duminda Silva, therefore, he has been denied a justifiable trial similar to that of any other citizen is entitled to in this case.
 
Therefore, President Counsel Anil Silva requested the Supreme Court to overrule the unlawful verdict that has sentenced former MP Duminda Silva, and acquit him from all the charges.
 
The appeal will be called again for further trial on June 4th.

heading: Fallen war heroes commemorated
description:
The 9th anniversary of War victory was commemorated throughout the island today (May 18).
The first school war heroes museum was inaugurated at Kingswood College in Kandy today.
A floral tribute was held on behalf of the soldiers who sacrificed their lives for the country during the commemoration.

heading: Risk of floods if rain continues
description:
The Department of Meteorology says that the inter-monsoon period will activate in another 4 days.
 
The Department added that in the next 24 hours showers of 100 to 150 millimeters could occur in the Western, Sabaragamuwa, Uva, Southern, and Central province in addition to certain areas in the Kurunegala District.
 
The Director of the Water Management Division of the Department of Irrigation added that if showers exceeding 100 mm continue over the next week, it is highly likely that floods could occur in several areas.

heading: Hiru TV's latest reality show 'Hiru Star' begins today
description:
Hiru TV, Sri Lanka leading television channel is bringing to its loyal viewers another reality show of international quality from today (May 19).
The stage is ready to commence 'Hiru Star' and up and coming singers from all over the country are getting ready to take part in this show which will be aired on Saturdays and Sundays at 7.30 pm.
The viewers can vote their favourite singer through the 'Hiru Star App'.
You can download the app from here.

heading: South Western skies to be gloomy, more showers expected
description:
The Met Department says that Southwest monsoon conditions are forming over the island.
Showers or thundershowers will occur at times in Western, Southern, Sabaragamuwa, Central and North-western provinces.
Heavy falls, above 100mm, can be expected at some places, particularly in Central, Sabaragamuwa, Uva, and Western provinces and in Galle and Matara districts.

heading: Police constable dies in misfire
description:
A police constable attached to Wagollakada Police Post in Horowpathana had died after a firearm of a Civil Defence Force personnel went off accidentally.
 
The accident had occurred last midnight (May 18).
 
The victim, aged 32 years, died after being admitted to Horowapathana Hospital.
 
He was a resident of Ihala Divulwewa in Horowpathana.

heading: Visitors advised not to get closer to hill country waterfalls (Photos)
description:
Due to the persistent rains prevailing in the Central hills, Rawana falls, Diyaluma falls and Dunhinda falls have become rough.
 
In this context, the Disaster Management Center and police urged the visitors not to get closer those water streams.
 
The DMC also said the water level of Kirindi Oya which is fed by the Rawana falls has risen, and people are urged to be vigilant of that.

heading: Gold worth Rs. 26mn detected at BIA
description:
The Customs officials at the Bandaranaike International Airport have arrested an Indian national who had attempted to smuggle in Rs. 26 million worth gold biscuits into Sri Lanka.
The suspect had arrived in the island from Chennai at around 8.45 am today (May 19).
The Customs Media said that the 54-year-old suspect had hidden gold in his purse and trouser pockets.

heading: Motorcyclist dies in train accident
description:
A motorcyclist who had attempted to cross the level crossing at Kapuwarna Bodhiya in Alawwa had collided with a train this morning (May 19).
 
He had died on the spot. The identity of the victim is yet to be ascertained.
 
Meanwhile, a 67-year-old person was killed in a hit and run accident at Devata in Galle.
 
The deceased was a resident of Welimada.

heading: National Ceremony to honour fallen war heroes to be held in Kotte
description:
The National War Heroes Commemoration will be held today (May 19) at 4 pm at the War Heroes Memorial at the Parliament Grounds in Kotte.
A special traffic plan will be in place near the Parliament roundabout in view of the commemoration.
The Police Headquarters said that traffic will be restricted from the Polduwa Junction to Kiyangnam Junction along the Parliament Road from 2 pm to 7 pm in view of this event.
Meanwhile, the special 'Aloka Pooja" organized by the Sri Lanka Army in remembrance of the fallen heroes will be held at the Kelaniya Raja Maha Viharaya this evening.
The Navy, Air Force, Police and Civil Defence Force will also support the initiative.
28,619 oil lamps will be lit in remembrance of the war heroes who sacrificed their lives for the country.

heading: GMOA offered to a discussion, token strike continues
War commemorations held in North
description:
A memorial statue for the Tamil people who died in the war was declared open with the participation of Northern Chief Minister, C. V. Wigneshwaran in the coastal area of Mullivaikkal in Mullaitivu this morning (May 18).
 
A group of Northern Provincial Councillors and another group of students from Jaffna University arrived in a motorcade to Mullivaikal to participate in the event.
 
Students of the Jaffna University also organized a commemoration for the Tamil people who died in the conflict.
 
It is also reported that many schools in the North flew the provincial flag at half-mast today.
 
Earlier, Northern Provincial Education Minister asked school administration to do so.
 
However, Minister of Law and Order Ranjith Madduma Bandara said that no legal permission has been given to hold commemorations of the war dead.

heading: No consolation for ETI depositors
Spill gates of Udawalawa reservoir opened
Sri Lanka commemorates war heroes
description:
Today marks 9 years since Sri Lanka war heroes had defeated the brutal terrorism of the LTTE, restoring peace and freedom in the country.
The national war hero commemoration day will be held under the patronage of President Maithreepala Sirisena tomorrow (May 19) in front of the war heroes memorial at the parliament grounds.
Alongside the commemoration, the Aloka Pujawa organized by the Sri Lanka Army in remembrance of war heroes who sacrificed their lives will be held at the Kelaniya Rajamaha Viharaya.
The Navy, Air Force, Police and Civil Defence Force will support this initiative.
Lighting of lamps remembering the 28,619 war heroes who sacrificed their lives for the country, will also take place under the patronage of the President.
The Army headquarters noted that chief of defence staff, commanders of the tri-forces, IGP and the director general of the Civil Defence Force, as well as the families of fallen war heroes, will grace the occasion.
Meanwhile, several ceremonies in commemoration of war heroes are scheduled to be held concurrently at 9.30 am today at security forces headquarters, combat training schools, regimental headquarters, as well as Field Headquarters island-wide.
50 officers of the tri-forces will be awarded the Vishishta Seva Vibhushana Medal.

heading: GMOA token strike ends
description:
The token strike launched by the GMOA in protest of the Singapore - Sri Lanka Free Trade Agreement will be concluded at 8 this morning (May 18).
Patients were severely inconvenienced yesterday due to island-wide strike that began at 8 on Thursday morning.
At a media briefing held yesterday, presidential secretary Austin Fernando said that the GMOA is scheduled to have a discussion with the President on 22nd of this month regarding the issue.
However, GMOA executive committee member Dr. Prasaad Colambage said that if action was not taken to provide solutions the GMOA would resort to uninterrupted strikes in the future.
Meanwhile, as a consequence of the ‘work-to-rule’ campaign being carried out by members of Sri Lanka Immigration and Emigration Officers' Association delays are expected, therefore SriLankan Airlines advised passengers to arrive at Katunayake airport at least three hours prior to the departure time.

heading: SLFP to appoint interim office bearers on June 3
description:
MP Lakshman Yapa Abeywardena says that the Sri Lanka Freedom Party's Central Committee has decided to appoint new officials for all the posts in the party temporarily on 3rd of June.
He also said that the SLFP CC decided that Ministers and MPs who are in supportive of splitting from the National Government should take a decision soon.
These had been discussed among other matters when the SLFP CC met under the patronage of President Maithripala Sirisena in Colombo this evening (May 17).

heading: Northern Education Minister advises schools to fly flags half-mast tomorrow
description:
The Northern Provincial Education Minister, Kandaiah Sarveshwaran has informed all schools in the province to fly the provincial flag half mast tomorrow (May 18) to commemorate the Tamil people who died in the war.
Speaking to our news team, he said that he had informed all principals and teachers in the province to do so.
Our news team contacted Education State Minister, V. Radhakrishnan to comment on this decision by the Northern Provincial Education Minister.
State Minister Radhakrishnan said that the Northern Provincial Education minister had no legal right to do so.
Meanwhile, Northern Chief Minister, V. Wigneshwaran inspected the ongoing arrangements to commemorate the war victims.
Meanwhile, Army Commander, Lieutenant General Mahesh Senanayake stated that war heroes should not be used to achieve private agendas and petty-gains.
In a statement, the Army Commander said war heroes should be paid gratitude without hostility and anti-social activities.
He further said that 23,962 soldiers from the Sri Lanka Army, 1,160 from Sri Lanka Navy, 443 from Sri Lanka Airforce, 2,568 from Sri Lanka Police and 456 from Civil Defence Force have sacrificed their lives to restore peace in Sri Lanka.

heading: Joint Opposition seeks debate on Singapore FTA
description:
The Joint Opposition is preparing to request for a parliamentary debate on the Free Trade Agreement with Singapore and the country’s economy.
The JO Parliamentarian Bandula Gunawardena said that they hope to make a request to the Speaker at the next session.
The opposition against Sri Lanka - Singapore FTA is mounting as professionals and other stakeholders argue that the agreement has been signed without having proper consultation and awareness.

heading: SLFP CC makes several key decisions
description:
The Sri Lanka Freedom Party’s Central Committee which met last night (May 17) had decided that the SLFP MPs who are with the Unity Government, should make a decision without delay to leave the government.
 
The SLFP CC met under the patronage of President Maithripala Sirisena last night at his official residence.
 
MP Lakshman Yapa Abeywardena that the next SLFP CC meeting is scheduled to be held on 3rd of June and it was decided to appoint interim office bearers on that day.
 
The MP said that it was also decided that reorganization of the party should take place before 20th of August.

heading: Rain causes traffic congestion in Colombo roads
Fire at Police Field Force HQ
description:
A fire broke out at the ground floor of the sports enclosure at the Police Field Head Quarters in Bambalapitiya.
 
Police said that the Fire Brigade was able to douse the fire.
 
The reason for the fire not known.

heading: Six drug traffickers arrested
description:
Six drug traffickers were arrested following raids carried out in the Sedawatte area, Colombo.
 
The raid was carried out by the Organized Crimes Prevention Unit yesterday (May 17).
 
Police found heroin, Kerala cannabis, a firearm and 6 live ammunition in the possession of the suspects who are residents of Narahenpita, Kirulapone, and Modera.

heading: Anurudda Polgampola granted bail
description:
Ex-Chairman of State Timber Corporation who was arrested over an alleged financial fraud has been released on bail.
 
He was released after he was produced before Kilinochchi Magistrate this morning (May 18).

heading: Two historic statues stolen from Jaffna kovil
description:
Police say a historic kovil situated at the Urumbirai Savier Vidyala ground has been broken into and 2 historic statues have been removed.
 
The robbery had taken place between 1.30 am and 5.30am yesterday.
 
Police said that the 2 statues which are dating back to 100 years are valued at around Rs. 200,000.
 
The police probe began after the principal of the school lodged a complaint, and at around 11.30 am a suspect had been arrested and the stolen statues were recovered.
 
The suspect, aged 22, is a resident of Urumbirai, will be produced before court today (May 18).

heading: Landslide warning issued for 10 districts
description:
Met Department says the rainfall of 108.3 mm recorded in Colombo fort was the highest rainfall recorded within the 24-hour period.
Meanwhile, the National Building Research Organization said with the activation of South Western monsoon, 10 districts are at risk of experiencing landslides.
The NBRO urged the residents of those landslide-prone areas to be vigilant.
Due to a low-level atmospheric disturbance associated with the Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone, cloudy conditions along with heavy rainfall is expected over most parts of the island, the Colombo Met Office said.
Around 100mm of rainfall can be expected in the Central, Sabaragamuwa, Southern, Uva, Western and North-Western provinces and in Amparai and Batticaloa districts.

heading: Loan given to business properties damaged in Kandy increased
description:
The Cabinet has approved a proposal to increase the loan given to the business properties that were damaged due to Kandy incidents.
 
Accordingly, the minimum loan amount would be increased from Rs. 500,000 to Rs. 1 million.
 
Earlier, Cabinet approval was granted to release Rs. 500,000 at an interest rate of 2%.

heading: Work-to-rule campaign by Immigration & Emigration officers continues
description:
The work-to-rule campaign which is being staged by Immigration and Emigration officers is continuing.
 
The trade union action was launched last midnight citing 3 main issues.
 
Meanwhile, the Union said that the subject minister S. B. Navinna had a discussion with them at the Bandaranaike International Airport premises.
 
The Minister had promised that he would discuss the issues with the relevant authorities to find an amicable solution.
 
However, President of the Union Aruna Kanugala told us that the work-to-rule campaign would continue, until a definitive solution is found.
 
Meanwhile, Sri Lankan Airlines requests passengers who would depart from the BIA to arrive at the airport 3 hours in advance for checking in.

heading: Northern war dead commemorated, Minister says permission not granted
description:
The Minister of Law and Order Ranjith Madduma Bandara says that legal permission had not been granted to hold commemoration ceremonies remembering those who killed in the North during the conflict.
 
He said this while speaking to media after participating at a ceremony in Tanamalwila today (May 18).
 
Commemorations were organized throughout the island in remembrance of war heroes who fought to defeat the LTTE terrorists.
 
This morning in Werahera, a statue to commemorate war heroes was unveiled by Major General H. S. Munasinghe, the commander of the Army Medical Brigade.
 
The Jathika Hela Urumaya commemorated the day with inmates of the Army Rehabilitation Center in Ratmalana.
 
Meanwhile, the Manning Market Traders' Association organized a war heroes commemoration this morning.
 
In addition, another commemoration was held in front of Hasalaka Hero, Gamini Kularathna’s memorial statue.
 
Meanwhile, several Northern Provincial Councillors led by Chief Minister, C. V. Wigneshwaran and TNA members were present at the unveiling of a memorial statue in remembrance of the Tamil people who died in the war.
 
The event was held in the coast of Mullivaikkal in Mullaitivu earlier today.
 
Meanwhile, the Minister of Law and Order Ranjith Madduma Banda said no legal permission is given to hold commemorations in the North.

heading: Unauthorized massage parlour raided in Thalawathugoda, 8 women arrested
description:
10 persons including 8 women were apprehended by police after raiding an unauthorized massage parlour in Thalawathugoda town.
 
The raid was carried out by the Central Anti-Vice Squad of Walaana.
 
The arrested women were aged between 20 and 30, residents of Amparai, Maharagama, Galle, Matale, and Ratnapura.
 
This location was raided on a previous occasion too.
 
Then the owner had fled. But he was apprehended during today's (May 16) raid.

heading: Bus fares increased, strike called off
GMOA to strike tomorrow against Singapore-Sri Lanka FTA
description:
The Government Medical Officers’ Association says they will launch a one day token strike tomorrow (May 17) to protest against the Sri Lanka Singapore Free Trade Agreement.
 
Addressing a media conference in Colombo today, GMOA Secretary Dr. Haritha Aluthge said that this FTA will have severe consequences on the Sri Lanka economy.
 
Meanwhile, All Ceylon Government Medical Officers’ Union also convened a media conference in Colombo today.
 
Its President, Dr. Gishantha Dassanayake said that its members would join the public to fight the FTA.
 
In addition, Sri Lanka Immigration and Emigration Officers' Union has planned to launch a work-to-rule campaign with effect from midnight tomorrow.
 
The union has taken this trade union action citing several issues including the introduction of a new service minute.
 
At the same time, the work-to-rule campaign launched by the CEB engineers is still continuing.
 
The CEB engineers are agitating against the failure of the Sri Lanka Public Utility Commission to approve Long-Term Power Generation Plan.
 
Meanwhile, 6 members of the Inter-University Bhikkhu Front launched a sit-in protest at the Lipton Circus this afternoon.
 
Convener of the SLBF, Ven. Rathkarawwe Jinarathana Thera said that the agitation is launched against the slashing of the subject, Buddhist Philosophy from the University syllabus.

heading: A new report claims China using 'debtbook diplomacy' for strategic gains in many countries including Sri Lanka
description:
The Chinese government is leveraging billions of dollars in debts to gain political leverage with developing countries across Asia and the Pacific, a new report presented to the US State Department claims.
 
The independent report, written by a pair of Harvard University scholars, identified 16 countries targeted by the Chinese government for "debtbook diplomacy, " with Pakistan, Djibouti and Sri Lanka identified as being most vulnerable.
 
According to the report, in some cases the huge debts grow to a size too large to pay back, allowing Beijing to leverage the loans to "acquire strategic assets or political influence over debtor nations."
 
This could allow the Chinese government to extend its influence across the Indian Ocean and the Pacific, encircling India and Australia as well as helping to consolidate its position in the South China Sea, the report said.
 
Last month, Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull said he viewed "with great concern" any foreign military bases being built in the South Pacific, following reports Beijing was in talks with Vanuatu to host Chinese forces.
 
According to the report, there are a number of ways in which Beijing and state-owned enterprises leverage debt to help China's strategic aims.
 
In one case, infrastructure built with Chinese loans has then been leased back to Chinese interests to pay off the original debt.
 
In 2017, an unprofitable Sri Lankan port built with billion-dollar loans from Beijing was leased to Chinese state-owned firms for 99 years to help repay the country's debts.
 
The report's co-author Sam Parker said there were concerns these ports could be used by Chinese naval vessels once they were under state control. "There's definitely the potential where they can have it go from commercial, to occasional visit, to logistics, to humanitarian and then maybe finally a military base," he said.
 
In the Pacific, nations such as Vanuatu, Papua New Guinea, and Tonga all owe the Chinese government billions of dollars in loans, encircling US allies Australia and New Zealand.
 
(CNN)

heading: Ramazan begins on Friday
SLFP CC meets tonight
description:
Sri Lanka Freedom Party Central Committee will meet this evening (May 17) under the patronage of President Maithripala Sirisena.
 
MP Chandima Weerakkody who recently stepped down from the Ministry post said that the meeting is scheduled to begin at around 7 pm.
 
It is expected to take a decision on the fate of the SLFP in the Unity Government at this meeting.
 
Meanwhile, State Minister A. H. M. Fowzi said that the agenda which is already finalized made no mention of such a decision to be made.
 
The State Minister said that a discussion on party restructuring is on the agenda.

heading: Galle fishermen stage candlelight agitation
description:
A group of fishermen in Galle staged a protest holding candles last night (May 16) demanding that fuel to be supplied to fishermen at the previous price.
 
They say that the proposed coupon systems will not succeed.
 
Participating in the protest, All Island Fishermen's General Federation’s National Organizer Rathna Gamage said the fishermen are facing hardships to carry out their livelihood as a result of the recent kerosene price hike.

heading: Bus fare revision to be submitted to Cabinet next week
description:
Deputy Minister of Transport Ashok Abeysinghe says the Cabinet paper on bus fare revision will be submitted to Cabinet next Tuesday.
 
It was decided to revise the bus fares by 12.5% and the minimum bus fare to Rs. 12 at a meeting last evening (May 16).
 
The bus unions were planning to stage a strike from midnight yesterday against the fare revision of 6.56% approved by the Cabinet on last Tuesday.

heading: Chairman & Deputy Chairman of Weligama Pradeshiya Sabha arrested
description:
The Chairman of Weligama Pradeshiya Sabha, Pushpakumara Bettage along with 8 others were arrested yesterday (May 16), after they surrendered to Weligama police, in connection to the tense situation which erupted during the opening of the Weligama, Polathumodera bridge.
 
Police said that the Deputy Chairman of Weligama Pradeshiya Sabha as well as 6 councillors, are representatives of Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna.
 
Meanwhile, two other Pradeshiya Sabha councilors who were previously arrested in connection to the same incident are being held in remand custody.
 
The 9 individuals who will be produced before Matara Magistrate later today, are accused of interfering with police duties and disrupting public peace.
 
Prior to the opening ceremony of the bridge on 11th of May, which was held under the patronage of Minister Sagala Ratnayake, a group of councillors from SLPP including the Chairman of the Weligama Pradeshiya Sabha had allegedly created a tense situation there.

heading: 6 sluice gates of Deduru Oya opened, people urged to be vigilant
description:
Disaster Management Center says 6 sluice gates of Deduru Oya reservoir have been opened as a result of rising water level.
 
The DMC urged the people living in low lying areas of Chilaw, Pallama, and Arachchikattuwa to be vigilant.

heading: Government doctors strike against Singapore FTA
description:
Doctors in the government hospitals have launched an island-wide token strike to protest against the Free Trade Agreement signed between Sri Lanka and Singapore.
 
The GMOA media spokesperson Dr. Samantha Ananda said that the strike that would continue until 4 pm.
 
He clarified however that the strike would affect the functions in maternity and children's hospitals, the Cancer Institute, and kidney clinics.

heading: Govt. Analyst's decision on deaths of British rugby players due
description:
The specimen from the bodies of the 2 British rugby players who had died after developing breathing difficulties after a night out in Colpetty, has been sent to the Government Analyst.
 
The decision was taken by the Colombo Judicial Medical Officer after the postmortem inquiries.
 
A 22-member British rugby team arrived in Sri Lanka last week to attend few friendly matches.
 
They had played a match on Saturday (May 12) with a leading Colombo club and in the evening, a group of players had visited a nightclub in Colpetty.
 
Police have collected CCTV footage from the nightclub to be probed.
 
Colombo Fort Magistrate told yesterday that the decision on whether bodies would be handed over to their relatives will be announced today (May 17).

heading: GMOA strike inconveniences patients
description:
Doctors in the government hospitals launched an island-wide token strike this morning (May 17) to protest against the Free Trade Agreement signed between Sri Lanka and Singapore. 
The GMOA media spokesperson Dr. Samantha Ananda said that the strike that would continue until 8 am tomorrow.
 
He clarified however that the strike would affect the functions in maternity and children's hospitals, the Cancer Institute, and kidney clinics.
 
However, our correspondents said the patients who had arrived at hospitals were inconvenienced as a result of the ongoing strike.

heading: Blast at Diyathalawa Air Force Camp
description:
Three Air Force personnel were injured and hospitalized following a blast occurred during a military training exercise at the Diyathalawa Air Force Camp.
The Air Force Spokesperson said that the injured were admitted to Diyathalawa Hospital.
Police said that the incident had happened at around 10.15 am.
The blast was caused by the explosion of a live hand grenade.
According to police, an Air Force officer, a sergeant and a trainee female soldier were injured in the blast.

heading: ETi depositors stage another protest
description:
A group of depositors of the ETI Finance is engaging in a protest at Ward Place, Borella demanding their money.
 
Our correspondent said that the protestors are blocking the road towards Borella.
 
The ETI depositors had staged protests at the Head Office in Ward Place earlier too.

heading: Trade Union action causes delays at BIA
description:
Trade Union action causes delays at BIA" 
Passengers are urged to come to BIA 3 hours prior to departure time..
SriLankan Airlines requests the passengers to arrive at the Bandaranaike International Airport, 3 hours prior to the departure time.
 
The statement issued by the national carrier said that it will be enforced from this afternoon (May 17) to until further notice.
 
The Immigration and Emigration Officers' Union has launched a work-to-rule campaign and SriLankan Airlines said the early arrival of passengers is needed to minimize delays at the airport.

heading: Joint Opposition prepares for a struggle
description:
The Joint Opposition says that they will launch agitation campaigns island-wide against the rising cost of living of the masses.
 
They say unfair taxes have been imposed further inconveniencing the public.
 
This was decided at a special discussion held at the Official Residence of the former President Mahinda Rajapaksa yesterday (May 15).

heading: Private bus unions threaten to strike from midnight
description:
Private bus unions say that that they would refrain from providing transport service from midnight tonight since the fare has not been raised to match the fuel price increase, as requested.
The decision to launch a strike came after the cabinet approval for raising private and SLTB bus fares by just 6.56 
was announced.
The new fare was made effective from midnight last night (May 15).
The bus fare revision committee had lengthy discussions and took into consideration the 12 indicators.
It was then decided that the current bus fare should be increased by 6.56 percent.
it was decided that the minimum bus fare of Rs. 10 not be changed.
Minister of Transport and Civil Aviation Nimal Siripala Silva submitted the relevant decisions to the cabinet yesterday.
They said that as a result, they would launch an uninterrupted island-wide strike from midnight tonight.
They said that although Transport deputy minister Ashok Abeysinghe had informed the private bus unions to attend a discussion today, they would not be attending the discussion.
The SLTB said that the increased bus fare would 
into effect from today.

heading: Wet weather to enhance
description:
Met Department says rainy condition over the island and surrounding sea areas is expected to enhance.
Showers or thundershowers will occur over most provinces of the island, particularly after 2 pm.
Showers will occur in Western and Southern provinces and in Puttalam district during the morning too.
Heavy falls of about 100mm can be expected at some places, particularly in Central, Sabaragamuwa, Southern,
Uva and Western provinces.

heading: Undergrads oppose SAITM decision
description:
Inter-University Student's Federation says they are opposing the government's decision to admit 982 SAITM medical students to the Kotelawala Defence University.
 
The convener of IUSF, Lahiru Weerasekera said this addressing the media in Colombo yesterday.
 
The Cabinet yesterday (May 15) ratified a Cabinet paper submitted by Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe to transfer those students to the KDU after scrutinizing their qualifications.
 
Meanwhile, when contacted the former President of the Sri Lanka Medical Council Prof. Carlo Fonseka said he agrees with the Cabinet decision.

heading: Fever spreading in South identified as Pneumonia
description:
Karaapitiya Teaching Hospital (KTH) Paediatrician Dr. Aruna de Silva has said that the virus fever that is spreading in the Southern province is pneumonia.
He said that the condition is caused by the viruses 'influenza' and 'adino',
It has been reported that the virus more commonly affects children under the age of three years.
Already 5 children died while being treated at the KTH.

heading: Monthly allowance for artists
description:
The government's initiative to give a monthly allowance for retired artists began at a special ceremony held the National Film Corporation auditorium under the patronage of President Maithripala Sirisena yesterday (May 15).
 
Accordingly, 163 artists will receive a monthly allowance of Rs. 5,000 from the month of April.

heading: Sri Lanka to lose $ 1bn through Singapore -Sri Lanka FTA
description:
The National Front of Professionals says that due to the Free Trade Agreement with Singapore, Sri Lanka will lose $ 1 billion.
 
The Customs Officers' Union, which is affiliated to that front said highlighted this fact during a media conference in Colombo yesterday (May 15).

heading: Amaraweera rejects Yapa's accusation
description:
United People's Freedom Alliance MP Mahinda Yapa Abeywardena says that the SLFP General Secretary Duminda Dissanayake and the UPFA General Secretary Mahinda Amaraweera are planning to contest under the UNP ticket at the next election.
 
He said this in response to questions posed by journalists following an event in Matara yesterday (May 15).
 
Meanwhile, Mahinda Amaraweera rejected that allegation following an event in Borelasgamuwa yesterday.

heading: Tragic death of father & son in Vavuniya (Photos)
description:
Police this morning (May 16) found 2 bodies in the bank of Suduwendapilaw tank at Paawakkulam in Vavuniya.
 
It was revealed that the victims were father and son from the area.
 
Police said that they had got contacted with a live power line laid by an unknown person to hunt animals.
 
The father was aged 48 years and his son was a 15-year-old.

heading: Leave of SLTB drivers, conductors & mechanics cancelled
description:
Sri Lanka Transport Board says that the leave of all drivers, conductors, and mechanics will be cancelled until the planned private bus strike is over.
 
The private bus unions are threatening to launch an island-wide bus strike from midnight tonight saying that the bus fare hike proposed by the government is inadequate.

heading: Water cut in several areas of Kalutara
description:
National Water Supply and Drainage Board says the water supply to several areas of Kalutara will be discontinued tomorrow (May 17) due to an essential maintenance work.
 
Accordingly, the water supply will be restricted for 11 hours from 8 am tomorrow.

heading: "Those who oppose government face harassment", says Joint Opposition
description:
Joint Opposition MP Shehan Semasinghe says questioning of MP Dilum Amunugama by the Terrorism Investigation Division portrays the fate of those who oppose the government.
 
MP Semasinghe said this addressing the media in Colombo this morning (May 16).

heading: Fmr. MP Polgampola remanded
description:
Former Parliamentarian Anuruddha Polgampola who was arrested by the Criminal Investigation Department has been remanded till 18
 of May.
 
He was arrested yesterday over an alleged Rs. 8 million financial fraud was produced before Fort Magistrate's Court today.

heading: Electricity breakdowns galore
description:
Electricity breakdowns have been reported from several areas of the country as a result of the ongoing work-to-rule trade union action by the CEB Engineers' Union.
 
Our correspondents said power outages were reported from Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa, and Kalubowila this morning (May 16).
 
The CEB engineers began their trade union action on 9th of this month demanding the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka to approve the Long-term Power Generation Plan.
 
The union President Saumya Kumarawadu said that the authorities are not responding positively to their demand hence they will continue their trade union action.

heading: Unidentified virus kills 5 kids
description:
The health authorities in the Southern Province warns the public that a viral fever is spreading in the region.
 
It is reported that the fever is spreading amongst the infants mainly.
 
The majority of cases are reported from Tangalle, Hambantota, and Walasmula.
 
Several kids are being treated at the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital.
Hospital sources said that 5 infants died of the disease over the past few days.
Parents are urged to not allow sick children mingling with others and seek medical advice as soon as they notice symptoms of fever.

heading: Sri Lanka Army understands role & task, says Lt. Gen. Senanayake
description:
Army Commander Lieutenant General Mahesh Senanayake says Sri Lanka Army has fully understood the role and responsibilities in post-war Sri Lanka.
 
He added that in recent history, Sri Lanka is the one and only country on the world map that has eradicated terrorism from its soil.
 
Lt. Gen. Senanayake said, “We are a victorious army”.
 
In an interview with The Hindu, the Army chief said that once the combat is over, it is the responsibility of the army itself to understand its role and task.
 
“The last nine years were very critical to understand what happened 30 years ago. What must this government and army do to ensure that we don’t go back to the roots of the conflict that began 30 years ago? We have to find a mechanism, a commitment within the country to satisfy our own people more than the people outside. Today, we are closer to a better solution. Democracy was restored, elections were held [in 2015], good governance was brought in”, he said.
 
The Army Commander said, “In this context, we are right-sizing and building a capacity-based army. We have to give back to the people by right-sizing and ensuring that the war will not recur. We are engaging with the people in the north and east to identify our responsibility. The 30 years of war were brutal, many lives were lost on both sides. This is a sort of testing period for us”.
 
“On April 13, we released 683 acres in Palaly, a critical area. It was a very bold decision as far as the Sri Lankan armed forces are concerned and we took it. We calculated the risk, nobody pressured us. Frankly, even the government or the political leadership did not know that we were going to release land there”, he disclosed.
 
“In another four to five months, we will return more land. We have identified some private land on which armed forces are stationed. We cannot compromise on national security. For that reason, we have to have some troops in those areas, and we are shifting them to state land. I need some finances for us to resettle”, Lt. Gen. Senanayake added.

heading: No electricity in several areas of Colombo
description:
Ceylon Electricity Board says due to a breakdown in the Biyagama - Pannipitiya line, power supply to several areas has disrupted.
 
It is reported that Jayawardenepura, Dehiwala - Mt. Lavinia, Ratmalana, Pannipitiya, and Battaramulla are without electricity.
 
The CEB said steps are being taken to address the issue.

heading: ‘Bus fare increase’ gets greenlight
description:
The government has agreed to revise the fares of Sri Lanka Transport Board operated buses and private buses.
 
The Deputy Transport Minister Ashok Abeysinghe said that the relevant proposal would be presented to the Cabinet today (May 15).
 
Accordingly, the minimum bus fare will be revised to Rs. 12 from the present fare of Rs. 10.
 
The overall fare increase will be around 8% to 10%.
 
The private bus unions and the Secretary of the Ministry of Transport G. S. Vithanage discussed the matter at the National Transport Commission yesterday. 
 
The Deputy Minister of Transport, Ashok Abeysinghe said that the decisions reached during that meeting will be included in the Cabinet paper.
 
Earlier, some bus unions threaten to call an island-wide strike if bus fares are not revised by 20% by Thursday.
 
They wanted the minimum fare to revised to Rs. 15.

heading: Crucial SLFP CC meeting to decide party’s fate
description:
16 Sri Lanka Freedom Party parliamentarians who recently resigned from the Unity Government say that the SLFP Central Committee meeting scheduled for Thursday (May 17) will be critical.
 
The meeting which will be held under the patronage of President Maithripala Sirisena will decide the fate of the SLFP in the government, they said.
 
When contacted, MP Chandima Weerakkody said the decisions relating to the changes of the positions of the party office bearers.

heading: Three killed in Urubokka accident (Photos)
description:
Three persons were killed in a road accident occurred at Daabogala in Rotuba, Urubokka in Matara last night (May 14).
 
Police said that the accident had occurred when a speeding three-wheeler veered off the road and hit a roadside three.
 
The victims were aged 34, 50, and 53 and they were residents of Pasgoda, Bengamuwa, and Handugala.
 
The three-wheel driver was admitted to Embilipitiya Hospital with critical injuries.

heading: Strike of fishermen continues
description:
Fisheries unions say that they will refrain from fishing today in protest of the recent increase of kerosene price.
 
The unions said they will engage in an uninterrupted strike until an acceptable solution is provided.
 
Small-scale fishermen in the Southern, Western and North Western Provinces also protested against kerosene price increase.

heading: Dilum Amunugama at TID
description:
The UPFA Kandy district MP Dilum Amunugama has arrived at the Terrorism Investigation Division to give a statement on Kandy incidents.
Our correspondent said that the MP arrived at the TID at 11.30 this morning (May 15).
MP Amunugama was originally summoned to the TID on 10th of May, but rescheduled the appointment for today as he had to participate in a Parliamentary sitting on 10th of May.
MPs Mahindananda Aluthgamage and Namal Rajapaksa accompanied MP Amunugama to the TID.

heading: Thanamalwila murder suspect arrested
description:
Police have arrested a youth in Thanamalwila for allegedly killing a money lender and stealing his money.
 
The incident occurred on 9th of May.
 
Police found the body of the 38-year-old victim in the roadside with cut injuries.
 
The motorcycle which was allegedly used for the murder has also been located.
 
The 19-year-old suspect will be produced before Wellawaya Magistrate court today (May 15).

heading: School children stage protest blocking road (Photos)
description:
A group of parents and students have started a demonstration against the transfer of the principal of Aparekke Maha Vidyalaya, Matara.
 
Our correspondent said that they have blocked the Matara - Kekanadura road.
 
The studies at the school have also been affected.

heading: South hit by outbreak of severe pneumonia
description:
Health authorities in the South have decided to limit the number of visitors to Karapitiya Teaching Hospital due to an outbreak of viral flu in the Southern Province.
 
The hospital authorities said that small children are more prone to this flu.
 
5 infants have already died in the past few weeks.
 
The highest number of cases are reported from Tangalle, Hambantota and Walasmulla areas.
 
The Director of the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital Dr. Jayampathi Senanayake said that a special investigation has already begun to prevent the spread of the disease.
 
Meanwhile, a meeting was held at the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital to discuss the actions to be taken to contain the disease, which is identified as an outbreak of severe pneumonia.
 
It has decided to launch a public awareness campaign targeting pre-school children and school children.
 
They have also decided to see the possibility of giving seasonal influenza vaccine.

heading: Fisheries unions to discuss kerosene issue with Minister
description:
The fishermen from North Western, Western and Southern coastal areas have boycotted venturing into the sea today (May 15) in protest of the recent price hike of kerosene.
 
The unions have agreed to discuss the issue with Minister of Fisheries Vijith Vijayamuni Zoysa this afternoon.
 
The President of Chilaw Rural Fishermen’s Union, Sujith Roshan said that his union agrees to have an identical colour for subsidized kerosene for fishermen.
 
Meanwhile, the price of fish in the marketplace has gone up due to the ongoing strike by the fishermen.

heading: One person missing as tractor carried away by rising water level in Hada Oya
description:
Ignoring the rising water level of Hada Oya, 6 persons on a tractor had attempted to cross the river last afternoon (May 14) in Siyambalanduwa.
 
However, the gushing water had carried away the along with the tractor.
 
The onlookers were able to rescue 5 of them.
 
But another person is missing, and he was a resident of Badulla.

heading: Bus fares increased from tomorrow
description:
The Cabinet has granted approval to increase the bus fares from tomorrow.
 
Accordingly, the bus fare will be revised by 6.56%.
 
Minister Ranjith Madumabandara said that the minimum bus fare will not be revised.
 
The Cabinet has also approved to integrate 980 SAITM medical students to the Medical faculty of the John Kotelawala Defence University.

heading: Second British rugby player dies
description:
The second British rugby player who was hospitalized after developing breathing problems following a night out in Colombo has died.
 
The victim was 27-years-old.
 
The 22-member rugby side, Clems Pirates had arrived in Sri Lanka early last week to play a couple of friendly matches.
 
They had played one game on Saturday with CR & FC in Colombo and following the game several members of the team had visited a nightclub in Colpetty.
 
However, after returning to the team hotel, two players had developed breathing difficulties and the hotel management had admitted them to a leading private hospital in Colombo.
 
Meanwhile, the postmortem on the first victim who died on Sunday was conducted by the Colombo Judicial Medical Officer this morning (May 15).
 
He had ruled the death was caused not by a disease or an injury.
 
The JMO then issued an open verdict and had ordered to send body specimen to the Government Analyst for further tests.

heading: Police probe mysterious death of 2-year-old child in Maligawatte
description:
Police have begun a probe into an incident after it was reported that attempts are made to bury a child who had died under mysterious circumstances in Maligawatte.
 
The parents had tried to conduct the funeral without a postmortem being held, last afternoon (May 14).
 
They had said that child died due to diabetes.
 
However, after being tipped-off, a team from the Maligawatte Police rushed to the location and found burn marks in the dead child's left leg.
 
Accordingly, the postmortem will be held today.

heading: Private bus strike looming ?
description:
The Inter-Provincial Private Bus Owners' Association says they will launch a strike action from midnight tomorrow.
 
They say that the government's proposed fare hike is not sufficient.
 
Earlier in the day, Cabinet granted approval to increase the bus fares from tomorrow.
 
Accordingly, the bus fare will be revised by 6.56%.
 
Minister Ranjith Madumabandara said that the minimum bus fare will not be revised.
Meanwhile, President of Lanka Private Bus Owners' Association, Gamunu Wijeratne said they too will launch a strike from tomorrow midnight against the government's bus fare hike.
He said it was not sufficient.

heading: Speaker signs Judicature Amendment Bill
description:
The Judicature Amendment Bill which facilitates the setting up of special High Courts has been signed into a law by the Speaker Karu Jayasuriya.
 
The Bill was debated in Parliament last Wednesday (May 09), and it was passed with a majority of 67 votes.

heading: Met Dept. issues severe weather warning
description:
Met Department says rainy condition over the island and surrounding sea areas is expected to enhance during next few days.
 
Heavy falls, above 100mm, can be expected at some places, particularly in Central, Sabaragamuwa, Southern, Uva and Western provinces.
 
The showery condition in the sea areas around the island is expected to enhance.
 
Heavy falls can be expected at some places, particularly in the sea areas off the coast extending from Puttalam to Batticaloa via Colombo, Galle, and Pottuvil.
 
People are warned that severe lightning and temporarily strong gusty winds up to 70-80 kmph are also possible during thundershowers.
 
The people who are living near the hills and valleys banks are advised to be on alert about the hazards that can occur due to heavy rainfall and thunderstorm.
 
The people who are engaged in naval and fishing activities in the sea areas around the Island have been advised to take adequate precautions to avoid the hazards due to heavy rains, severe thunderstorms and temporarily strong gusty winds associated with rough sea areas.
 
People are also advised:
* Seek shelter, preferably indoors, covered vehicles and never under trees
* Avoid open areas such as paddy fields, tea plantations and open water bodies during thunderstorms.
 
* Avoid using wired telephones and connected electric appliances during thunderstorms.
* Avoid using open vehicles, such as bicycles, tractors and boats etc.
* Beware of fallen trees and power lines.

heading: Cabinet paper on bus fare hike to be presented tomorrow says NTC
description:
The Chairman of National Transport Commission M. A. P. Hemachandra says that a proposal regarding the bus fare increase will be submitted for tomorrow’s (May 15) cabinet meeting.
 
The NTC Chairman said that a special discussion would be held at the commission today in relation to this matter.
 
The bus unions are demanding to increase the bus fares as a result of recent fuel price hike.
 
The Secretary of the All Ceylon Private Bus Association Anjana Priyanjith said that bus fares should be increased by 20% to match the fuel price hike.
 
He said otherwise they would launch a strike on 17
 of this month.
 
However, the President of the Lanka Private Bus Owners' Association, Gemunu Wijerathna said that the revision of bus fares should be carried out by the National Transport Commission.
 
Meanwhile, the NTC said when the annual bus fare hike is implemented by 1
 of July, they would consider the fuel price hike.

heading: Sri Lanka & Iran sign 5 MoU's
description:
Sri Lanka and Iran have signed five MoU's to enhance bilateral ties between the 2 nations.
 
Iran is Sri Lanka's largest export destination in the Middle-East.
 
The representatives of the 2 nations signed the agreements following bilateral discussion between Sri Lanka President Maithripala Sirisena and his Iranian counterpart, Hassan Rouhani in Teheran yesterday (May 13).
 
 
Health, Medical Science, Pharmaceutical and Medical Equipment
Meteorology, and Training
Combating illicit trafficking in narcotic drugs
Cinema and Television
Culture, Science, and Technology

heading: Police firearm goes off, one person killed (Photos)
"Group of 16" undecided to whom to support at Presidential Election
description:
MP Dilan Perera says that Sri Lanka Freedom Party "Group of 16", who resigned from the government recently, is still not yet decided to whom to support at the 2020 Presidential Election.
 
He said this addressing a public rally in Hali Ela yesterday (May 13).
 
Perera said they are of the belief that somebody who has the backing of a coalition headed by the SLFP should contest the Presidential election.
 
He added that President Maithripala Sirisena and former President Mahinda Rajapaksa should make a unified decision on the candidate.

heading: UPFA Gen. Sec. makes a revelation on "Group of 16"
description:
The General Secretary of the United People's Freedom Alliance Minister Mahinda Amaraweera says that the 16 SLFPers who left the Unity Government recently would not join any other political party.
 
However, former Minister W. D. J. Seneviratne yesterday (May 13) said that their group with contest elections in future under the leadership of former President Mahinda Rajapaksa.

heading: British rugby player dies in Colombo
description:
A British rugby player who was touring Sri Lanka with a club team has died in a private hospital in Colombo due to a respiratory issue.
 
Police said another player is receiving treatment.
 
The deceased was a 26-year-old person, and he had arrived in Sri Lanka on 10th of this month, with a 22-member team.
 
They had played a friendly rugby match on Saturday and thereafter they had dinner at the same place.
 
It was revealed after arriving at their team hotel, few players have gone to a nightclub in Colpetty.
 
The deceased player and other player were hospitalized by the hotel management as they were suffering from respiratory issues.

heading: Kandy riots : 35 suspects including leader of Mahason Balakaya remanded
description:
Theldeniya Magistrate M. H. Farikdeen remanded 35 suspects including the leader of the Mahason Balakaya, Amith Weerasinghe until 28th of this month.
Weerasinghe was taken to Anuradhapura Remand Prison while other 34 suspects were sent to Pallekele Prison.
They are in remand custody over their alleged links with Kandy riots in March this year.

heading: Indian Army Chief in Sri Lanka (Photos)
description:
The Chief of Staff of the Indian Army, General Bipin Rawat has arrived in Sri Lanka.
 
The visiting Indian Army chief who arrived in the yesterday (May 13) will stay in Sri Lanka for 7 days.
 
He is here on the invitation of Sri Lanka Army Commander, Lt. Gen. Mahesh Senanayake.

heading: Heavy rainfall predicted during afternoon
description:
The Met Department says the possibility for afternoon thundershowers is still high over the island.
 
Showers or thundershowers will occur over most provinces of the island, particularly after 2 pm.
 
Showers will occur in Western and Southern provinces and in Puttalam district during the morning too.
 
Heavy falls, about 100mm can be expected at some places, particularly in Central, Sabaragamuwa, Southern,
Uva and Western provinces and in Polonnaruwa and Vavuniya districts.

heading: Verdict given against Duminda not lawful, verdict states evidence could not be accepted as 100% correct
description:
The President Counsels proved before the Supreme Court today (May 10) that the verdict given by the Colombo High Court against former MP Duminda Silva is not lawful.
 
When the Appeal made by former MP Duminda Silva was taken up for consideration today, his President Counsels pointed out that the evidence in every incident that was given to make former MP Duminda Silva guilty are contradictory.
 
They said that the verdict itself states that the evidence given by the witnesses could not be accepted as 100% correct.
 
The Appeal which has been filed by former MP Duminda Silva, requesting the Court to acquit him was taken up for consideration for a 4th day today.
 
It was taken up before a bench of five Supreme Court Judges headed by Chief Justice Priyasad Dep.
 
Making submissions, President Counsel, Anuja Premarathna said that no explanation was made in the verdict about the shortcomings and the contradictions that were found in the false evidence which had been fabricated intending to convict former MP Duminda Silva.
 
Referring to previous judgments, the President Counsel said that the care should be taken when a person is made guilty based on evidence that has shortcomings and contradictions.
 
President Counsel Anuja Premarathna said previous judgments are generally adopted in the judicial tradition, but former MP Duminda Silva has been convicted without taking such traditions into consideration.
 
He repeatedly proved before the Supreme Court that the evidence in every incident that was given to make former MP Duminda Silva guilty are contradictory.
 
The President Counsel said that the verdict itself states that the evidence given by the witnesses could not be accepted as 100% correct.
