The JO MP Bandula Gunawardena said that the IMF is urging the government to implement the fuel pricing formula to release the next tranche of Extended Fund Facility next month.
 
He said that the disagreement is brewing up due to government's failure to implement the fuel pricing formula.

heading: Samurdhi Development Bank put under Central Bank
description:
Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe says that the Samurdhi Development Bank will be vested under the control of the Central Bank.
 
He said this joining the May Day rally of UNP held at the Sugathadasa Stadium.
 
The PM said that although other banks are regulated by the CBSL, for Samurdhi Bank, there's no proper authority.

heading: Six persons drown in Ambalangoda Sea, one dies
description:
Six persons including 2 minors have drowned while bathing in the sea nearby the Ambalangoda Guest House at around 12.45 pm today (May 06).
 
Five of them were admitted to Balapitiya Hospital and police said one of them, a 73-year-old retired member of government administrative service died in the hospital.
 
The others, who are in hospital are a doctor attached to Elpitiya Hospital, his wife - a doctor serving at the Karapitiya Hospital, their 2 daughters aged 3 1/2 and 2 1/2 and a relative.
 
Police said that due to the roughness of sea people were advised in the morning not to venture into the sea.
 
Police said that the group was reportedly bathing at an insecure place.

heading: No dust storms in Sri Lanka - Met Department
description:
The Met Department says Sri Lanka will not face a dust storm similar to what had happened in India.
When contacted the Director of Met Department, Athula Karunanayake said this.
Over 125 persons were killed in a series of dust storms hit Northern India recently.

heading: Maliyadeva cricketer assaulted in busy street
description:
The student who was arrested for allegedly assaulting a school cricketer from Maliyadeva College, Kurunegala has been produced before Kurunegala Magistrate Court.
 
He will be produced before an identification parade.
 
The student who was brutally attacked by several individuals could not attend the court today (May 04).
 
The 16-year-old student was attacked on the Tissa Mawatha in Kuliyapitiya by a group that included a defeated Sri Lanka Freedom Party candidate for Kuliyapitiya Pradeshiya Sabha.
 
The victim who was attacked with a helmet and a shovel were, first admitted to Kuliyapitiya Hospital and thereafter he was transferred to Kurunegala Teaching Hospital.
 
The incident was recorded in a CCTV camera installed at a nearby building...

heading: Colombo Crime Division takes over probe on missing award of late Dr. Lester
description:
The Colombo Crime Division has been tasked with assisting the investigation which is being carried out to locate the missing Golden Peacock or 'Ranamayura' award of late Dr. Lester James Peries.
 
The probe is conducted under the supervision of a DIG.
 
The award was reported missing from the residence of the veteran filmmaker.
 
Police believe someone had taken away the valuable piece when the funeral activities were taking place at the residence on Wednesday (May 02).
 
Police said that video footage was analyzed in an attempt to identify the suspects.
 
However, at this stage, no one is identified.
 
He was awarded the Golden Peacock award in 1965 for Gamperaliya and the veteran filmmaker was awarded the lifetime felicitation award in 2000.

heading: Kalutara private buses on strike
description:
Employees of private buses starting journeys from Kalutara are staging a strike.
They have launched the strike after a private bus driver was assaulted.
The victim is being treated at the Intensive Care Unit of Nagoda Hospital, Kalutara.

heading: Joint Opposition says certain Ministers unhappy
description:
The Joint Opposition says that several new supplementary estimates will be presented in Parliament to meet the huge expenses of the new ministers.
 
Addressing the media at the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna office in Bambalapitiya this morning (May 04), MP Rohitha Abeygunawardana said that some Ministers were unsatisfied by the new cabinet reshuffle.
 
State Minister, Piyasena Gamage has said that he is disappointed that he was not offered a Cabinet portfolio.
 
Gamage has been appointed as the State Minister of Youth Affairs and Southern Development.
 
Meanwhile, Palitha Range Bandara who made controversial statements relating to the restructuring of the United National Party also not offered a Cabinet position.
 
In addition to his previous State ministerial positions, he was offered State Minister portfolio of Disaster Management in the recent reshuffle.

heading: Milk powder price hike effective from midnight
description:
The Cabinet Sub Committee on Cost of Living has recommended that the Consumer Affairs Authority to allow milk powder companies to increase the retail price.
 
Accordingly, a kilo of milk powder will be increased by Rs. 50 and the price of a 400g pack will be increased by Rs. 20.
 
The price revision is effective from midnight today (May 04).
 
However, the price of baby formula will be unchanged.
 
A member of the subcommittee, Minister of Industry, and Commerce Risath Bathuideen said that milk powder importers demanded a hike of 75 rupees per kilogram.
  
The Consumer Affairs Authority recently permitted gas companies to increase the price of a 12.5 kg domestic gas cylinder by Rs. 245.

heading: Raids to curb production of banned polythene continues
description:
Central Environmental Authority says raids to nab manufacturers of banned polythene will be continued.
In September 2017, the production and distribution of non-degradable polythene were banned.
Meanwhile, the investigation officers of the Central Environmental Authority raided a lunch sheet production factory in Mattakkuliya.
They were producing lunch sheets using H. D. P. E. plastic using 4 machines at the time of the raid.
Police who assisted the raid collected the samples of produced lunch sheets and CEA said that legal action will be taken against the factory owners.

heading: Showers to enhance during weekend – Met Department
description:
Met Department says due to a low-level atmospheric disturbance in the vicinity of Sri Lanka, the showery condition is expected to enhance over the island.
 
Showers or thundershowers will occur at several palaces in the most parts of the island after 2 pm.
 
Showers will occur in the Western, Southern and North-Western provinces during the morning too.
 
Heavy falls, above 100 mm can be expected at some places in Southern, Central, Sabaragamuwa, Uva and North-Central provinces and in Kalutara district.
 
Misty conditions can be expected at some places in the Sabaragamuwa and Central provinces during the morning.
 
There may be temporary localized strong winds during thundershowers.
 
The general public is requested to take adequate precautions to minimize damages caused by lightning activity.

heading: Left parties propose Chamal Rajapaksa for Presidential election
description:
MP Vasudeva Nanayakkara says that the Leftist political parties have decided to propose MP Chamal Rajapaksa to contest the forthcoming Presidential Election.
However, responding to the statement by Vasudeva Nanayakkara, MP Chamal Rajapaksa told the media in Kandy today that there are more qualified contenders than him for the job.

heading: Twitter request 'a precautionary measure'
description:
Sri Lanka Computer Emergency Readiness Team says that the request by Twitter to change the passwords of subscribers was a precautionary request.
The Senior Information Technology Engineer of SLCERT, Roshan Chandragupta said the Twitter may have make the request to avoid any danger which could be posed by using improper passwords.
Earlier in the day, Twitter warned its 330 million users to change their passwords after a glitch exposed some in plain text on its internal network.
The social network said an internal investigation had found no indication passwords were stolen or misused by insiders.
However, it still urged all users to consider changing their passwords "out of an abundance of caution".
Twitter did not say how many passwords were affected.

heading: 18 SP's & ASP's given transfers
description:
Police Media Unit announced that one SP and 17 ASP's have been transferred with the recommendation of IGP by the Police Commission.
The ASP's of Presidential Security Division and Terrorism Investigation Division are among the officers transferred.
Accordingly, ASP D. Abeywardena of the PSD has been transferred to the Colombo North Division while ASP H. Fonseka of TID has been transferred to the Vavuniya Division.

heading: Duty free shop worker arrested with Rs. 40mn worth gold
Muslim Congress not to support 20th Amendment
description:
The Sri Lanka Muslim Congress says that as a party they would oppose the 20th Amendment which is aimed at abolishing the Executive Presidency.
The leader of the Muslim Congress Minister Rauf Hakeem said this while expressing views following a visit to Kandy yesterday (May 04).
When the journalists asked the Minister whether there would be an upward price revision in water bills. 
In response, Hakeem said they would be compelled to increase water fares to cut losses.

heading: CCD records 15 statements on cinema veteran’s Lifetime Award
description:
The Colombo Crime Division says they have already recorded statements from 15 persons over the missing lifetime award of late filmmaker Dr. Lester James Peries.
A senior officer said that CCTV footage of the day of the funeral is being analyzed at present.
Although no information has been uncovered regarding any suspects, footage showing an individual stealing a mobile phone from the residence of the late filmmaker is circulating on social media.
Veteran actor Ravindra Randeniya appealed to return the late Dr. Lester James Peries’s lifetime award to be handed it over to the wife of the late filmmaker.

heading: Showers or thundershowers predicted
description:
Met Department says due to a low-level atmospheric disturbance in the vicinity of Sri Lanka, the showery condition is expected to enhance over the island.
Cloudy skies can be expected over the island.
Showers or thundershowers will occur at several palaces in the most parts of the island after 2 pm.
Showers will occur in the Western, Southern and Eastern provinces during the morning too.

heading: Group of independent councillors at Mahiyangana PS joins SLFP
description:
8 councillors who were elected to the Mahiyangana Pradeshiya Sabha as an Independent Group has joined the Sri Lanka Freedom Party.
 
They had obtained the party membership from President Maithripala Sirisena this afternoon (May 03)..

heading: Three suspects arrested over Rs. 18mn gem robbery
description:
On 4th of April, two persons who had arrived on a motorcycle had threatened another person with a weapon who was travelling on another motorcycle and robbed gems worth Rs. 18 million.
The robbery was investigated by the Beruwala Police and yesterday (May 04), 3 suspects were arrested along with the stolen gems.
 
The motorcycle used for the robbery and another car which was used to sell the gems were also apprehended by police.
The suspects aged 24, 31, and 35 are residents of Embilipitiya and Anuradhapura.
They will be produced before Kalutara Magistrate today.

heading: Police seek public support to apprehend 'Navy Sampath'
description:
Police seek public support to arrest Chandana Prasad Hettiarachchi, alias 'Navy Sampath' over the abduction, disappearance and murder of 11 youths during 2008/09.
 
Those abducted were Kasthuriarachchilage John Rit alias John, Rajiv Naganathan alias Malli, Pradeep Vishvanathan, Tillakeshwaran Ramalingam, Mohamed Sajith, Jamamdeen Dilan, Amalan Leon, Roshan Leon, Antony Kasthuriarachchi, Thyagaraja Jegan and Mohamed Ali Anver alias Hajiya.
 
The Criminal Investigation Department is probing the incident and Colombo Fort Magistrate has issued an Open Warrant to arrest him.
 
He was a resident of Wennawatte in Wellampitiya.
 
Information could be provided to:
 
0112 320141
0112 320142
0112 320143
0112 320144
0112 320145
0112 422176

heading: Special Commodity Tax on imported potatoes and big onions increased
description:
Finance Ministry says that the Special Commodity Tax on imported potatoes and big onions have been increased.
 
Accordingly, the SCT on imported big onions which were on Rs. 1 for a kilogramme has now increased up to Rs.40.
 
The Special Commodity Tax on potatoes which were on Rs. 30 per kilogramme has not revised to Rs. 40.
 
The Finance Ministry said this step was taken to protect the domestic farmers.

heading: Wasps close school in Vavuniya (Photos)
description:
Parakum Maha Vidyalaya in Vavuniya was closed temporarily today (May 03).
 
The decision was taken after 4 persons including 2 students were attacked by wasps.

heading: Former President says Presidential candidate will be announced at right time
description:
Former President Mahinda Rajapaksa says that their Presidential candidate will be announced at the right time.
He expressed these views answering to questions raised by Journalists following a programme in Colombo yesterday (May 04).

heading: Met Office issues extreme weather advisories
description:
Met Department has issued a heat weather advisory for Northern, North Central and Eastern provinces.
 
Caution level is expected in some parts of the Northern, North Central and Eastern provinces tomorrow.
 
In isolated places in Polonnaruwa, Anuradhapura, Vavuniya, Mullaitivu and Kilinochchi districts this can go up to Extreme Caution level as well.
 
Meanwhile, the Met Department said severe thunderstorm and heavy rainfall could be prevailing in the Western, Sabaragamuwa, Central, North-western and Southern provinces this evening (May 03).
 
It added that thunderstorms accompanied by severe lightning and thunder are likely to occur in the warning areas during next several (about seven) hours.
 
Fairly heavy rainfalls are expected at some places (above 75 mm) and strong gusty winds up to 70-80 kmph are also possible during thundershowers. 
 
 Seek shelter, preferably indoors and never under trees
 
 Avoid open areas such as paddy fields, tea plantations and open water bodies during thunderstorms
 
 Avoid using wired telephones and connected electric appliances during thunderstorms
 
 Avoid using open vehicles, such as bicycles, tractors and boats etc..
 
 Beware of fallen trees and power lines
 
 For emergency assistance contact the local disaster management authorities

heading: Minister Duminda says SLFP will be strengthened
description:
Minister Duminda Dissanayake says those who have left the Sri Lanka Freedom Party would be united in order to create a strong SLFP.
 
He said this while assuming duties at the Ministry of Irrigation, Water Management and Disaster Management today (May 03).

heading: Peshala Jayaratne new Chairman at National Gem and Jewellery Authority (Photos)
description:
The former Chief Minister of the North Central Province Peshala Jayaratne has been appointed as the new Chairman at National Gem and Jewellery Authority.
 
The appointment was made last afternoon (May 02), the President's Media Division said.

heading: Attempt to smuggle Gold by Indians foiled
description:
Four Indian nationals were apprehended at the Bandaranaike International Airport this morning (May 03) while they were trying to smuggle in 1.737 KG of Gold from India.
 
The arrest was made by the officers of the Katunayake Unit of the Police Narcotic Bureau.
 
The Gold was hidden in the baggage of the suspects, who are aged 26, 27, 35 and 43.

heading: Central Bank annual report portrays economic turmoil
description:
The Patriotic Professionals' Forum says that the country's economic downturn is portrayed in the Central Bank's annual report.
 
They told a media conference held in Colombo today that since the authorities are not concerned about it that the masses should raise concerns.

heading: 32.2 kg of gold smuggled from Sri Lanka seized in Tamil Nadu
description:
In a span of fewer than 24 hours, officers of the Directorate of Revenue Intelligence (DRI), Chennai Zonal Unit, seized a total of 32.249 kg of gold.
 
It was smuggled into India by sea and being transported to Chennai for sale.
 
Six people were apprehended in connection with the case and all of them in their statements admitted that they purposely transported the smuggled gold to Chennai.
 
The gold was being smuggled from Sri Lanka through coastal Tamil Nadu.
 
On Tuesday evening, DRI officials kept a strict vigil in the by-lanes of Mannady and observed a person on a two-wheeler receiving a heavy suspicious looking package.
 
The receiver of the contraband was apprehended by the officials. After detailed examination, the gold was found to weigh 12.149 kg.
 
The accused were staying in a budget lodge at Mannady.
 
DRI officials found a lady passenger carrying the smuggled gold and handing it over to another intermediary who had been staying at the lodge.
 
In a similar incident, DRI conducted a thorough search of a private bus moving from Keelakarai to Chennai, where a person was suspected of carrying smuggled gold.
 
The officials quickly identified him and his baggage and recovered 8.1 kg of gold from him.
 
In all the operations, a total 32.249 kg of gold was seized and six persons were arrested by DRI under the provisions of the Customs Act.
 
DRI warned that gold smuggling has been a recurrent issue in South India, and the coastal areas of Tamil Nadu are particularly prone to this illicit activity, due to its geographical proximity to Sri Lanka.
 
The previous year itself saw DRI Chennai Zonal Unit seizing more than 105 kg of gold smuggled via Sri Lanka through the Tamil Nadu coast.
 
The areas most vulnerable to smuggling are Tiruchendur, Rameswaram and Vedaranyam.
 
Apart from the enforcement measures, the DRI has also taken up the issues of smuggling and other customs-related matters at the policy level during the 28th Indo-Sri Lanka DG Level talks at New Delhi in February this year.
 
As a result, both administrations had firmly resolved to combat smuggling.
 
The Sri Lanka Customs and the Sri Lankan Navy have also stepped up efforts to curb smuggling of gold, narcotics, and other contraband.
 
In April, Sri Lanka increased the rate of import duty on gold to 15 percent (from the earlier rate of 10 percent), in an attempted move to curb smuggling.

heading: ETI depositors stage protest demanding their money
description:
A group of depositors staged a protest at the ETI Finance Limited urging the authorities to repay their money.
 
ETI is a company attached to Edirisinghe Group.
 
These types of protests have been held a number of times by the depositors as of now.
 
The aggrieved depositors started a protest march from nearby the ETI Head Office in Ward Place and proceeded towards the President's Official Residence in Mahagamasekera Road.
 
These people who had come there with an intention of collecting their money demanded to return their savings and remove the 4 directors of the company.

heading: President's Chief of Staff arrested by Bribery Commission
description:
President's Media Division says that President Maithripala Sirisena has paid his attention towards the arrest of a senior officer at the Presidential Secretariat and a chairman of a state corporation.
 
He had ordered to interdict the services of the suspected officials and take stern legal actions against them without any interference.
 
In this case, President's Chief of Staff Dr. I. H. K. Mahanama and State Timber Corporation Chairman P. Dissanayaka were arrested by the Bribery Commission this evening (May 03) while accepting a bribe of Rs.20 million from an Indian businessman.
 
Dr. Mahanama was earlier the Secretary to the Ministry of Lands and Parliamentary Reforms.

heading: Customers catch bank robber
description:
A group of customers with the support of a security officer have been able to foil a robbery at a private bank in Elakanda, Wattala.
 
Police said at around 2.30 pm yesterday (May 03), a 30-year-old person had attempted to rob money from the woman who was at a collection counter, after throwing chili powder at her.
 
Then the customers along with a security officer acted swiftly and apprehended the criminal.
 
He was a resident of Rukgahawila.
 
Police have taken into custody the money amounting to Rs. 11,082,160 that the suspect attempted to rob.
 
He will be produced before Wattala magistrate today.

heading: Heat advisory : Parents urged to have a close eye on toddlers
description:
Health authorities are requesting the public to take precautions to ensure prevention of dehydration, especially amongst children due to the extremely high temperatures being experienced in many parts of the island.
 
The Met Department announced that excessively high temperatures are predicted in the North, North Central, and Eastern provinces today (May 04).
 
The Department warns residents in Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa, Vavuniya, Mullaitivu and Kilinochchi districts to be cautious.

heading: Minister Ganesan rejects to have Office of Missing Persons
description:
Minister Mano Ganesan has requested the President to exclude the subjects such as Office of Missing Persons, Office for National Unity and Reconciliation from his Ministry’s’ purview.
 
He said that the two subjects should come under the President considering the national interests.
 
The Office of Missing Persons is currently coming under the President while Office for National Unity and Reconciliation is chaired by former President Chandrika Kumaratunga.

heading: Flights delay continues
description:
Bandaranaike International Airport announces that 3 flights that are scheduled to depart from the airport will be delayed today (May 04).
 
Accordingly, the flight UL 165 which was due to take off at 7.35 am will leave the BIA at 12.30 pm.
 
The flight UL 129 to Chennai scheduled to leave at 8.35 am will now depart at 10.10 am.
 
The BIA said that the flight UL 281 which was originally scheduled to depart at 2.25 pm will now take off at 5.05 pm.
 
The Sri Lankan Airlines yesterday announced flight delays will be experienced due to prevailing dust storms in India and technical glitches experienced by several aircraft.

heading: Fmr. intelligence chief re-remanded
description: Former Army Intelligence Director Retired Major General Amal Karunasekera who was arrested over assault on journalist Keith Noyahr has been further remanded till 16th of May.

heading: Glyphosate ban removed for tea & rubber
description:
The ban on weedicide Glyphosate has been removed for tea and rubber sectors.
 
Minister Plantation Industries Navin Dissanayake confirmed this.

heading: Dust storms & technical glitches delay SriLankan flights
description:
SriLankan Airlines says a number of flights to Melbourne, Jeddah, Kuala Lumpur and Bangkok are experiencing prolonged delays due to a dust storm in India and other technical issues.
 
The airline said a flight from the Middle East was forced to land in Kochin, India after a passenger fell ill causing delays.
 
Meanwhile, another flight from Kuwait encountered technical issues after it caught in a dust-storm.
 
A statement issued by the national carrier said 2 other planes have encountered technical glitches causing prolong delays.

heading: Hot weather advisory issued
description:
Heat Weather Advisory has been issued for Northern, North Central, Eastern, Uva and North Western provinces and Matale and Hambanthota districts by the Met Department.
 
Caution level is expected in most parts of the Northern, North Central and Eastern provinces.
 
Caution level can also be expected in some parts of the North Western and Uva provinces and Matale and Hambantota districts tomorrow. In isolated places in the Polonnaruwa district, the level can go up to Extreme Caution level as well.

heading: Locomotive operators to take a trade union action next week
description:
The Locomotive Engineering Operators' Union says they will move away from operating trains with Chinese built compartments from Tuesday (May 08).
 
The Secretary of the Union Indika Dodangoda said this decision was reached at their Executive Committee meeting today (May 02).
 
He said that the Union had also decided to stop operating trains on the Kelaniweli Line.

heading: Late Dr. Peiris' honorary medal stolen
Police probe underway to locate late Dr. Peiris’ award
description:
Police have commenced an investigation to identify the perpetrator who had robbed a precious award from the residence of the late legendary cinematographer Dr. Lester James Peiris, yesterday (May 02).
 
The missing award has been identified as the Ranamayura award, awarded to Dr. Peiris at the New Delhi Film festival in 1965 for his film Gampereliya.
 
Police Media Spokesperson SP Ruwan Gunasekera said that a complaint on this had been lodged at Bambalapitiya Police and investigations are underway by previewing video footage.
 
According to the complaint, the award may have been lifted when the religious observances were taking place at his Thimbirigasyaya residence before the cortege left there.

heading: No price increase for milk powder
description:
The Ministry of Industry and Commerce has decided not to permit to increase of milk powder price anymore.
 
However, a senior Ministry spokesperson said that further study was being carried out regarding the action that should be taken to prevent importers from falling into difficulties due to the price fluctuations in the world market.
 
While the price of a metric tonne of milk powder in the world market ranges between $ 3250 and 3350, reports say that there is a possibility that price would rise to $ 3400 and 3500 during the next 2 months.
 
Under these conditions, milk powder importing companies have submitted requests for at least Rs. 75 price increase.
 
Reports also say that if a price increase was not granted, the milk powder importers have decided to restrict imports.

heading: Party leaders discuss new Parliamentary session
description:
The party leaders met at the Parliamentary Complex under the patronage of speaker Karu Jayasuriya this morning (May 03).
 
Matters with regard to the new parliamentary session which is to commence on 8th of May were among the topics discussed.
 
Meanwhile, a Joint Opposition party leaders’ and MPs met yesterday under the patronage of former President Mahinda Rajapaksa.
 
It was held at the former President’s official residence in Wijerama.
 
During the meeting, views have been exchanged regarding the May Day celebrations and the new Parliamentary Session.

heading: Traffic restrictions on New Kelani Bridge
description:
Police say that vehicular traffic on the New Kelani Bridge will be restricted from today to 5th of May due to renovations.
 
The motorists are urged to utilize alternative roads to avoid traffic congestion.

heading: Famous artist kills wife using a dumbbell
description:
A famous paint-artist has attacked his wife with a dumbbell, which is used for weight training, following a domestic dispute.
 
The 27-year-old wife had died at Wathupitiwela Hospital while being treated.
The incident had taken place at Katuwasgoda, Veyangoda yesterday (May 02).
Police said the couple was fighting frequently and yesterday the husband had attacked his wife following a domestic dispute.
Later, she was admitted to hospital with critical injuries.
Police arrested the husband and the postmortem will be held today.

heading: Devotees in large numbers pay homage to Kapilawasthupura Niseka Sri Sarvagna relics
description:
Having concluded the exposition organized by Hiru TV and Hiru FM under Hiru Uththama Dhathu Vandana to mark Vesak, the Kapilawasthupura Niseka Sri Sarvagna relics are now being taken back to Sri Subhuthi temple in Waskaduwa. 
 
The exposition of the exact sacred relics of Kapilawasthupura commenced under Hiru Uththama Dhathu Vandana program at the Jethawanaramaya sacred site last Monday.
 
The relics were placed in a special shrine by the chairman of Asia Broadcasting Corporation, Mr. Rayynor Silva before the exposition began for the public.
 
The journey began yesterday (May 02) from sacred Jethawanaramaya in Anuradhapura where the exposition of exact sacred relics was held.

heading: Public urged to be vigilant over lightning
description:
Met Department says that the prevailing rainy condition in the island is expected to enhance from tomorrow (May 04).
Showers or thundershowers will occur at several palaces in the most parts of the island after 2 pm.
Showers will occur in the Western, North-western and Southern coastal areas during the morning too.
Fairly heavy falls, about 75mm can be expected in Central and Sabaragamuwa provinces and in Galle, Matara, Anuradhapura and Vavuniya districts.
There may be temporary localized strong winds during thundershowers and the general public is requested to take adequate precautions to minimize damages caused by lightning activity.
The Met Department added that due to the active cloudiness in the Southern and western sea areas, the possibility for heavy showers/thundershowers and sudden roughness, associated with a sudden increase of wind speed (up to 70-80 kmph) in the sea areas off the coast extending from Colombo to Potuvil via Hambantota is high.
It requested the Naval and fishing communities to be vigilant in this regard.
Showers or thundershowers will occur at several places in the sea areas off the coast extending from Colombo to Batticaloa via Galle and Hambantota. Heavy showers will occur in the deep sea areas to the South-East of the island.
Winds will be Westerly to South-westerly in the direction of the sea areas around the island and speed will be 20-30 kmph.
Wind speed can increase up to 40-50 kmph in the sea areas off the coast extending from Puttalam to Kankasanturai via Mannar and Matara to Potuvil via Hambantota.
Temporarily very strong gusty (up to 70-80 kmph) winds and rough seas can be expected during thundershowers.

heading: Gotabhaya says war heroes in dire straits
description:
Former Defence Secretary Gotabhaya Rajapaksa says at present the war heroes are inconvenienced both locally in internationally.
 
He said this addressing an event in Colombo yesterday (May 02).

heading: Govt. Policy Statement to be debated on May 10
description:
The party leaders have decided to hold a one day debate on 10th of May 10 Government's Policy Statement to be delivered on 8th of May at the inaugural session of new Parliament.
The decision was reached at the Party Leaders' meeting held at the Parliament, this morning (May 03).

heading: Makandura fuel station robbed
description:
Two persons arrived in a car had ransacked a fuel station in Gonawela in Makandura early this morning (May 03).
 
The robbers have come wearing face masks.
 
Police said the 2 men had threatened the workers with firearms and then collected around Rs. 70,000 before fleeing.

heading: Woman jumps out of moving three-wheeler (CCTV)
description:
A mother of two children in Dehigasmulla, Matugama, has died after a jumping out of a moving three-wheeler.
 
She had admitted to Nagoda Hospital in Kalutara where she had succumbed to her injuries.
 
The victim was aged 26 years.
 
It is reported on 29th of April, after work, she had got into a three-wheeler to go home.
 
However, when the three-wheeler sped away without stopping at her destination, she had jumped out from it.
 
Thereafter, the area residents have forced the three-wheeler driver to hospitalize the woman.
 
However, later police found the woman abandoned in a by-road in Matugama town.
 
Police are looking out for information on the three-wheeler.

heading: Milk powder prices increased
description: Minister Rishath Bathiudeen says that the Cost of Living Committee recommended Consumer Affairs Authority to increase the price of a 400g packet of milk powder by Rs.20 and a kilo by Rs.50.

heading: One killed in Wellawaya accident
description:
One person was killed when a van and a motorcycle collided head-on in Weherayaya on the Wellawaya - Thanamalwila main road early this morning (May 03).
 
The deceased, the motorcyclist, was a resident of Andawelayaaya in Wellawaya.
 
He was aged 25 years.
 
Police have arrested the van driver, a resident of Dickwella.

heading: President's Chief of Staff  & STC chairman remanded
description:
President's Chief of Staff and Chairman of State Timber Corporation who were arrested for allegedly obtaining a bribe have been remanded until 9th of May.
 
The suspects were produced before Colombo Chief Magistrate Lal Ranasinghe Bandara this morning (May 04).

heading: LTTE armoury detected in Vishwamadu (Photos)
description:
Special Task Force has detected an abandoned armoury of LTTE following a tip-off in the Vishwamadu area in Mullaitivu.
 
The area was searched after obtaining a court order.
 
736 mortars, 6 hand grenades, 2 Rocket Propelled Grenade launchers, several parts of T-56 weapons, 80 anti-aircraft ammunition and several grenades were among the arms cache.
 
Police said this was the largest arms cache found in the Puthukudiiruppu area.
 
The detected arms cache will be defused by the STF.

heading: New plant similar to mukunuwanna affects kidneys
description:
The Medical Researchers say that a plant similar to mukunuwenna which causes kidney disease is spreading throughout the island.
According to the Senior Lecturer of Rajarata University, Dr. Channa Jayasumana, this new plant is identified as kimbulwenna and it has a high potential of absorbing a large quantity of toxic components which could affect the kidney.
Meanwhile, the Director General of Department of Agriculture, Dr. W. M. W. Weerakoon said although kimbulwenna plant spread in the country several years ago, there were no reports of the spread of this plant recently.
However, he said that he would look into the matter.

heading: Foreign liquor racket foiled (photos)
description:
Customs Revenue Task Force staff has detected a large haul of illegally imported foreign liquor, cigarettes, and hashish.
 
Customs said there were 282 whiskey bottles, 253 wine bottles, 46 beer bottles and 1,000 sticks of cigarettes were detected.
 
The total value of the contraband which was brought in a 40-foot container containing unaccompanied passenger baggage was worth around Rs. 1.7 million.

heading: Artists appeal return of missing Ranamayura award
description:
The cinema artists request the return of the missing ‘Ranamayura Award’ of late Dr. Lester James Peiris.
 
It is believed that the award may have been stolen by somebody at his residence yesterday (May 02).
 
Meanwhile, Minister of Law and Order, Ranjith Madduma Bandara has instructed police to conduct a proper investigation into this incident.
 
Accordingly, a DIG has been assigned to conduct the investigations.
 
At the same time, Bambalapitiya police have initiated an investigation by previewing video clips.
 
Late, Dr. Lester James Peiris was conferred with the Ranamayura Award for Gamperaliya in New Delhi in 1965.

heading: Late Lester James Peries' missing award found
description:
The lifetime award of late Lester James Peries' which was missing since May 2 has been found.
It is reported that the missing honourary award was abandoned at a bus in Colpetty.
Police said that the award was found inside a Kaduwela - Colpetty private bus at around 8 am today (May 05).
Then the driver and the conductor of the bus have informed the Colpetty Police about it.
Now the award is in the custody of the Colpetty Police.

heading: Student drowns in a tank
description:
A school student had drowned in the Kithanawela Wewa in Athuraliya, Akuressa.
Yesterday, the student had suddenly disappeared while he was bathing in the tank.
Thereafter, the area residents who conducted a search in the tank found the body.
The victim was aged 16 and was studying in grade 11 at Athuraliya Maha Vidyalaya.

heading: Sumithra Peiries identifies Ranamayura award
description:
The lifetime award of veteran filmmaker, late Dr. Lester James Peries which was reported missing has been found in a private bus.
It was found at around 8 am.
Police Media Spokesperson SP Ruwan Gunasekara said that the award was found in the overhead rack of a private bus operating on the 177 route from Kaduwela to Colpetty.
Later, the bus driver and the conductor had alerted the police.
Now the bus is kept at the Colpetty Police.
The widow of late Dr. Peries, Sumithra Peries had identified the award.
Police said the award will be returned after investigations are completed.

heading: Two arrested with heroin
description:
Police Narcotic Bureau arrested two persons including a woman while transporting 100g of heroin in a luxury jeep.
The arrest was made in Thalgahawila on the Padukka - Horana road.
The arrest was made yesterday (May 05) and then thereafter the suspects were remanded.

heading: SLFP's "Group of 16" to form alliance with MR
description:
The Sri Lanka Freedom Party's 16 parliamentarians who had recently left the Unity Government say that they are ready to form an alliance with former President Mahinda Rajapaksa.
 
MP W. D. J. Seneviratne made this statement addressing a press briefing held in Ratnapura today (May 06).

heading: Sri Lanka seeks details of arrested Sri Lankans from Malaysia
description:
Ministry of Foreign Affairs says the officials of Sri Lanka High Commission in Malaysia is working closely with the Malaysian authorities in relation to the arrest of 131 illegal immigrants of Sri Lankan origin.
 
The Royal Malaysian Police Special Branch earlier confirmed that 131 persons believed to be Sri Lankans have been detained at Tanjung Gamoh, Sedili, in Johor Baru on 1
 of May.
 
Out of the 131 persons, 127 have been arrested under the Immigration Act 1959/63.
 
They are presently detained at Pekan Nenas Immigration Detention Centre in Johor Baru.
 
The remaining 4 persons have been arrested under the Anti-Trafficking in Persons and Anti-Smuggling of Migrants Act of 2007 and are also detained.
 
While the identities of the 131 persons are still in the process of being determined, initial information indicates that 43 of the 131 persons arrested hold identity cards issued by the UN Refugee Agency, the Ministry said.

heading: 5 arrested over stealing of Ranamayura Lifetime Medal
description:
Five persons have been arrested in connection with the stealing of the Golden Peacock Lifetime Medal of late veteran film director Dr.
Lester James Peries.
The medal was thought to have gone missing on Wednesday (May 02), at the time of the funeral of late Dr. Peries.
A senior police officer conducting the investigation said that the suspects had been apprehended during raids conducted in Kaduwela, Matugama and Navalapitiya.
Ongoing investigations are being carried out by a special police team.

heading: Ravi, Malik, Kabir and several backbenchers unavailable for UNP May Day rally
description:
The United National Party conducted their May Day rally at the Sugathadasa Indoor Stadium, under the patronage of Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe.
 
The rally began at 10 am.
 
However, former Chairman Malik Samarawickrema, current Chairman Kabir Hashim, former Minister Ravi Karunanayake were not present at the rally.
 
Palitha Range Bandara, Dilip Wedararachchi and Chaminda Wijesiri were also unavailable as they had said there were sick.
 
Meanwhile, Matale district MP Wasantha Aluvihare yesterday (May 05) said that he will skip the rally as he’s not happy with the recent party restructuring.

heading: S. B. says no division in SLFP
description:
President Maithripala Sirisena says that the Sri Lanka Freedom Party will move forward transforming it into a fully democratic party.
The President said this addressing the SLFP’s May Day rally in Batticaloa yesterday (May 07).
Meanwhile, of the 16 parliamentarians who resigned from the Unity Government last month, S. B. Dissanayake and Sumedha G. Jayasena took their seats on the stage yesterday.
MPs Dayasiri Jayasekera, Thilanga Sumathipala and Dilan Perera were present at the rally. But they refrained from taking their seats on the stage.

heading: Value of Ranamayura medal to be estimated
description:
Police say that the Golden Peacock Lifetime medal of late Dr. Lester James Peries, which was recovered on Saturday (May 05) will be handed over to the National Gem and Jewellery Authority to obtain an estimate of its value.
 
The Colombo Additional Magistrate Daminda Weligodapitiya remanded the 6 suspects arrested in connection with the theft until the 21st of May.
 
It has also been decided that a case will be filed against the suspects at the High Court.
 
The award presented by India to Dr. Lester James Peries went missing from his home during the funeral proceedings on 2nd of May.
 
Then police launched a massive operation and the medal was found being abandoned in the private bus.
 
Police identified the suspects using CCTV footages and they are residents of Gampola.

heading: Traffic congestion at Parliament junction
description:
Traffic congestion has been reported at the Parliament Junction right now.
It has been created as supporters of 16 Sri Lanka Freedom Party MPs who quit the government and sat in opposition are preparing to welcome them.
They say in the opposition benches when the parliamentary session was inaugurated today (May 08).

heading: Duminda treated unfairly - Verdict intended to make him guilty – Verdict contains many shortcomings
description:
Two President Counsels proved before the Supreme Court today (May 08) that the verdict given by the Colombo High Court against former MP Duminda Silva is illegitimate.
When the Appeal by former MP Duminda Silva was taken for consideration today, his President Counsels pointed out that the verdict on former MP Duminda Silva has a lot of faults thereby proving that it has been given with the intention of convicting the former MP.
The Appeal by former MP Duminda Silva requesting the Court to acquit him was first taken for consideration before a bench of 5 Supreme Court Judges chaired by Chief Justice Priyasath Dep on March 27th.
Making submissions for the Appellant, President Counsel, and Anil de Silva who pointed out the faults of the High Court verdict said that it was schemed to convict former MP Duminda Silva.
He said that the verdict has been given by the Judge solely based on the statements made by the State Counsels. The Judge has not scrutinized whether the evidence was proved beyond reasonable doubt.
The President Counsel pointed out before the Supreme Court that Duminda Silva was accused of using firearms but no evidence was given during the trial to prove such charges.
He further stated that irrelevant evidence was given with regard to other charges as well. He said that 62 contradictions and shortcomings were marked during the trial.
The President Counsel said that such benefits of the doubt should have been given to the Duminda Silva faction but the Judge has neglected to do so.
 
In addition, the President Counsel logically proved that incidents were concocted intending to make Duminda Silva guilty.
 
He pointed out that the shooting at Duminda Silva was instigated by Bharatha Lakshman faction. However such action was completely overlooked by the judge when she issued her verdict.
 
President Counsel Anil de Silva further pointed out before the Supreme Court that the High Court has ignored the say by the Duminda Silva faction or Defence submissions and has conducted trial solely based on the fictitious incidents and evidence.
He said that this Case was filed to tarnish the image of former MP Duminda Silva, therefore, he was denied of a justifiable trial similar to that of any other citizen is entitled to in this Case.
 
Therefore, President Counsel Anil Silva requested the Supreme Court to overrule the verdict which has unlawfully sentenced former MP Duminda Silva and acquit him from all the charges.
 
Later, the Case was taken before the bench of 5 Supreme Court judges again for the third day today.
 
Making submissions before the Court, President Counsel Anuja Premarathna also stated that the verdict given against former MP Duminda Silva was unlawful.
 
The President Counsel who pointed out the shortcomings of the verdict under 10 factors said that the verdict was given neither on the evidence nor on the submissions. He said it was given on the fact that Duminda Silva is a popular political icon.
 
He further said that although the verdict is read one hundred thousand times, it is not possible to understand why Duminda Silva has been convicted.
 
The President Counsel said that the shortcomings and contradictions of the false evidence that created to make Duminda Silva guilty, have been marked during the trial.
 
Quoting the evidence of the High Court, the President Counsel stated that the Court did not explain the reason to not consider such doubts before it gave a unilateral verdict.
 
He said that the High Court has given a sentence for possessing a firearm without any evidence to prove it.
 
The President Counsel said that the verdict by the High Court itself has stated that a single Judge of the three-member bench has no authority to mete out punishment.
Thus, President Counsel Anuja Premarathna proved before the bench of five Supreme Court Judges that the verdict which convicted former MP Duminda Silva is neither an actual nor an authentic verdict.
The Appeal will be called again for further trial on this Thursday.

heading: Cabinet approves removal of glyphosate ban
description: Minister Daya Gamage says that the Cabinet approval was granted to remove the ban on the use of glyphosate for tea and rubber.

heading: LG candidate remanded for assaulting Maliyadeva student
description:
The defeated Local Government candidate who is accused of assaulting a Maliyadeva College student recently was remanded until 11th of this month.
 
Another suspect, a 16-year-old student was also remanded.
 
They assaulted the Maliyadeva student on 28th of last month in Tissa Mawatha, Kuliyapitiya.
 
The suspects were produced before Kuliyapitiya Magistrate today (May 08).

heading: Galle hit by flash floods (Photos)
description:
Disaster Management Center says that around 7700 persons and the Galle district and 635 persons in Beruwela, Kalutara have been affected by the flash floods.
The reports say that around 20 Gramaseva Divisions in the Kadawathsathara Divisional Secretariat area have also been affected by flash floods.
The Divisional Secretary said that there were few incidents of earth-slips as well.
Meanwhile, the Met Department said that those thundershowers of around 100mm could hit Central, Sabaragamuwa, Uva and Western provinces tomorrow (May 13).

heading: Timely police action catch a would-be murderer (Photos)
description:
Police have arrested a man along with a locally made gun while he was venturing out of his home to commit a murder.
The arrest was made today (May 13) in the Suriyawewa area.
Police found the gun along with 2 ammunition in the possession of the suspect.
The suspect had confessed that he had brought the gun to commit a murder.
The suspect, a resident of Suriyawewa was aged 42 and he will be produced before Hambantota court tomorrow.

heading: Three hints on 2020 Presidential candidates
description:
Sri Lanka's next Presidential election will be held in 2020, which is just 18 months away.
 
The political parties are hinting of their candidates for that crucial election.
 
Speaking to the media following an event in Kuruwita, Ratnapura today (May 13) former Minister MP W. D. J. Seneviratne said at any future election they would work under the leadership of former President Mahinda Rajapaksa.
 
Meanwhile, following a rally in Kandy, Minister Lakshman Kiriella said that the United National Party's 2020 candidate will be Ranil Wickremesinghe.
 
In the meantime, Minister Mahinda Amaraweera said that Sri Lanka Freedom Party will field President Maithripala Sirisena for 2020 Presidential election.

heading: Police raid Facebook friends' party
description:
Police have raided a party organized by a group of Facebook friends in Hikkaduwa.
The raid was carried out early last morning (May 13).
19 persons were arrested during the raid for having narcotics in their possession.
7 youths were arrested for the possession of drugs, of those 7, 3 were females.
 
9 grams of marijuana, 16 lollipops containing lethal intoxicants and 50 milligrams of cocaine were seized by police.
 
Police Media Spokespersons office noted that 12 of the 19 arrested have been released on bail.
 
The hotel was raided by Meetiyagoda police, with the assistance of officers from Karandeniya and Baddegama police stations after obtaining a search warrant from the Galle Magistrate Court.

heading: Cabinet approves Long-term Power Generation Plan
description:
Minister Mahinda Amaraweera says that the Cabinet has approved the Long-term Power Generation Plan during the weekly Cabinet meeting today (May 09).
 
The CEB Engineers' Union launched a work-to-rule campaign yesterday citing that Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka is delaying approving the Long-term Power Generation Plan.

heading: SLPP says government should hold general election
description:
Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna says the patience of masses is going beyond the limit as a result of the existing economic woes in the country.
 
The Chairman of the SLPP. Prof. G. L. Peiris addressing a media conference in Colombo today (May 14) that under these circumstances that the government should call the general election without delay.
 
However, responding to the media, Minister Mano Ganesan in Deniyaya yesterday (May 13) said that the Presidential election should be conducted before the Provincial Council election.

heading: Fishermen in Western, Wayamba and South suspend fishing activities
description:
The fishermen in the Western, North-Western and Southern coastal belts who are engaging in traditional fishing methods have suspended fishing activities over the rising fuel prices.
 
They had raised black flags at fisheries harbours to show their protest.
 
The protests by the fishing community have contributed to increasing the retail price of fish.
 
It was revealed that tuna which was sold at Rs. 300 to Rs. 350 per kilo has now risen to Rs. 600.
 
The prices of other fish varieties have also gone up.

heading: Death sentence after 26 years
description:
The Colombo High Court today (May 14) sentenced a resident of Negombo for shooting down a person and then snatch the gold chain of the house owner.
 
The incident had occurred in 1992 in Maligawatte.
 
The convicted person was aged 62.

heading: Drug over-dose ‘cause’ of British ruggerite’s death ?
description:
Initial investigations have revealed that the visiting British rugby player who died of breathing difficulties had overdosed on narcotics and liquor.
 
The deceased rugby player’s colleague who was also fallen ill after consuming excessive amounts of drugs is currently receiving treatment in the intensive care unit of a private hospital in Colombo.
 
22-members of the ‘Clems Pirates Rugby team’ from the United Kingdom arrived in the island on 11
 of May to participate in 2 friendly matches in Colombo.
 
After having dinner hosted by the Colombo rugby club, the two victims had visited a nightclub in Colpetty.
 
However, last morning (May 13), they had complained of breathing difficulties.
 
The management of the team hotel had admitted them into a private hospital in Colombo.
 
Police said the 26-year old died at the private hospital and his teammate is in critical condition.
 
The narcotics that were consumed by the two victims have not yet been identified.
 
The Colombo Fort Police said that the postmortem of the deceased will be conducted after his relatives arrive in Sri Lanka from Northern Ireland.

heading: Gammanpila urges government to withdraw 19th amendment
description:
The Pivithuru Hela Urumaya urges the government to withdraw the 19th amendment to the constitution.
 
Addressing a media conference in Colombo today (May 14), the PHU General Secretary MP Udaya Gammanpila said it is the 19th amendment that is blocking the re-entry of former President Mahinda Rajapaksa to power.

heading: SDIG Nanayakkra further remanded
description:
Former Senior DIG Prasanna Nanayakkara and former Mount Lavinia Crimes OIC Tissasiri Sugathapala have been further remanded till 25
 of May.
 
They were remanded by the Mount Lavinia Magistrate over the case of Lasantha Wickrematunge murder.
 
The 2 policemen are accused of concealing and destroying evidence.

heading: Duminda convicted for charges not mentioned in the indictment
description:
The President’s Counsels proved before the Supreme Court today (May 14) that although there is evidence to prove that former MP Duminda Silva was shot at first, neglecting such evidence, an unlawful verdict has been given against the former MP.
 
The appeal filed by former MP Duminda Silva was taken again before a bench of five Supreme Court Judges led by the Chief Justice, Priyasath Dep.
 
The Appeal which has been filed by former MP Duminda Silva, requesting the Court to acquit him was taken for consideration for a 5
 day today.
 
President’s Counsel Anuja Premarathna stated that it is proven during several testifying in the High Court trial that former MP Duminda Silva was shot at first and the President Counsel argued then how does the High Court verdict state that such proofs are immaterial.
 
Further, the President’s Counsel pointed out that the Judicial Medical report too has also authenticated that gunshots had hit former MP Duminda Silva’s forehead.
 
Later, he quoted a statement made by the 12th defendant from his Court box.
 
His statement describes that the CID asked him to admit to the shooting and, he was named the 12th defendant and indicted him as he did not plead guilty to a crime he never committed.
 
The President Counsel stated although the statement by the 12th defendant has been recognized as faithful in the same verdict, that special statement has not been properly evaluated in this verdict although a statement made from a Court box is considered to be of paramount importance.
 
President Counsel Anuja Premarathna who pointed out that action has been taken to make former MP Duminda Silva guilty of charges which are not filed in the indictment against him said that such action is not lawful whatsoever.
 
He further proved that there were no common objectives as both factions met in the incident accidentally.
 
In addition, the President Counsels pointed out again several more omissions in the verdict today.
 




 




 




 




 




 




 




 
Concluding his oral submissions, President’s Counsel, Anuja Premarathna emphasized again today that although this verdict, full of contradictions and omissions is read one hundred thousand times, it is not possible to understand why former MP Duminda Silva has been convicted.
 
The appeal will be taken for further hearing on May 18th.

heading: Gold smuggling attempt foiled at BIA
description:
Customs officials at the Bandaranaike International Airport have apprehended a Sri Lankan passenger returning from Chennai with 4 gold biscuits.
 
He was arrested at around 11.10 am today (May 14).
 
The value of the gold was around Rs. 2.2 million.
 
The suspect, a resident of Hatton is aged 63.

heading: China to fund 1st phase of Central Expressway
description:
Chinese Ambassador to Sri Lanka says that China will fund $ 1 billion for the phase I of the Central Expressway construction.
 
Cheng Xueyuan conveyed this to Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe during a meeting in Colombo today (May 14).
 
He said that instructions have been given to Chinese EXIM bank to process the loan.
 
The ambassador requested the Sri Lankan side to expedite administrative and legal formalities.
 
The Prime Minister’s Office said that the Chinese ambassador also discussed Hambantota port project and Colombo Port City project.
 
With regard to Hambantota Port, Chinese ambassador had mentioned that they encourage investors to set up factories for producing high-end products.
 
The last tranche for the payment of Hambantota port is due on 9th of June.  
 
The Chinese ambassador had also requested the PM to expedite the negotiations for the signing of Chinese Free Trade Agreement.

heading: Heroin trafficker arrested with a firearm
description:
Police have arrested a drug trafficker in Galpothugoda in Pugoda.
 
The arrest was made following a raid conducted by Police Narcotic Bureau yesterday.
 
The detected 151.1g of heroin, a foreign-made firearm and 13 ammunition from the suspect.
 
The suspect aged 41 and was a resident of Galpothugoda.
 
On information provided by him, police attempted to arrest another drug trafficker.
 
However, he was able to flee abandoning the car in which he came.
 
Later police found 500g of heroin in the car.
 
The suspect was identified as a resident of Ranaala.

heading: Fishermen suspend agitation campaign
Traffic congestion in Ward Place
description:
A traffic congestion is reported from the Ward Place area, Colombo due to a protest by the Inter-University Bhikku Front.
 
They are staging this protest accusing the authorities of removing Buddhist Philosophy from the university study stream.

heading: Fmr. Military Intelligence Director further remanded
description:
Former Military Intelligence Director Former Military Intelligence Director, Retired Major General Amal Karunasekara further remanded until 30th of May over the abduction and assault of journalist Keith Noyahr.
The case was taken up before Mount Lavinia Additional Magistrate Lochana Abeywickrema.

heading: Car collides with moving train at a level crossing (CCTV footage)
description:
A mother and her daughter sustained critical injuries when the car that they were travelling hit a moving train at an unprotected level crossing at Palpolawatte, Meegoda.
 
The injured were admitted to Homagama Hospital.
 
A CCTV camera installed at a nearby shop had captured the accident.

heading: Bodies of mother & 4-year-old daughter found in a canal
description:
Bodies of a 30-year-old mother and her 4-year-old daughter were found in a canal in Dehiattakandiya.
 
The canal was taking water from the Bihirisorowwa Tank.
 
Police found the bodies this afternoon.
 
It is suspected that they might have died of drowning and Dehiattakandiya Police probe the incident.

heading: 3100 persons die in road accidents
description:
The National Council for Road Safety says in 2017, 3100 persons had died in road accidents.
 
The Councils Chairman, Dr. Sisira Kodagoda said 4320 persons were fully disabled because of road accidents last year.
 
He also said 8 persons die due to road accidents in Sri Lanka each day.

heading: Private bus workers demand wage hike
description:
Lanka Private Passenger Transport Workers' Union says with the latest bus fare hike, the wages of the private bus employees should also increase by 10%.
 
Yesterday, the government agreed to upwardly revise the bus fares by 12.5%.
 
The General Secretary of the union, Sumithra Kumaradasa Kuliyapitiya said if wages are not increased within the next 2 weeks, they will launch an island-wide strike.
 
The All Ceylon Private Bus Unions Federation's Secretary Anjana Priyanjith said as a result of bus fares are increased by 12.5%, they could be able to increase the wages of the bus employees.
 
However, Lanka Private Bus Owners' Association's Gamunu Wijeratne said wages of bus employees could not be increased as such.

heading: Minister Rajitha's statement draws ire
description:
Diverse views were expressed at media conferences today (May 17) on the statement made by Co-Cabinet Spokesperson Minister Rajitha Senaratne during the Cabinet media briefing yesterday.
 
Here, he said naming May 18, which was the date that LTTE leader V. Prabakaran was found dead, as a day of mourning in the Northern Province, is not an issue for the government.
 
Meanwhile, Joint Opposition MP Mahindananda Aluthgamage, after coming out of the Supreme Court attending a court case said this shows that the government is in agreement with taking war heroes to the courts.
 
Addressing the media in Colombo today, MP Udaya Gammanpila said if the terrorists are allowed to be commemorated that all the detainees in prisons should be freed.
 
He said those detainees have not committed large-scale crimes.
 
Meanwhile, the Propaganda Secretary of the JVP, MP Vijitha Herath said that JVP had never acted as a terrorist organization.
 
He said this in response to Minister Senaratne's statement who compared the past actions of the JVP to that of LTTE actions.
 
The MP said people including J. R. Jayawardena and Rajitha Senaratne took steps to outlaw their party.
 
He also said Rajitha Senaratne involved in handling killer squads through 'Pra'.

heading: SLFP’s “Group of 16” to meet MR
description:
The 16 Sri Lanka Freedom Party members who recently quit the Unity Government say they will have a discussion with former President Mahinda Rajapaksa this Sunday (May 20).
 
Addressing a media conference in Colombo this morning, a member of the group, former Minister, Lakshman Yapa Abeywardana disclosed it.
 
Meanwhile, MP Dayasiri Jayasekera said they are not a part of the government now.

heading: Fines on parking meter violations suspended
description:
Mayor of Colombo has instructed to suspend all fines charged relating to parking meters pending council's approval.
 
Colombo Municipal Commissioner Lalith Wickramaratne told us that Colombo Mayor Rosy Senanayake has made this decision due to rising number of complaints against the system.

heading: 20th amendment to be tabled next week
description:
The Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna says that the 20th amendment to the constitution will be tabled in Parliament next week.
 
This amendment proposes to abolish the Executive Presidency.

heading: Steering Committee of Constitutional Assembly meets on Thursday
description:
Member of the Steering Committee, Dr. Jayampathi Wickremarathna said that the final report on the new constitutional amendment and the proposed constitutional draft bill will be discussed at the meeting.
 
Meanwhile, the Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna says that the 20th amendment to the constitution will be tabled in Parliament next week.
 
This amendment proposes to abolish the Executive Presidency.
The Steering Committee of the Constitutional Assembly is scheduled to convene on Thursday under the patronage of Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe.

heading: Indian Chief of Army Staff meets President
description:
President Maithripala Sirisena met with visiting Chief of Army Staff of the Indian Army General Bipin Rawat this morning (May 18).
 
The meeting took place at the President's Official residence in Colombo.
 
The Indian military head has highlighted the importance of improving intelligence sharing between the 2 countries.
 
Meanwhile, the President has said that Sri Lanka seeks Indian military assistance to prevent drug smuggling.

heading: Turbulence in the Bay of Bengal, signs of showers increasing
description:
The Met Department says that turbulence is developing in the vicinity of the Bay of Bengal.
 
Director Athula Karunanayake said that if it develops into a low-pressure zone, heavy showers can be expected in many areas of the island next week.
 
Meanwhile, Assistant Director of the Disaster Management Centre, Pradeep Kodippili advised people living nearby reservoirs to be vigilant for rising water levels in downstream as most of the spill gates are opened now.
 
He stated that 4 spill gates of Deduru Oya, one spill gate of Udawalawa reservoir and one spill gate of Kala Wewa have been opened.
 
The Assistant Director of the Disaster Management Centre further requested the public to refrain from using cordless phones and travelling in open vehicles, during lightning.

heading: Murder accused given death penalty
description:
Three persons who were accused of committing a murder in 2001 were sentenced to death by the Colombo High Court Judge Vikum Kaluarachchi today (May 18).
 
The accused had killed a person on 1st of November in 2001, attacking the victim with sharp objects.
 
The 3 persons were residents of Grandpass.

heading: Fever in South : Death toll risen to 13
description:
Health authorities say 13 persons including 11 children have died from a viral fever spreading in the Southern Province.
 
Southern Province health authorities say that the fever is caused by influenza virus along with the Adino virus and pneumococcal bacteria.
 
Earlier, 5 children died at the Karapitiya Teaching Hospital and 3 of them were affected by influenza and other 2 had infected with the Adino virus and pneumococcal bacteria.
 
So far blood samples of 84 persons have been sent to Medical Research Institute in Borella for testing and 27 of those have been infected with influenza along with Adino virus and pneumococcal bacteria.
 
The health authorities say pregnant mothers and small children are more prone to this disease.
 
They urge the public to seek medical advice if fever persists more than one day.

heading: Heroin trafficker arrested in Hikkaduwa
description:
Police Narcotic Bureau has arrested a drug trafficker in Hikkaduwa.
 
The suspect had 101.4g of heroin in his possession at the time of his arrest.
 
The 39-year-old suspect is a resident of Akmeemana, Galle.

heading: More rains predicted
description:
Met Department says Southwest monsoon conditions are getting established over the island.
 
Prevailing rainy condition along with cloudy skies in the South-west part of the island is expected to continue for tomorrow (May 21).
 
Showers or thundershowers will occur at times in Western, Southern, Sabaragamuwa, Central and North-western provinces.
 
Showers or thundershowers will occur elsewhere particularly after 2 pm.
 
Very heavy falls, about 150 mm can be expected at some places in Sabaragamuwa province.
 
Heavy falls, above 100 mm can be expected at some places, particularly in Western Central and Uva provinces and in Galle and Matara districts.

heading: UPFA Gen. Sec. says ready to decide on withdrawing from National Government
description:
The General Secretary of the United People’s Freedom Alliance, Minister Mahinda Amaraweera says that they are prepared to make a decision favourable to the country with regard to the proposal of leaving the National Unity government.
 
The Minister made this statement in response to questions raised by journalists after paying courtesy calls on the chief prelates of Malwathu and Asgiri Chapters in Kandy, this morning (May 20).

heading: 20 A to be tabled in Parliament
description:
The Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna says that the 20th amendment to the constitution which proposes the abolition of the Executive Presidency will be tabled in Parliament tomorrow (May 22).
 
When contacted the JVP MP Bimal Ratnayake said that the party leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake will table it as a private motion.

heading: Main rivers reaching spill level, people warned of possible floods
description:
The Disaster Management Center urges the people who are living in low-lying areas of Nilwala, Kalu, Gin, Kelani rivers and Aththanagalu and Maa Oya to be vigilant for possible floods.
 
Meanwhile, the death toll as a result of the inclement weather has risen to 6.
 
Four persons including a Buddhist nun died from being struck by lightning in separate incidents in Horana, Welikanda.
 
Another person died as a soil mound collapsed on their house at Undugoda in Bulathkohupitiya last night.
 
In Monaragala, a woman died after a tree branch fell on her in Badalkumubura.
 
The Disaster management Center has requested that the public take precautionary measures during lightning and storms.
 
Additionally, the center has requested the public to refrain from visiting flood-affected areas on sight-seeing.
 
Our correspondents reported that traffic has been affected in many areas due flooding.
 
Meanwhile, Education Minister, Akila Viraj Kariyawasam said that authority has been vested in zonal education officers, including school principals to decide whether schools should be closed or not, due to the inclement weather conditions.
 
It was announced that schools in Ratnapura, Nivitigala and Dehiovita educational zones in the Sabaragamuwa Province would remain closed today and tomorrow.
 
 In addition, several schools in Akuressa, Panadugama, and Athuraliye in Matara district were also closed.
 
The Department of Meteorology warned that the impact of ongoing inclement weather could increase if the current low-pressure zone in the Bay of Bengal develops into a depression as it reaches the island.
 
The Department said, however, in the next 24 hour period 100 to 150 millimeters of rain is predicted for the Western, Sabaragamuwa, North-Western, Central, Uva provinces and the districts of Galle and Matara.
 
By 8.30 this morning, 353.8 millimeters of rain was reported in Anamaduwa, Puttalam.
 
The NBRO has issued landslide warning for Galle, Kalutara, Ratnapura, Nuwara Eliya and Kegalle districts and it has been further extended for another 24 hours.
 
A “Red alert” has been issued for Palinda Nuwara Divisional Secretariat for landslides.
 
The evacuation of residents in areas prone to landslides has begun.

heading: Finance Minister instructs officials to release funds
description:
Finance Minister Mangala Samaraweera today (May 22) instructed the Treasury officials to release adequate funds to help the disaster-affected people.
 
The Ministry said required funds will be released to District Secretaries and Disaster Management Center.
 
Meanwhile, as a result of persistent rains, the Malwana town is completely inundated.
 
It has obstructed the vehicular traffic Dekatana - Colombo road.
 
The Bandarawatte junction in Biyagama is also under water.
 
The Ratnapura - Kiriella - Elapatha road is also under water.
 
Meanwhile, the Ministry of Power and Renewable Energy said the hydro-power generation has improved by 30% as a result of the prevailing weather.

heading: 4 Ava Group members arrested in Jaffna
description:
Police Special Task Force has arrested 4 members of the Ava Group in Kodikamam, Jaffna.
 
The STF personnel also seized 2 motorbikes, 2 swords and several other weapons in the possession of the suspects.
 
A senior officer at the Police STF told our news team that the arrested suspects are aged between 18 and 25.
 
They were scheduled to be produced before Kodikamam Magistrate today (May 20).

heading: Bus fare revision list released
description:
The bus fares will be increased by 12.5 percent from midnight today (May 22).
 
The minimum charge will be revised to Rs. 12.
 
The list of new charges:

heading: Expressway bus fares too increased
description:
The bus fares of expressways have also been revised in line with the 12.5% bus fare revision which will be effective from midnight today (May 22).
The expressway charge of Rs. 500 from Maharagama to Matara will be revised to Rs. 560.
The bus fare to Galle from Maharagama will be Rs. 450.
The new bus fare from Kadawatha to Galle will be Rs. 490 and from Kadawatha to Matara, the bus fare will be Rs. 600.

heading: Team of experts to visit South to investigate viral flu
description:
A group of specialists from the Epidemiology Unit of the Ministry of Health tomorrow (May 21) will leave the Southern Province to investigate the viral fever which is spreading area.
 
The Director Generate of the Health Services Dr. Anil Jasinghe said that the team will visit Galle, Matara, and Kamburupitiya areas to check the situation.
 
He added that based on investigations done so far, certain preventive measures have been introduced.
 
13 persons including 11 children have died from the virus spreading in the Southern Province.

heading: Traffic on Kaduwela Bridge restricted
description:
The traffic on the Kaduwela Bridge on the New Kandy Road has been restricted.
 
The authorities say that the soil erosion on the river banks and the imminent danger of part of the bridge being sunk were the reasons to restrict traffic on the bridge.
 
Now only one lane of the bridge is open for traffic.

heading: SLFP’s 16-member group prepares a policy statement
description:
Former Minister Susil Premajayantha says they the 16-member Sri Lanka Freedom Party group who recently resigned from the government is preparing a policy statement.
 
Premajayantha said that the policy statement contains 21 issues that have a direct impact on the day-to-day life of the masses.
 
The group has mentioned the reasons for their recent resignation from the government, in this document.
 
 In addition, the group expects to conduct a series of awareness conferences throughout the island.

heading: Water level of Rajanganaya Reservoir rising
description:
Disaster Management Center says 2 spill gates of the Rajanganaya Reservoir have been opened.
The DMC advises people at downstream to be vigilant.

heading: Weather havoc : Death toll risen, rains to continue
description:
The Disaster Management Centre says that the adverse weather has hit 19 districts affecting around 126,000.
 
The death toll has now reportedly risen to 15.
 
Meanwhile, 20 spill gates of the Thabbowa Reservoir in Puttalam have been opened.
 
The Disaster Management Centre has advised those living downstream to be vigilant.
 
Meanwhile, Director of the Irrigation Department Mala Alawathugoda said that the water levels of main rivers are receding.
 
The Met Department states that the prevailing rains in the South-Western part of the island are expected to continue today.
 
Showers or thunderstorms will occur at times in Western, Southern, Sabaragamuwa, Central and North-Western provinces and elsewhere after 2 pm.
 
The Duty Meteorologist Sathushka Premachandra stated that Heavy rainfalls of 50mm are predicted for Sabaragamuwa, Western, Central and North-Western provinces and in Galle, Matara districts.

heading: Weather havoc : Death toll risen to 12
description:
The Disaster Management Center says 124,733 persons in 18 districts are affected due to the prevailing inclement weather.
 
It added that the death toll has increased to 12.
 
The DMC said that displaced persons are given shelter at 229 welfare centers.

heading: President intervenes to solve issues of Immigration & Emigration union
description:
President Maithripala Sirisena has paid his attention to solve the issues of Immigration and Emigration officers.
 
A group of representatives from their union met with President Sirisena in Colombo yesterday (May 24).
 
Here, they have pointed out the issues facing them when executing their duties.
 
It was agreed during the discussion to raise those issues with relevant authorities and solve them step by step.

heading: Murder of Dhananjaya's father : Police probe underworld link
description:
Police have initiated investigations to look into whether underworld is linked to the murder of the father of Sri Lanka national cricketer, Dhananjaya de Silva.
Police state that they are scrutinizing the CCTV footage in connection with the shooting.
A senior police officer attached to the Mt. Lavinia police said that it will be helpful to trace the suspects of the shooting at Gnanendra Road, Ratmalana.
The assailants had arrived in a white motorcar and shot K. Ranjan de Silva at 8.30 pm yesterday.
T-56 firearms were used by Ranjan de Silva’s assailants and police found 12 gunshots in the victim’s body.
Police also said the 62-year old Dehiwala Mt. Lavinia Municipal Councilor, Ranjan de Silva was talking with some of his friends in front of his home at the time of the shooting.
Meanwhile, a spokesperson from the Kalubowila hospital stated that the condition of the two friends of Ranjan de Silva who were with the latter at the time of the shooting is not critical.
Police believe that an underworld gang is responsible for the shooting.

heading: Police constable at Gokarella commits suicide
description:
A police constable attached to Gokarella police committed suicide by shooting himself, using his service weapon.
 
It was revealed that the wife of the police constable, who was not well following an accident 2 years, had died this afternoon.
 
After hearing of the death of his wife, the police constable had shot himself inside the dormitory at around 7.30 pm.
 
He was a father of 3 children and was aged 48 years.

heading: Water levels of Kalu, Kelani, Gin, Nilwala Rivers and Attanagalu and Ma Oya recede, 138,000 affected
description:
The Irrigations Department says that water levels of Kalu, Kelani, Gin, Nilwala Rivers as well as Attanagalu Oya and Ma Oya are gradually receding.
 
Director of the Irrigation Department Mala Alawathugoda stated that heavy showers were not experienced in catchment areas during the last 9 hours.
 
Meanwhile, the Disaster Management Centre said that those living in low lying areas in Negombo, Ja Ela, Katana, Minuwangoda, Gampaha and Attanagalla should be vigilant as water levels of Attanagalu Oya is remained high.
 
People residing in Badalgama and Giriulla were also cautioned due to the high water levels of Ma Oya.
 
138 thousand 292 persons of 35 thousand 129 families have been affected by the inclement weather which has affected 20 districts.
 
16 persons have lost their lives as a result of the weather-related incidents.
 
The Disaster Management Centre further said that one sluice gate of Laxapana Reservoir continues to be opened while 12 sluices gates of Thabbowa are also remained open.
 
The landslide warning issued for Ratnapura, Kegalle, Nuwara Eliya, Kalutara and Galle will also continue to be in effect.
 
Meanwhile, the Met Department said that prevailing rainy conditions in the South-Western part of the island is expected to continue.
 
Showers or thundershowers will occur at times in Western, Southern, Sabaragamuwa, Central and North-Western provinces.

heading: STF detect Kerala cannabis (Photos)
description:
Special Task Force arrested a suspect in Kilinochchi yesterday (May 27) with 1.6 kilos of Kerala cannabis.
 
The raid was conducted following a tip-off and the contraband was ready to be distributed.
 
The suspect had obtained cannabis from racketeers in Jaffna.
 
Police said that the arrested person along with the narcotic haul will be produced before Kilinochchi Magistrate today (May 28).

heading: Leopard dies in Norwood (Photos)
description:
A carcass of a young leopard was found in a grassland in Norwood.
An official from the Nallatanniya Forest Office said that the leopard had caught up in a trap, and it was 4-foot in length.
He said that the persons who have killed the leopard had removed its teeth and nails before dumping the carcass here.

heading: SriLankan flight veers off in Cochin while landing, no injuries to passengers
description:
SriLankan Airlines says its flight UL 167 en-route from Colombo to Cochin while landing at Cochin International Airport during an intense rain, veered towards the runway edge and caused damages to some ground lights.
 
In a statement, the airline said no passengers were injured in the incident that happened at around 3.30 pm today (May 27).
 
Thereafter, the aircraft was thoroughly inspected and certified as undamaged by SriLankan Airlines’ engineering staff.
 
There was minor damage to two lights on the runway. The flight was carrying a total of 228 passengers and 12 crew members.

heading: Heated argument ends in murder
description:
A 39-year-old person was murdered after attacking him with a sharp object in Mudunpitakanda at Kirindiwella in Radawana.
